{"type":"json_schema","json_schema":{"id":15805,"attracts":[],"care_guides_details":[{"type":"watering","description":"Flavoparmelia baltimorensis (rock greenshield lichen) does not require traditional watering as it is not a vascular plant like most garden plants. Instead, it derives moisture from rain, humidity, and the surrounding air. Thus, naturally occurring precipitation typically provides adequate moisture. In dry climates or during extended periods without rain, occasional misting can help maintain optimal moisture levels. However, avoid over-misting, as lichens are sensitive to excess moisture and prolonged dampness, which can lead to deterioration. Consider environmental conditions and be mindful of the natural habitat to mimic moisture needs."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Flavoparmelia baltimorensis thrives in environments where it can receive indirect sunlight. It can typically be found growing on rocks in partly shaded areas. While it does need some sunlight, ensure that it is not exposed to intense, direct sunlight for prolonged periods as this can cause desiccation and damage. Instead, aim for a balance where it can receive dappled light or filtered sunlight, similar to the conditions found in its natural habitat. Maintaining a balance between light and shade will help support its photosynthetic needs without causing stress from overexposure."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning is not typically required for Flavoparmelia baltimorensis, as lichens grow slowly and do not have stems or leaves that require regular trimming. Instead, if necessary, gently remove any debris or dead sections that might accumulate on the lichen’s surface, taking care not to damage the healthy parts. Minimal intervention is best, given the symbiotic relationship between fungi and algae or cyanobacteria in lichens. Focus on maintaining a clean growing environment to support healthy lichen growth rather than frequent pruning, which is not part of their care routine."}],"care_level":"Medium","common_name":"rock greenshield lichen","description":"Flavoparmelia baltimorensis or Rock greenshield lichen (from Lichens of North America) is a medium to large foliose lichen with a yellow green upper surface when dry; lobes rounded without pseudocyphellae; the upper surface with globose, pustule-like growths resembling isidia. Lower surface is black with a narrow brown zone at the margins.","family":null,"flower_color":null,"flowering_season":false,"fruit_color":null,"growth_rate":"Low","harvest_season":null,"leaf_color":["Green-Gray"],"maintenance":"Low","origin":["North America"],"other_name":["rock greenshield lichen"],"pest_susceptibility":[],"propagation":["Fragmentation"],"pruning_month":["March"],"scientific_name":["Flavoparmelia baltimorensis"],"soil":["Well-drained","Gravely","Acidic"],"watering_period":"Morning"}}

{"type":"json_schema","json_schema":{"id":14314,"attracts":[],"care_guides_details":[{"type":"watering","description":"Euphrasia nemorosa, commonly known as Eyebright, typically requires relatively little watering once established, as it thrives in well-drained soils and can tolerate periods of dryness. However, during its initial growth phase or during extended dry spells, it should be watered moderately to prevent the soil from completely drying out. It is crucial to avoid waterlogging, as too much moisture can lead to root rot. Ensure that the plant is not standing in water and that excess water is allowed to drain out fully. It's generally best to mimic its natural habitat's moisture levels."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Euphrasia nemorosa prefers a location that receives full to partial sunlight. Ideally, it should be exposed to at least 4 to 6 hours of sunlight daily. This plant tends to grow in open fields and rocky places in its natural habitat, where it receives plenty of light. In areas with intensely hot climates, some afternoon shade can be beneficial to protect it from scorching. However, insufficient light may result in poor blooming and leggy growth. Therefore, positioning it in an area with ample light is essential for its optimal health and flowering."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning Euphrasia nemorosa is relatively straightforward and involves removing spent flowers and any dead or yellowing foliage to encourage new growth and flowering. Pruning can be done by lightly trimming the plants with scissors or pruning shears. Since Eyebright is an annual, significant pruning is not required, but keeping the plant tidy encourages a healthier appearance and prevents potential disease. Ensure to disinfect the pruning tools before use to avoid transferring possible infections. It is usually pruned during the growing season, but be gentle to not harm the plant's main structure."}],"care_level":"Easy","common_name":"Common Eyebright","description":null,"family":null,"flower_color":"White","flowering_season":false,"fruit_color":null,"growth_rate":"Moderate","harvest_season":null,"leaf_color":["Green"],"maintenance":"Moderate","origin":["Europe"],"other_name":["Common Eyebright"],"pest_susceptibility":[],"propagation":["Seed Propagation"],"pruning_month":["October"],"scientific_name":["Euphrasia nemorosa"],"soil":["Well-drained"],"watering_period":"Morning"}}

{"type":"json_schema","json_schema":{"id":14811,"attracts":["Bees"],"care_guides_details":[{"type":"watering","description":"Mimosa diplotricha typically thrives in moist, well-draining soil, so watering should be regular but not excessive. Water the plant deeply about once a week, allowing the soil to dry out slightly between waterings to prevent root rot. In hotter, drier months, you may need to water more frequently, while in cooler or wetter seasons, reduce watering to prevent waterlogging. The plant's leaves will usually droop when it's thirsty, signaling that it's time for watering. However, be cautious not to overwater, as this can damage the plant."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Mimosa diplotricha prefers full sun locations for optimum growth, although it can tolerate partial shade. Ideally, position the plant where it can receive at least 6 to 8 hours of direct sunlight each day. In regions with extreme heat, some afternoon shade can be beneficial to prevent leaf scorch. However, too much shade will result in sparse foliage and reduced flowering, as the plant thrives in bright conditions. Ensure the plant is in a well-ventilated area to avoid mildew, which thrives in overly shaded and damp conditions."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning Mimosa diplotricha is essential to control its vigorous growth and prevent it from overtaking other plants. Prune the plant regularly by cutting back branches to maintain its shape and encourage bushier growth. The best time to prune is during the growing season when the plant is actively expanding. Removing dead or damaged branches also helps prevent disease. By keeping it well-pruned, you also reduce the risk of the plant becoming invasive, as it tends to spread rapidly if not controlled. Always use clean, sharp tools to prevent damage."}],"care_level":"Medium","common_name":"giant false sensitive plant","description":"Mimosa diplotricha is a species of leguminous woody shrub native to the Neotropics. It is an invasive species and now has a pantropical distribution. It is commonly known as the giant sensitive plant, giant false sensitive plant, or nila grass.","family":null,"flower_color":"Pink","flowering_season":false,"fruit_color":null,"growth_rate":"High","harvest_season":null,"leaf_color":["Green"],"maintenance":"Moderate","origin":["South America"],"other_name":["giant false sensitive plant"],"pest_susceptibility":[],"propagation":["Seed Propagation"],"pruning_month":["March"],"scientific_name":["Mimosa diplotricha"],"soil":["Well-drained","Acidic"],"watering_period":"Morning"}}

{"type":"json_schema","json_schema":{"id":14118,"attracts":["Bees","Butterflies"],"care_guides_details":[{"type":"watering","description":"Trillium sessile requires consistent moisture, particularly during its active growing season in the spring. It prefers well-drained, organically rich soil that retains moisture. Regular watering is crucial if the period is dry, as the plant does not tolerate drought well. However, it is important to avoid waterlogging, which can lead to root rot. During the summer months, when the plant is dormant, reduce watering significantly, allowing the soil to dry out slightly between waterings, mimicking its natural woodland habitat."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Trillium sessile thrives best in partial to full shade, mimicking its natural woodland environment. It is well adapted to the dappled sunlight found under trees. Direct sunlight can be too harsh and can scorch the leaves, particularly in hotter climates. In the wild, they are often found on forest floors that receive filtered light, which keeps the soil cool and moist. When planting Trillium sessile in a garden, choose a spot that gets morning sun followed by afternoon shade, or full shade if the area is warm and dry."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning is not typically required for Trillium sessile, as it is a low-maintenance plant. After the flowering season, you may remove spent flowers to maintain a tidy appearance, although it is not necessary for the plant’s health. In autumn, once the foliage has yellowed and begun to die back, you can cut it back to the ground. This process helps to improve the plant's overall aesthetic and ensures better growth the following spring. Avoid cutting back green leaves, as they continue to photosynthesize and provide energy for next year's growth."}],"care_level":"Medium","common_name":"toadshade","description":"Trillium sessile, the toadshade or sessile-flowered wake-robin, is a perennial spring wildflower native to the central part of the eastern United States and the Ozarks. It is a small trillium (rarely over 9 cm tall). Toadshade can be distinguished from other trilliums by its single foul smelling, stalkless, flower nestled in the middle of its three leaves. The three maroon petals, maintain a \"closed\" posture throughout its presence, the petals are occasionally pale green. The leaves are...","family":null,"flower_color":"Red","flowering_season":false,"fruit_color":null,"growth_rate":"Low","harvest_season":null,"leaf_color":["Green"],"maintenance":"Low","origin":["North America"],"other_name":["toadshade"],"pest_susceptibility":[],"propagation":["Seed Propagation"],"pruning_month":["October"],"scientific_name":["Trillium sessile"],"soil":["Acidic","Well-drained","Rich in organic matter"],"watering_period":"Morning"}}

{"type":"json_schema","json_schema":{"id":15309,"attracts":["Bees","Butterflies"],"care_guides_details":[{"type":"watering","description":"Coreopsis leavenworthii, commonly known as Leavenworth's Tickseed, prefers well-drained soil and can tolerate both drought and occasional flooding. To ensure optimum growth, water the plant moderately, allowing the soil to dry out slightly between waterings. Overwatering should be avoided as it can lead to root rot. During dry spells, especially in the hotter months, more frequent watering might be required to maintain the plant's vibrancy and flowering. Ensure that any excess water can drain away easily to prevent the roots from being waterlogged, which could harm the plant's health."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Coreopsis leavenworthii thrives in full sun conditions, requiring at least six hours of direct sunlight per day for optimal growth and flowering. This plant is well-suited to sunny areas and can even flourish in hot, arid climates, making it a great choice for gardens with ample sun exposure. While it can tolerate partial shade, too little sunlight may result in reduced flowering and a leggier appearance. For best results, ensure that the plant is positioned in a location where it is not overshadowed by taller plants or structures, maximizing its exposure to sunlight throughout the day."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning Coreopsis leavenworthii is an essential practice to encourage healthy growth and prolonged blooming. Deadhead spent flowers regularly to prevent seed formation and promote continuous blooming throughout the season. At the end of the growing season, or in early spring, cut back the foliage to about one-third of its height to maintain a neat appearance and stimulate new growth. If the plant becomes too leggy or overgrown during the growing season, a light trim can help restore its shape. Avoid pruning too aggressively, as this can stress the plant and hinder its growth."}],"care_level":"Easy","common_name":"Leavenworth's Tickseed","description":"Coreopsis leavenworthii (Leavenworth's Tickseed) is an annual or short lived perennail plant species in the sunflower family. It is often grouped within Coreopsis tinctoria which it resembles.","family":null,"flower_color":"Yellow","flowering_season":false,"fruit_color":"[\"Brown\"]","growth_rate":"Moderate","harvest_season":null,"leaf_color":["Green"],"maintenance":"Low","origin":["United States"],"other_name":["Leavenworth's Tickseed"],"pest_susceptibility":[],"propagation":["Seed Propagation"],"pruning_month":["November"],"scientific_name":["Coreopsis leavenworthii"],"soil":["Well-drained","Sandy"],"watering_period":"Morning"}}

{"type":"json_schema","json_schema":{"id":15011,"attracts":[],"care_guides_details":[{"type":"watering","description":"Carex sparganioides, commonly known as bur sedge, prefers consistently moist soil conditions, mimicking its natural woodland habitat. Ensure the soil is well-draining, yet retains moisture, to prevent the plant from drying out. During dry spells or extremely hot weather, it may require more frequent watering to maintain soil moisture. However, avoid waterlogging the plant, as excessive water can lead to root rot. In general, aim to keep the soil evenly moist, especially during the growing season in spring and summer. Allow the top inch of soil to dry out slightly between waterings during the dormant winter months."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Carex sparganioides thrives in partial to full shade, replicating its natural environment of woodland settings. It can tolerate some morning sun, but intense afternoon sun can scorch its leaves. If planting in a garden, choose a location that's protected from harsh direct sunlight, particularly during the hottest parts of the day. In shadier spots, it will flourish and show its best growth and form. However, it can also survive in lightly dappled sunlight, making it a versatile choice for a variety of shaded garden areas. Ideal conditions will help prevent stress and promote lush, healthy foliage."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning Carex sparganioides involves removing dead or damaged foliage to maintain its health and appearance. In early spring, cut back old and discolored leaves to make way for new growth. This can be done using clean, sharp garden scissors or shears. It's not necessary to prune heavily, as this sedge has a naturally tidy form. Throughout the growing season, you can occasionally trim back stray or untidy stems to encourage compact growth. Avoid cutting into the crown of the plant, as this can damage new shoots. Pruning is mainly aesthetic and helps rejuvenate the plant's appearance."}],"care_level":"Medium","common_name":"bur reed sedge","description":"Bur-reed sedge (Carex sparganioides) is a perennial plant belonging to the sedge family (Cyperaceae). Its native range includes most of the Eastern and Central U.S., and it is typically found in hardwood or mixed forests. It typically grows 30–100 centimeters (12–39 in) high, and contains teardrop-shaped seed sacs within egg-shaped spikelets.","family":null,"flower_color":null,"flowering_season":false,"fruit_color":null,"growth_rate":"Low","harvest_season":null,"leaf_color":["Green"],"maintenance":"Low","origin":["North America"],"other_name":["bur reed sedge"],"pest_susceptibility":[],"propagation":["Seed Propagation","Division"],"pruning_month":["March"],"scientific_name":["Carex sparganioides"],"soil":["Well-drained","Loamy"],"watering_period":"Morning"}}

{"type":"json_schema","json_schema":{"id":15706,"attracts":["Bees","Butterflies"],"care_guides_details":[{"type":"watering","description":"The Juglans major, or Arizona walnut, is a tree that prefers moderate watering. It is adapted to arid and semi-arid climates, so it is drought tolerant once established. During its initial growth phase, it needs regular watering to help develop a robust root system. Water deeply but infrequently, allowing the soil to dry out between waterings. Overwatering can lead to root rot, so it’s crucial to ensure the soil has good drainage. As the tree matures, you can reduce the frequency of watering, but ensure the tree receives adequate moisture during prolonged dry spells."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"The Arizona walnut thrives best in full sunlight. It requires at least six hours of direct sunlight per day to ensure healthy growth and optimal nut production. This tree is well-suited for open spaces without shade competition from towering structures or other large trees. While it can tolerate partial shade, insufficient sunlight exposure may result in reduced growth vigor and fewer nuts. Full sun exposure also helps to reduce moisture levels around the tree, minimizing the risk of fungal diseases. Ensure the planting location grants ample sunlight to support the tree's development and longevity."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning for the Juglans major is best done in late winter or early spring before new growth begins. Focus on removing any dead, damaged, or diseased branches to maintain the tree’s health and structure. Additionally, thin out crowded branches to allow better air circulation and light penetration. This will help prevent fungal infections and promote healthy growth. Avoid heavy pruning as it may stress the tree; instead, make small and strategic cuts to shape the tree and remove any competing leaders to encourage a strong central trunk. Regular pruning helps develop a sturdy, aesthetically pleasing form."}],"care_level":"Medium","common_name":"Arizona black walnut","description":"Juglans major (literally, the larger walnut), also known as Arizona walnut, is a walnut tree which grows to 50 ft tall (15 m) with a DBH of up to 0.61 metres (2 ft) at elevations of 300–2,130 m (1,000–7,000 ft) in Texas, Oklahoma, New Mexico, Arizona, and Utah. It also occurs in Mexico as far south as Guerrero. Common names include Arizona black walnut (as it belongs to the \"black walnuts\" section Juglans sect. Rhysocaryon), and the Spanish name nogal cimarrón...","family":null,"flower_color":"Green","flowering_season":false,"fruit_color":"[\"Brown\"]","growth_rate":"Moderate","harvest_season":"Autumn","leaf_color":["Green"],"maintenance":"Moderate","origin":["Southwest United States","Northern Mexico"],"other_name":["Arizona black walnut"],"pest_susceptibility":[],"propagation":["Seed Propagation"],"pruning_month":["November"],"scientific_name":["Juglans major"],"soil":["Well-drained","Sandy","Loamy"],"watering_period":"Morning"}}

{"type":"json_schema","json_schema":{"id":14513,"attracts":[],"care_guides_details":[{"type":"watering","description":"Gymnosporangium juniperi-virginianae, commonly known as cedar-apple rust, is a type of fungus, and not a plant that requires watering. However, it's part of a life cycle involving both juniper and apple or crabapple trees. To manage this fungus, ensure trees are well-watered to keep them healthy in general. Junipers should be watered at the base to prevent fungal growth. Avoid overhead watering, as moisture on leaves can encourage fungal development. Proper watering aids in maintaining the overall health of the host plants, making them less susceptible to infection."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Gymnosporangium juniperi-virginianae is a fungus affecting junipers and apples, so the light requirement pertains to these plants. Both juniper and apple trees generally thrive in full sun, which also aids in controlling fungal infections. Sunlight can help reduce moisture levels and thus the proliferation of the fungus. Ensuring that these plants receive adequate sunlight (at least 6-8 hours a day) can promote health and vigor, making them more resistant to infections like cedar-apple rust. Adequate sun exposure also helps dry leaf surfaces, reducing the likelihood of fungal growth."},{"type":"pruning","description":"For managing Gymnosporangium juniperi-virginianae, it's crucial to focus on the host plants, mainly junipers and apple or crabapple trees. Pruning involves removing and destroying any galls found on juniper plants before the orange spores appear typically in spring. On apple trees, regularly inspect for any signs of infection, and prune affected leaves or branches immediately to reduce fungal spread. Use sterilized pruning tools to prevent spreading the fungus. This kind of careful management helps prevent the fungus from completing its life cycle between these plants."}],"care_level":"Medium","common_name":"juniper-apple rust","description":"Gymnosporangium juniperi-virginianae is a plant pathogen that causes cedar-apple rust. In virtually any location where apples or crabapples (Malus) and Eastern red-cedar (Juniperus virginiana) coexist, cedar apple rust can be a destructive or disfiguring disease on both the apples and cedars. Quince and hawthorn are the most common host and many species of juniper can substitute for the eastern red cedars.","family":null,"flower_color":null,"flowering_season":false,"fruit_color":null,"growth_rate":"Moderate","harvest_season":null,"leaf_color":null,"maintenance":"Moderate","origin":["North America"],"other_name":["juniper-apple rust"],"pest_susceptibility":["Fungal leaf spot","Canker"],"propagation":[],"pruning_month":["March"],"scientific_name":["Gymnosporangium juniperi-virginianae"],"soil":["Well-drained","Loamy"],"watering_period":"Morning"}}

Ensure the plant receives at least 4-6 hours of direct sunlight for optimal growth."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning of Carex frankii is minimal and usually involves removing any dead or damaged foliage throughout the growing season. If the plant becomes too dense, it can also be divided during this time. {"type":"json_schema","json_schema":{"id":14613,"attracts":["Bees"],"care_guides_details":[{"type":"watering","description":"Narcissus papyraceus, commonly known as paperwhite narcissus, requires careful watering to prevent bulb rot. During the growing season, water them thoroughly but allow the soil to dry slightly between waterings. Typically, this means watering once or twice a week. Ensure that your container or garden bed has good drainage, as paperwhites do not tolerate soggy soil. Once the flowering period ends, gradually reduce watering until foliage dies back, at which point you should stop watering altogether as the bulbs enter dormancy."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Narcissus papyraceus thrives in full sunlight, which supports robust growth and flowering. Ideally, provide them with at least six hours of direct sunlight each day. In regions with hot climates, some afternoon shade might be beneficial to prevent excessive heat stress. If growing indoors, place them near a south-facing window to maximize light exposure. However, indirect sunlight can also work, though it might prolong the growth period and lead to taller, more leggy plants. Ensure that lighting conditions encourage steady, healthy growth."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning is not typically required for Narcissus papyraceus, but removing spent blooms can improve appearance and direct the plant's energy back into the bulb for next season's growth. After flowering, allow the foliage to remain until it yellows and dies back naturally, as this process is crucial for photosynthesis and replenishing the bulb's nutrients. Avoid cutting back green leaves prematurely. Clean up any dead or yellowed foliage to maintain a tidy appearance and prevent disease."}],"care_level":"Easy","common_name":"Paperwhite","description":"Narcissus papyraceus (from papyrus and aceus; meaning paper-like), one of a few species known as paperwhite, is a perennial bulbous plant native to the Mediterranean region, from Greece to Portugal plus Morocco and Algeria. The species is considered naturalized in the Azores, Corsica, Texas, California and Louisiana. The white flowers are borne in bunches and are strongly fragrant. It is frequently grown as a house plant, often forced to flower at Christmas.","family":null,"flower_color":"White","flowering_season":false,"fruit_color":"[\"Green\"]","growth_rate":"Moderate","harvest_season":"Winter","leaf_color":["Green"],"maintenance":"Low","origin":["Mediterranean"],"other_name":["Paperwhite"],"pest_susceptibility":[],"propagation":["Bulbs","Division","Seed Propagation"],"pruning_month":["March"],"scientific_name":["Narcissus papyraceus"],"soil":["Well-drained","Loamy"],"watering_period":"Morning"}}

{"type":"json_schema","json_schema":{"id":14097,"attracts":[],"care_guides_details":[{"type":"watering","description":"Leucocoprinus birnbaumii, commonly known as the yellow houseplant mushroom, thrives in consistently moist soil, but it is vital not to overwater. Ensure the soil stays slightly moist but never soggy to prevent root rot or other fungal issues in your plants. It's best to water little and often, checking that the top inch of soil has begun to dry before adding more water. Maintaining proper drainage in the pot can also help minimize water retention, creating an ideal environment where these mushrooms may appear, usually indicating high humidity and good soil moisture."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Leucocoprinus birnbaumii mushrooms prefer indirect light environments, which is why they commonly appear indoors, particularly in houseplants kept in partial sunlight. Avoid direct sunlight, which can dry the soil too quickly, especially if you wish to cultivate these mushrooms for their decorative appearance without disturbing them. They require a humid and warm environment to thrive, conditions often achieved in indirect lighting settings. Therefore, providing a warm and slightly shady area mimics their natural environment and supports the mushrooms’ growth."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Leucocoprinus birnbaumii mushrooms themselves do not require pruning as these mushrooms are not a cultivated plant but often appear in potting soil of houseplants. However, if you wish to manage their occurrence because they are purely ornamental and not harmful to plants, you can simply remove them by hand. Prune them as soon as they appear to prevent spore release and further spread. While they do not directly harm plants, regular removal might help to maintain a tidy appearance and prevent proliferation, especially if they are unwanted in your houseplant pots."}],"care_level":"Medium","common_name":"flowerpot parasol","description":"Leucocoprinus birnbaumii is a species of gilled mushroom in the family Agaricaceae. It is common in the tropics and subtropics, but in temperate regions frequently occurs in greenhouses and flowerpots, hence its common names of flowerpot parasol and plantpot dapperling. The fruit bodies are poisonous, if consumed.","family":null,"flower_color":null,"flowering_season":false,"fruit_color":null,"growth_rate":"Moderate","harvest_season":null,"leaf_color":null,"maintenance":"Low","origin":["Tropical regions worldwide"],"other_name":["flowerpot parasol"],"pest_susceptibility":[],"propagation":[],"pruning_month":["February"],"scientific_name":["Leucocoprinus birnbaumii"],"soil":["Well-drained","Loose potting soil"],"watering_period":"Morning"}}

{"type":"json_schema","json_schema":{"id":14812,"attracts":["Pollinators"],"care_guides_details":[{"type":"watering","description":"Hibiscus syriacus, also known as Rose of Sharon, requires consistent watering, especially during dry periods. Ensure the soil remains moist but not waterlogged. During the growing season (spring to early autumn), water deeply once a week if there's no rain. In especially hot or dry climates, increased frequency may be necessary. Allow the top couple of inches of soil to dry out between waterings to prevent root rot. Mulching can help retain soil moisture and reduce the need for frequent watering. Reduce watering during the fall and winter months when the plant is dormant."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Hibiscus syriacus thrives in full sun, requiring at least 6 to 8 hours of direct sunlight daily for optimal flowering. It tolerates a range of light conditions, but insufficient sunlight may result in fewer blooms and weaker growth. In regions with exceptionally high temperatures, some afternoon shade can prevent leaf scorch. When planting, select a location that allows for adequate sunlight exposure throughout the day. If grown indoors, place near a south or west-facing window, ensuring it receives abundant bright light."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning Hibiscus syriacus is best done in late winter or early spring before new growth begins. Start by removing any dead or damaged wood. To control the shape and size of the plant, you can cut back the branches to a healthy node or bud. Thinning the plant by removing some of the older, woodier stems can improve air circulation and encourage new growth. Avoid pruning more than one-third of the plant at a time to prevent stress. Regular pruning helps maintain a tidy appearance and promotes prolific blooming."}],"care_level":"Medium","common_name":"common hibiscus","description":"Hibiscus syriacus is a species of flowering plant in the family Malvaceae, native to India and much of Asia. It was given the epithet syriacus because it had been collected from gardens in Syria. Common names include rose of Sharon (especially in North America), Syrian ketmia or rose mallow (United Kingdom), St Joseph's rod (Italy) and Rosa de Sharon (Brazil).","family":null,"flower_color":"Violet","flowering_season":false,"fruit_color":null,"growth_rate":"Moderate","harvest_season":null,"leaf_color":["Green"],"maintenance":"Moderate","origin":["China","India"],"other_name":["common hibiscus"],"pest_susceptibility":["Aphids","Japanese beetles"],"propagation":["Cutting","Seed Propagation"],"pruning_month":["March"],"scientific_name":["Hibiscus syriacus"],"soil":["Loamy","Well-drained"],"watering_period":"Morning"}}

{"type":"json_schema","json_schema":{"id":15806,"attracts":[],"care_guides_details":[{"type":"watering","description":"Drosera whittakeri, a type of sundew, prefers consistently moist conditions, mimicking its natural boggy habitat. It is important to use distilled or rainwater for watering, as this species is sensitive to the minerals in tap water. The soil should never dry out completely, so maintain a consistently damp environment by watering from the bottom, allowing the plant to absorb water through a tray beneath. Ensure the tray has water at all times for optimal hydration, especially in warmer months. Reducing watering slightly during dormancy in winter is recommended, but never let the soil dry out completely."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Drosera whittakeri thrives in bright, indirect sunlight, which is necessary for its health and robust growth. A windowsill with filtered light or a location where it can receive dappled sunlight for at least 4-6 hours a day is ideal. Direct sunlight can scorch the leaves, while too little light can hinder its growth and reduce its ability to produce dew, critical for its insect-catching capabilities. During the growing season, maintaining consistent light conditions will help ensure healthy development. If natural light is insufficient, consider supplementing with fluorescent grow lights."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning for Drosera whittakeri is minimal but beneficial for maintaining the plant’s health and appearance. Remove dead leaves and spent flower stalks to prevent mold and disease. This can be done by gently snipping them off at the base with sterilized scissors, taking care not to damage surrounding healthy leaves. Pruning helps to direct the plant’s energy into new growth and flower production. Performing maintenance pruning at the end of the growing season, before the winter dormancy period, can also help prepare the plant for a restful and healthy transition into dormancy."}],"care_level":"High","common_name":"Whittaker's sundew","description":"Drosera whittakeri (scented sundew, Whittaker's sundew) is a sundew that is native to South Australia.","family":null,"flower_color":"White","flowering_season":false,"fruit_color":null,"growth_rate":"Low","harvest_season":null,"leaf_color":["Green"],"maintenance":"High","origin":["Australia"],"other_name":["Whittaker's sundew"],"pest_susceptibility":[],"propagation":["Seed Propagation","Tissue Culture"],"pruning_month":["December"],"scientific_name":["Drosera whittakeri"],"soil":["Well-drained","Acidic"],"watering_period":"Morning"}}

{"type":"json_schema","json_schema":{"id":15012,"attracts":["Butterflies"],"care_guides_details":[{"type":"watering","description":"Gomphrena globosa, commonly known as Globe Amaranth, is fairly drought-tolerant once established. During the hot growing season, water the plant more frequently, ensuring the topsoil is dry before each session. In containers, be mindful of drainage to prevent excess water buildup. Reducing the frequency in cooler months is advised, as water needs diminish."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Globe Amaranth thrives best in full sunlight, requiring at least 6 to 8 hours of direct sunlight daily. This plant is well-suited for bright, warm locations and performs superbly when sited in a sunny spot in the garden or on the patio. While it can tolerate partial shade, especially in hotter climates, reduced sunlight may result in fewer blooms. The plant's vibrant flower colors are enhanced by ample sunlight exposure. Ensure it receives enough light, particularly during its peak growing season, for optimal flowering and growth."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning Gomphrena globosa helps promote bushier growth and encourages more blooms. Regularly deadheading the spent flowers is beneficial and keeps the plant looking tidy. To do this, simply snip the spent blooms just above the nearest set of leaves. The plant responds well to cutting back, so feel free to trim any leggy or overgrown stems. It's ideal to perform a more extensive pruning in early spring, which helps to rejuvenate the plant after winter dormancy. Always ensure your pruning tools are clean to prevent the spread of diseases."}],"care_level":"Easy","common_name":"Globe amaranth","description":"Gomphrena globosa, commonly known as globe amaranth, makhmali and bachelor button , is an annual plant that grows up to 24 inches in height. Remove any dead, diseased, or damaged branches whenever noticed. This species benefits from occasional thinning to improve air circulation and reduce pest issues. The best time to prune is in late winter or early spring, before new growth begins. Avoid pruning during the growing season as it can stress the tree. When pruning, make cuts just outside the branch collar to promote proper healing and maintain the tree's natural shape."}],"care_level":"Medium","common_name":"southwestern white pine","description":"Pinus strobiformis, commonly known as Southwestern white pine, Mexican white pine or Chihuahua white pine, is a medium-sized white pine tree whose native habitat is in southwestern United States and Mexico. {"type":"json_schema","json_schema":{"id":15907,"attracts":["Bees","Hummingbirds","Butterflies"],"care_guides_details":[{"type":"watering","description":"Brugmansia suaveolens, commonly known as Angel's Trumpet, requires regular watering to thrive, especially during the growing season in spring and summer. The soil should be kept consistently moist but not waterlogged, which can lead to root rot. It's crucial to allow the top inch of soil to dry out between watering to prevent overwatering. During the dormant season in winter, reduce watering but ensure the soil doesn't completely dry out. Use room temperature water to avoid shocking the roots. Maintaining humidity can also benefit the plant, especially in dry indoor environments."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Brugmansia suaveolens thrives best in full sun to partial shade. Ideally, it should receive at least 4 to 6 hours of direct sunlight daily for optimal growth and flowering. When growing indoors, placing the plant near a south or west-facing window would ensure adequate light exposure. In extremely hot climates, providing some afternoon shade may help protect the plant from leaf scorch. If outdoor temperatures drop significantly, especially in colder zones, it's advisable to bring the plant inside to a location that offers bright, indirect sunlight to mimic its natural growing conditions."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning Brugmansia suaveolens is essential to encourage healthy growth and blooming. It's best to prune in early spring before new growth begins. Remove any dead or damaged branches, which can redirect energy to healthier parts of the plant. Trim back long or unbalanced stems to maintain a desirable shape and size. When pruning, look for the 'Y' joints where new growth tends to start and cut just above these to encourage branching. Use clean, sharp tools to make precise cuts and prevent disease. Regular pruning also helps improve air circulation within the plant's canopy."}],"care_level":"High","common_name":"night bells","description":"Brugmansia suaveolens, Brazil's white angel trumpet, also known as angel's tears, is a South American species of flowering plants that grow as shrubs or small trees with large fragrant flowers.","family":null,"flower_color":"White","flowering_season":false,"fruit_color":null,"growth_rate":"Moderate","harvest_season":null,"leaf_color":["Green"],"maintenance":"Moderate","origin":["Brazil"],"other_name":["night bells"],"pest_susceptibility":["Spider mites","Aphids"],"propagation":["Cutting","Seed Propagation"],"pruning_month":["February"],"scientific_name":["Brugmansia suaveolens"],"soil":["Well-drained","Loamy"],"watering_period":"Morning"}}

{"type":"json_schema","json_schema":{"id":14316,"attracts":["Fish","Marine invertebrates"],"care_guides_details":[{"type":"watering","description":"Posidonia oceanica, also known as Neptune grass, is an aquatic plant found in the Mediterranean Sea, thus does not require traditional watering like land plants. Its care involves ensuring it is completely submerged in clean and nutrient-rich saltwater. If maintained in an aquarium setting, regular water changes and ensuring the correct salinity levels are essential for maintaining healthy Posidonia. Any exposure to pollutants should be avoided, as these can harm or kill the plant."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"For optimal growth, Posidonia oceanica requires ample sunlight as it is naturally found in shallower depths of the Mediterranean Sea where sunlight can penetrate. In an aquarium setting, ensure that the plant receives sufficient light, which can be supplemented with specialized aquatic plant lighting if necessary. Light cycles should mimic natural conditions, providing about 12 hours of light per day. Avoid positioning it in areas entirely deprived of sunlight as insufficient lighting will negatively impact its health and growth."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning Posidonia oceanica is not commonly required unless within an aquarium setting, wherein leaf tips that show signs of decay or damage can be gently trimmed using sterilized scissors to prevent potential spread of rot. Avoid excessive pruning as this can hinder the plant's growth and disrupt its natural habitat."}],"care_level":"Extreme","common_name":"Neptune Grass","description":"Posidonia oceanica (commonly known as Neptune grass or Mediterranean tapeweed) is a seagrass species that is endemic to the Mediterranean Sea. It forms large underwater meadows that are an important part of the ecosystem. The fruit is free floating and known in Italy as \"the olive of the sea\" (l'oliva di mare). Balls of fibrous material from its foliage, known as egagropili, wash up to nearby shorelines.","family":null,"flower_color":null,"flowering_season":false,"fruit_color":null,"growth_rate":"Low","harvest_season":null,"leaf_color":["Green"],"maintenance":"High","origin":["Mediterranean Sea"],"other_name":["Neptune Grass"],"pest_susceptibility":[],"propagation":["Seed Propagation","Rhizome Propagation"],"pruning_month":["June"],"scientific_name":["Posidonia oceanica"],"soil":["Sandy","Gravelly"],"watering_period":"Morning"}}

Be sure to use clean and sharp pruning shears to avoid damaging the plant. Regular pruning also helps in controlling its spreading habit."}],"care_level":"Easy","common_name":"Dakota mock vervain","description":"Glandularia bipinnatifida, commonly called Dakota mock vervain, is a species of flowering plant in the verbena family (Verbenaceae).","family":null,"flower_color":"Pink","flowering_season":false,"fruit_color":"[\"Blue\"]","growth_rate":"Moderate","harvest_season":null,"leaf_color":["Green"],"maintenance":"Low","origin":["United States","Mexico"],"other_name":["Dakota mock vervain"],"pest_susceptibility":["Aphids","Spider mites"],"propagation":["Seed Propagation","Cutting"],"pruning_month":["August"],"scientific_name":["Glandularia bipinnatifida"],"soil":["Well-drained","Sandy","Gravelly"],"watering_period":"Morning"}}

{"type":"json_schema","json_schema":{"id":14813,"attracts":["Bees","Butterflies"],"care_guides_details":[{"type":"watering","description":"Lactuca graminifolia, like many other species of lettuce, thrives best in moist, well-draining soil. The key is to keep the soil consistently moist but not waterlogged. Water deeply but infrequently, ensuring that the soil has a chance to dry out slightly between waterings. During hotter months or dry periods, more frequent watering may be necessary. It's important to avoid overhead watering as wet leaves can promote fungal diseases."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Lactuca graminifolia prefers plenty of sunlight but can also tolerate partial shade. Ideally, it should be grown in a location that receives full sun for at least 6-8 hours a day to ensure robust growth. In hotter climates, providing some shade during the peak afternoon sun can prevent the leaves from wilting and bolting prematurely. If grown indoors, placing the plant near a south-facing window or under grow lights will help meet its sunlight requirements."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning for Lactuca graminifolia generally involves removing any dead or wilted leaves to encourage healthy growth. Regularly inspect the plant and snip off any damaged or diseased leaves at the base using sharp, clean scissors or pruning shears. This not only helps with air circulation but also redirects energy to healthier parts of the plant. Harvesting the outer leaves regularly can also act as a form of pruning, promoting bushier growth."}],"care_level":"Medium","common_name":"grass-leaf lettuce","description":"Lactuca graminifolia, the grassleaf lettuce is a North American species of wild lettuce. It grows in Mexico, Central America, Hispaniola, and the southern United States from Arizona to Florida, Virginia and the Carolinas.","family":null,"flower_color":"White","flowering_season":false,"fruit_color":null,"growth_rate":"Moderate","harvest_season":null,"leaf_color":["Green"],"maintenance":"Moderate","origin":["North America"],"other_name":["grass-leaf lettuce"],"pest_susceptibility":["Fungal leaf spot","Miltonia"],"propagation":["Seed Propagation"],"pruning_month":["July"],"scientific_name":["Lactuca graminifolia"],"soil":["Well-drained","Loamy"],"watering_period":"Morning"}}

{"type":"json_schema","json_schema":{"id":14913,"attracts":["Butterflies","Bees"],"care_guides_details":[{"type":"watering","description":"Cirsium horridulum, commonly known as the bristly thistle, is a hardy plant that thrives in well-drained soil conditions. When watering this plant, ensure that you do not over-saturate the ground, as it prefers slightly dry conditions. Regular watering once a week should suffice, allowing the soil to dry out between waterings. In periods of extended drought, you may increase the frequency, but be cautious not to let the roots sit in water. Mulching around the base of the plant can help retain soil moisture and reduce the need for frequent watering."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"This species thrives in full sun exposure and requires at least six to eight hours of direct sunlight daily. Gardeners should plant Cirsium horridulum in a location that receives ample sunlight to ensure optimal growth and flowering. If grown in partially shaded areas, you might notice a decrease in the plant's vigor and flower production. Therefore, choose a south-facing area or any spot in your garden with unobstructed access to sunlight. Providing ample sunlight will enhance its luster and ensure a more robust and dynamic growth pattern."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning Cirsium horridulum generally involves removing dead or damaged stems and leaves to encourage healthier growth and maintain a neat appearance. You can also cut back the plant after flowering to prevent self-seeding if you do not wish for it to spread too much. Use clean, sharp tools to make clean cuts and avoid spreading diseases. Regularly inspecting the plant for any signs of pests or diseases and addressing them promptly is also part of good pruning practice, ensuring the plant stays healthy and robust."}],"care_level":"Easy","common_name":"bristle thistle","description":"Cirsium horridulum, called bristly thistle, horrid thistle, yellow thistle or bull thistle, is a North American species of plants in the thistle tribe within the sunflower family. {"type":"json_schema","json_schema":{"id":15311,"attracts":[],"care_guides_details":[{"type":"watering","description":"Eupatorium capillifolium, commonly known as dog fennel, prefers moderate watering. It is relatively drought-tolerant once established but thrives best when the soil is kept consistently moist, especially during the growing season. It's important to let the top couple of inches of soil dry out between waterings to prevent root rot. Overwatering can lead to poor plant health, so ensure the plant is in well-draining soil to avoid waterlogging. In periods of high heat or if the plant is in a container, you may need to water more frequently than usual to maintain optimal moisture levels."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Eupatorium capillifolium thrives best in full sun to partial shade conditions. When placed in full sun, it enjoys 6 to 8 hours of direct sunlight per day, which promotes robust growth and helps it develop its distinctive foliage. However, it can also tolerate some partial shade, especially in hotter climates, where some afternoon shade can prevent scorching. If grown in too much shade, the plant may become leggy and produce fewer flowers. Therefore, providing a balanced light environment based on your geographical location is optimal for this plant."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning is not strictly necessary for Eupatorium capillifolium, but it can help maintain a more manageable size and encourage bushier growth. The best time to prune is in late winter or early spring before new growth starts. You can cut back the old stems to about 6 inches above the ground. Removing any dead or damaged branches and spent flowers can tidy up the plant and promote healthier growth. Regular trimming can also prevent the plant from self-seeding excessively, which helps control its spread in the garden."}],"care_level":"Easy","common_name":"dogfennel","description":"Eupatorium capillifolium (dogfennel) is a North American perennial herbaceous plant in the family sunflower family, native to the eastern and south-central United States. It is generally between 50 cm and 2 meters tall with several stems that fork from a substantial base. The stems and base are covered in leaves so dissected that they resemble branching green threads coming out of the stem in fractal patterns. When crushed, the leaves and flowers smell rather unpleasant.","family":null,"flower_color":"Green","flowering_season":false,"fruit_color":null,"growth_rate":"High","harvest_season":null,"leaf_color":["Green"],"maintenance":"Low","origin":["North America"],"other_name":["dogfennel"],"pest_susceptibility":["Fungal leaf spot","Rust"],"propagation":["Seed Propagation"],"pruning_month":["November"],"scientific_name":["Eupatorium capillifolium"],"soil":["Well-drained","Loamy"],"watering_period":"Morning"}}

{"type":"json_schema","json_schema":{"id":15708,"attracts":["Birds"],"care_guides_details":[{"type":"watering","description":"Pistacia chinensis, or Chinese pistache, is drought-tolerant once established but thrives with moderate watering, especially during its first few years. For optimal growth, water the tree deeply but infrequently, allowing the soil to dry out between waterings. During dry spells or extreme heat, you should increase the frequency of watering to prevent stress. Ensure good drainage to prevent root rot, as the tree does not tolerate soggy soil. Mulching around the base helps retain soil moisture and minimize evaporation."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Pistacia chinensis thrives in full sun, ideally receiving at least 6 hours of direct sunlight per day. Full sun exposure encourages its spectacular fall foliage coloration and healthy growth. While it can tolerate partial shade, reduced light may lead to less vibrant leaves and reduced overall vigor. Select a planting site that maximizes sun exposure and ensures the tree can grow without significant shade interference from nearby buildings or taller plants."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning is typically needed to maintain structure and remove dead or crossing branches. It's best to prune Pistacia chinensis in late winter or early spring before new growth starts. Focus on removing suckers from the base of the tree, thinning out crowded areas, and shaping the canopy to your desired form. Avoid heavy pruning, as this can stress the tree. Regular light pruning keeps the tree healthy and attractive, encouraging vigorous growth and optimal canopy shape."}],"care_level":"Medium","common_name":"Chinese pistache","description":"Pistacia chinensis (English: Chinese pistache; Chinese: 黄连木; pinyin: huángliánmù) is a small to medium-sized tree in the genus Pistacia in the cashew family, Anacardiaceae, native to central and western China. It is hardy, can withstand harsh conditions and poor quality soils, and grows up to 20 m. The leaves are deciduous, alternate, pinnate, 20–25 cm long, with 10 or 12 leaflets, the terminal leaflet usually absent. The flowers are produced in panicles 15–20 cm long at the ends...","family":null,"flower_color":"Green","flowering_season":false,"fruit_color":"[\"Red\"]","growth_rate":"Moderate","harvest_season":null,"leaf_color":["Green"],"maintenance":"Moderate","origin":["China","Taiwan"],"other_name":["Chinese pistache"],"pest_susceptibility":[],"propagation":["Seed Propagation","Cutting"],"pruning_month":["February"],"scientific_name":["Pistacia chinensis"],"soil":["Well-drained","Loamy"],"watering_period":"Morning"}}

{"type":"json_schema","json_schema":{"id":14098,"attracts":["Bees","Butterflies"],"care_guides_details":[{"type":"watering","description":"Epiphyllum oxypetalum, or the Queen of the Night, thrives best with consistent but moderate watering. During the growing season, which typically spans spring and summer, ensure that the soil is kept slightly moist but not waterlogged. Water thoroughly when the top inch of soil feels dry. Always avoid letting the plant sit in standing water, as this can lead to root rot. Direct sun exposure, especially during the hottest parts of the day, can scorch the leaves. Ideally, place it near an east or west-facing window where it can receive plenty of morning or late afternoon light. If keeping it indoors, it can benefit from time in a sunroom or other brightly lit area. During its flowering season, ensuring adequate light can enhance bloom production. However, too low light conditions can slow growth and reduce flowering, so balance is key."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning of Epiphyllum oxypetalum is generally done to maintain shape and encourage healthy growth. Remove any dead or damaged stems by cutting them at the base to prevent pest infestations and diseases. It's best to prune after flowering seasons, as the plant flowers on older growth. This also helps redirect the plant's energy towards producing fresh growth and blooms. Use sharp, sterilized pruning shears to make clean cuts and prevent infections. Additionally, removing any overcrowded stems can help in improving air circulation around the plant."}],"care_level":"Medium","common_name":"queen of the night","description":"Epiphyllum oxypetalum (Dutchman's pipe cactus or queen of the night) is a species of cactus and one of the most cultivated species in the genus. E. oxypetalum blooms rarely and only at night, and its flowers wilt before dawn. Though it is sometimes referred to as a nightblooming cereus, it is not closely related to any of the species in the tribe Cereeae, such as Selenicereus, that are more commonly known as nightblooming cereus. All Cereus species...","family":null,"flower_color":"White","flowering_season":false,"fruit_color":null,"growth_rate":"Moderate","harvest_season":null,"leaf_color":["Green"],"maintenance":"Moderate","origin":["Central America","South America"],"other_name":["queen of the night"],"pest_susceptibility":["Aphids","Mealybugs","Spider mites","Scale insects"],"propagation":["Cutting","Seed Propagation"],"pruning_month":["April"],"scientific_name":["Epiphyllum oxypetalum"],"soil":["Well-drained","Loamy"],"watering_period":"Morning"}}

{"type":"json_schema","json_schema":{"id":14515,"attracts":["Bees","Butterflies"],"care_guides_details":[{"type":"watering","description":"Rhus virens, commonly known as the evergreen sumac, requires moderate watering. It's drought-tolerant once established, so allow the topsoil to dry out between waterings. Over-watering can lead to root rot, so ensure the soil is well-drained. During the growing season, regular watering promotes healthy growth, but in the dormant winter months, reduce the frequency. Consider rain patterns in your region; during periods of rain, additional watering may not be necessary. Mulching can help retain soil moisture, reducing the need for frequent watering, especially in hot climates."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Rhus virens thrives in full sun to partial shade. For optimal growth, provide at least 6 hours of direct sunlight daily. However, it can tolerate some afternoon shade, especially in hotter regions. Ensure it's not planted in deep shade, as it may struggle to survive. Adjust sunlight exposure based on local climate conditions to keep the plant healthy and vigorous."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning Rhus virens is essential to maintain its shape and encourage dense growth. Prune in late winter or early spring before new growth starts. Remove any dead or damaged branches, and thin out dense areas to improve air circulation. To keep the shrub compact, trim back long stems just above a leaf bud. If you're managing its size in a landscape, you can prune back harder, but be aware that it flowers on old wood, so excessive pruning may reduce blooms for the season. Regular pruning helps prevent leggy growth and promotes vibrant foliage."}],"care_level":"Easy","common_name":"evergreen sumac","description":"Rhus virens is a species of flowering plant in the mango family, Anacardiaceae, that is native to Arizona, southern New Mexico, and Texas in the United States as well as northern and central Mexico as far south as Oaxaca. In winter or during dormant periods, reduce the frequency of watering. It thrives best in well-drained soils, so ensure the pot or ground allows excess water to escape. If it's grown indoors or in shady areas, ensure it gets some direct sunlight each day to prevent weak, leggy growth. Ideally, choose a spot with bright, consistent sunlight access to foster healthy development and maximize resilience."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning Pongamia pinnata is essential for maintaining its shape and encouraging vigorous growth. It is best done in late winter or early spring before new growth begins. Regularly remove any dead, diseased, or damaged branches to ensure healthy growth. Thin out the canopy if the tree becomes too dense; this improves air circulation and allows sunlight to penetrate the inner branches. Prune to maintain a desired shape or size, cutting above a bud or branch collar to promote branching. Avoid excessive pruning as it can stress the tree. Be careful not to over-moisten, as this can lead to substrate saturation and inhibit growth."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Fungi like Polyporus squamosus thrive in low-light conditions usually in shaded or semi-shaded environments. Removing older mushrooms can help reduce the chance of mold or bacteria that might affect younger growth."}],"care_level":"Medium","common_name":"Dryad's Saddle","description":"Polyporus squamosus aka Cerioporus squamosus (yet to be confirmed new taxonomy) is a basidiomycete bracket fungus, with common names including dryad's saddle and pheasant's back mushroom. It has a widespread distribution, being found in North America, Australia, Asia, and Europe, where it causes a white rot in the heartwood of living and dead hardwood trees. The name \"dryad's saddle\" refers to creatures in Greek mythology called dryads who could conceivably fit and ride on this mushroom,...","family":null,"flower_color":null,"flowering_season":false,"fruit_color":null,"growth_rate":"Moderate","harvest_season":"Spring","leaf_color":null,"maintenance":"Low","origin":["Northern Hemisphere"],"other_name":["Dryad's Saddle"],"pest_susceptibility":[],"propagation":[],"pruning_month":["April"],"scientific_name":["Polyporus squamosus"],"soil":["Well-drained","Loamy","Wood-based substrate"],"watering_period":"Morning"}}

Consistent light pruning each year is generally the best approach."}],"care_level":"Medium","common_name":"Wild Rosemary","description":"Andromeda polifolia, common name bog-rosemary, is a species of flowering plant native to northern parts of the Northern Hemisphere. Avoid cutting into the woody stems, as this can damage the plant and reduce its vigor."}],"care_level":"Easy","common_name":"Florida pennyroyal","description":"Piloblephis is a genus of flowering plant in the Lamiaceae family, first described as a genus in 1838. In general, it is best to allow the soil to dry out completely between waterings. Overwatering can lead to root rot, which is a common problem in succulents like this one. {"type":"json_schema","json_schema":{"id":14717,"attracts":["Bees","Butterflies"],"care_guides_details":[{"type":"watering","description":"Salix caroliniana, also known as the Carolina willow, thrives in wet environments, which means it requires regular watering to maintain its moisture levels. Ideally, the soil around this plant should remain consistently moist without becoming waterlogged. During hot summer months, increase the frequency of watering, ensuring the root zone is sufficiently moist. For newly planted willows, water deeply once a week to encourage deep root growth. During rainy seasons, natural precipitation may suffice, so adjust according to weather conditions. Mulching can also help retain moisture and minimize the need for frequent watering."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Salix caroliniana prefers full sun to partial shade conditions, which is vital for optimal growth and health. Ideally, this willow should receive at least six hours of direct sunlight each day. While it can tolerate some shade, too much shade may lead to weaker growth and a sparser foliage canopy. In sunny locations, ensure it has access to adequate water, as sunlight can increase the rate of evaporation and potentially dry out the soil. If planting in a partially shaded area, make sure it still receives ample morning or afternoon sun to thrive."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning Salix caroliniana can help maintain its shape and encourage healthier growth. Prune this willow tree in late winter or early spring before new growth begins. Remove any dead, diseased, or broken branches to improve air circulation and overall plant health. It's also beneficial to thin out dense areas to allow sunlight to reach the inner branches. Be sure not to cut too far into the main trunk and maintain its natural shape by following the tree's growth pattern as much as possible. {"type":"json_schema","json_schema":{"id":14816,"attracts":[],"care_guides_details":[{"type":"watering","description":"Senecio ampullaceus is a drought-tolerant plant that thrives with minimal watering. It prefers the soil to dry out completely between waterings, especially during its growing season. Watering once every two weeks should suffice during warmer months. In the winter, when the plant is dormant, reduce watering frequency further to once a month or on an as-needed basis. Overwatering is a common issue, and it's important to ensure the soil has good drainage to prevent root rot. Always water at the base and not on the leaves to minimize fungal infections."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Senecio ampullaceus prefers bright, indirect sunlight. Ideally, it flourishes when placed in a location that receives several hours of filtered sunlight per day. Direct sunlight, particularly during the intense afternoon hours, may scorch the leaves, so it's essential to provide some protection, like a sheer curtain. If the plant is grown indoors, placing it near an east or west-facing window should provide adequate light. During winter months, when daylight is limited, consider supplementing with grow lights to support its photosynthesis process."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning Senecio ampullaceus is typically done to maintain shape and remove any dead or damaged parts. It’s best to prune this plant in early spring before new growth begins. Start by removing any dead or withered stems, cutting them back to the base. If the plant has become leggy or overgrown, you can trim the tips of the stems to encourage more compact growth. Always use clean, sharp pruning shears to make clean cuts and minimize stress on the plant. Regular pruning will not only shape the plant but also help in redirecting energy to healthier growth."}],"care_level":"Medium","common_name":"Texas ragwort","description":"Senecio ampullaceus also known as Texas ragwort, Texas squaw-weed, Texas groundsel, and Texas butterweed is a species of Senecio in the family Asteraceae and gets its Latin name ampullaceus from its flask shaped flower-head and is a recommended native for landscape use in Texas where it came from.","family":null,"flower_color":"Yellow","flowering_season":false,"fruit_color":null,"growth_rate":"Moderate","harvest_season":null,"leaf_color":["Green"],"maintenance":"Moderate","origin":["North America"],"other_name":["Texas ragwort"],"pest_susceptibility":["Fungal leaf spot"],"propagation":["Seed Propagation"],"pruning_month":["July"],"scientific_name":["Senecio ampullaceus"],"soil":["Well-drained","Loamy","Sandy"],"watering_period":"Morning"}}

Water the plant deeply when the top inch of soil feels dry to the touch. During hot, dry periods, you may need to increase the frequency of watering to ensure the soil remains adequately moist. However, be cautious not to overwater, as standing water can lead to root rot. During the winter months or in dormancy, reduce the watering frequency, allowing the top 2-3 inches of soil to dry out between waterings."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Hypericum punctatum thrives best in full sun to partial shade. Aim to provide at least 6 hours of direct sunlight per day, as this will encourage the best flowering and growth. In areas with intense afternoon sun, some light afternoon shade can protect the plant from excessive heat and potential leaf scorch. While it can tolerate some shade, too much shade may result in reduced flowering and a leggier, less compact growth habit. Ensure the plant receives adequate light to flourish and produce vibrant blooms."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning Hypericum punctatum can help maintain its shape and promote healthy growth. Prune in early spring before new growth starts or in late fall after flowering has finished. Trim back spent flowers and remove any dead, damaged, or diseased branches to encourage bushier growth. Light pruning can also be done throughout the growing season to maintain shape and remove any unwanted growth. Avoid cutting back to the base during the growing season, as this can stress the plant and reduce flowering potential."}],"care_level":"Medium","common_name":"spotted St. John's wort","description":"Hypericum punctatum, the spotted St. John's wort, is a perennial herb native to North America. The yellow-flowered herb occurs throughout eastern North America into southern Canada. The process of microsporogenesis carried out by this plant is prone to errors in chromosomal segregation. It has a diploid number of 14 or 16. Insects are attracted to the plant's pollen and the hypericin in the plant's leaves is toxic to mammals.","family":null,"flower_color":"Yellow","flowering_season":false,"fruit_color":"[\"Red\"]","growth_rate":"Moderate","harvest_season":null,"leaf_color":["Green"],"maintenance":"Moderate","origin":["North America"],"other_name":["spotted St. John's wort"],"pest_susceptibility":[],"propagation":["Seed Propagation","Cutting"],"pruning_month":["August"],"scientific_name":["Hypericum punctatum"],"soil":["Well-drained","Loamy","Sandy"],"watering_period":"Morning"}}

This fungus benefits from environments with consistent natural humidity, but artificial watering is not applicable for outdoor or native funguses like this, which primarily invade trees directly."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"As Porodaedalea pini is a fungal pathogen, it doesn’t rely on sunlight in the way that plants do. Instead, it inhabits the shaded and protected areas beneath tree bark where direct sunlight is limited. Therefore, sunlight management isn't directly applicable to this fungus."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning doesn’t apply to Porodaedalea pini since it’s not a plant but a fungus causing decay in trees like pines and firs. To manage its impact, foresters may remove infected tree parts or entire trees to prevent spread. Observing and removing visually infected areas can limit further mycelial advancement. For landscape management, it’s important to enhance the health of surrounding trees, reducing stress factors that could exacerbate fungal invasions, rather than direct pruning."}],"care_level":"Medium","common_name":"Pine Bracket","description":null,"family":null,"flower_color":null,"flowering_season":false,"fruit_color":null,"growth_rate":"Low","harvest_season":null,"leaf_color":null,"maintenance":"Low","origin":["North America","Europe","Asia"],"other_name":["Pine Bracket"],"pest_susceptibility":["Heart rot"],"propagation":[],"pruning_month":["March"],"scientific_name":["Porodaedalea pini"],"soil":["Well-drained","Acidic"],"watering_period":"Morning"}}

Avoid heavy pruning as this species does not require it for healthy growth. In lower light conditions, ensure some exposure to indirect light to facilitate its growth."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning Alectoria sarmentosa is generally unnecessary as it grows in natural, draping formations typical of lichens. However, if you wish to maintain a certain shape or size, use clean, sharp scissors to trim away sections as desired. Remove any visibly dead or damaged portions to promote healthy growth. {"type":"json_schema","json_schema":{"id":15414,"attracts":["Butterflies","Bees"],"care_guides_details":[{"type":"watering","description":"Eutrochium fistulosum, commonly known as hollow Joe-Pye weed, prefers consistently moist soil and can tolerate wet conditions. It's important to water it regularly, especially during dry spells, to ensure the soil remains damp. However, avoid waterlogging, which can lead to root rot. Mulching around the base can help retain soil moisture. During its growing season, check the soil moisture frequently and water if the top inch feels dry. In areas with sufficient rainfall, additional watering might not be necessary once the plant is established, except in prolonged dry periods."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Eutrochium fistulosum thrives in full sun to partial shade conditions. Ideally, it should receive at least 4 to 6 hours of direct sunlight daily to support robust flowering and healthy growth. In regions with extremely hot climates, providing afternoon shade can prevent stress from intense sunlight. While this plant can tolerate some shade, too much shade can reduce its flowering potential and result in a leggier growth habit. Choosing a planting location with ample morning sunlight and some afternoon shade will often yield the best results for this species."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning Eutrochium fistulosum typically involves cutting back the stems to maintain shape and encourage bushier growth. In early spring, remove any dead or damaged stems to make way for new growth. You can trim back the plant by about one-third in late spring if you want to control its height, as it can grow quite tall. After flowering, deadhead spent blooms to extend the flowering period and prevent unwanted self-seeding. In autumn, after the plant has died back completely, cut the stems to the ground to tidy up the garden and prepare for the next growing season."}],"care_level":"Medium","common_name":"Hollow Joe-Pye Weed","description":"Eutrochium fistulosum (Eupatorium fistulosum), also called Hollow Joe-Pye weed, trumpetweed, or purple thoroughwort, is a North American flowering plant in the sunflower family. It is native to southern Canada and throughout the eastern and south central United States from Maine west to Ontario, Wisconsin, and Missouri and south as far as Florida and Texas. The species name fistulosum refers to the tubular stem; see fistula.","family":null,"flower_color":"Pink","flowering_season":false,"fruit_color":null,"growth_rate":"Moderate","harvest_season":null,"leaf_color":["Green"],"maintenance":"Moderate","origin":["Eastern United States"],"other_name":["Hollow Joe-Pye Weed"],"pest_susceptibility":["Fungal leaf spot"],"propagation":["Seed Propagation","Cutting"],"pruning_month":["October"],"scientific_name":["Eutrochium fistulosum"],"soil":["Moist","Well-drained"],"watering_period":"Morning"}}

Light trimming can help maintain the shape and size of the tree, but do not remove more than a third of the foliage in one go. {"type":"json_schema","json_schema":{"id":15912,"attracts":["Bees","Butterflies"],"care_guides_details":[{"type":"watering","description":"Physalis virginiana, commonly known as the Virginia Groundcherry, prefers moderate watering. It is important to keep the soil consistently moist but not waterlogged. Water the plant deeply once or twice a week, allowing the top inch of soil to dry out between waterings. During particularly hot or dry spells, more frequent watering may be necessary. To prevent fungal diseases, it is preferable to water at the base of the plant rather than overhead. Good drainage is crucial, so ensure the plant is in soil that drains well and avoid areas where water tends to pool."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Physalis virginiana thrives best in full sun to partial shade. It requires at least 6 to 8 hours of direct sunlight per day to grow and produce fruit effectively. While it can tolerate some shade, too much can lead to leggy growth and fewer flowers and fruits. If planted in a shaded area, consider increasing the light exposure by trimming overhanging branches or relocating the plant. Proper sunlight ensures robust growth and optimal fruiting. If growing indoors or in a greenhouse, position the plant near a south or west-facing window where it can receive ample sunlight."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning Physalis virginiana is generally not a complex process. It benefits from light pruning in early spring to remove any dead or damaged stems from winter’s effect. This encourages new growth and maintains overall plant health. As the plant grows, regular removal of yellowing or diseased leaves will help prevent the spread of disease. Regular, deep watering once or twice a week is ideal, especially during dry spells, to encourage deep root growth. In autumn and winter, reduce watering as the plant goes dormant, requiring much less moisture. To determine when to water, check the top couple of inches of soil; if it feels dry, it’s time to water."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Vitis riparia thrives best in full sunlight, requiring at least 6 to 8 hours of direct sun each day. Adequate sunlight ensures healthy growth and optimizes fruit production. If grown in a shadier spot, the plant may experience stunted growth and reduced fruit yield. Therefore, positioning it in a sunny location like a south-facing trellis or wall will maximize its potential. While it can tolerate partial shade, especially where intense sunlight might scorch young leaves, fruiting will likely be less abundant than in full sun conditions."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning Vitis riparia is crucial for health and productivity. It should be done during the dormant season, usually in late winter. Remove any dead, damaged, or crossing branches to encourage an open structure. Focus on reducing overcrowding to allow sunlight and air to penetrate. Cut back one-year-old canes, as they bear fruit, to a few buds per cane. This process encourages new growth and fruiting in the coming season. Keep enough mature wood to sustain the plant's structure while promoting vigorous new growth for optimum fruit production."}],"care_level":"Medium","common_name":"riverbank grape","description":"Vitis riparia Michx, with common names riverbank grape or frost grape, is a native American climbing or trailing vine, widely distributed across central and eastern Canada and the central and northeastern parts of the United States, from Quebec to Texas, and eastern Montana to Nova Scotia. It is long-lived and capable of reaching into the upper canopy of the tallest trees....","family":null,"flower_color":"Green","flowering_season":false,"fruit_color":"[\"Purple\"]","growth_rate":"High","harvest_season":"Autumn","leaf_color":["Green"],"maintenance":"Moderate","origin":["North America"],"other_name":["riverbank grape"],"pest_susceptibility":["Downy Mildew","Powdery Mildew","Grape Leafhopper","Grape Phylloxera"],"propagation":["Cutting","Seed Propagation"],"pruning_month":["March"],"scientific_name":["Vitis riparia"],"soil":["Well-drained","Loamy"],"watering_period":"Morning"}}

It's important to maintain a balance; overwatering can cause bulb rot, while underwatering may lead to stunted growth and poor flowering."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Allium cernuum thrives best in full sun to partial shade. In regions with intense summer heat, providing some afternoon shade can prevent leaf scorching. If grown in too much shade, the plant may become leggy and produce fewer flowers. After the flowers have bloomed and start to fade, you can cut the flower stalks down to encourage the plant to focus energy on foliage and bulb growth. In late fall or early spring, remove any dead or damaged leaves to tidy the plant. This also helps prevent any potential diseases or pests from harboring. Avoid cutting green or healthy foliage as the leaves are still photosynthesizing and storing energy for the plant's bulb for the next growing season."}],"care_level":"Easy","common_name":"nodding onion","description":"Allium cernuum, known as nodding onion or lady's leek, is a perennial plant in the genus Allium. During the growing season, typically in spring and early summer, increase watering frequency slightly to support its active growth. However, during its dormancy period, usually in late summer to winter, reduce watering significantly or stop altogether to prevent excessive moisture. Always ensure the plant is in well-draining soil to avoid waterlogging."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Caladenia lyallii thrives in conditions that provide dappled sunlight. In its natural habitat, it often grows in open woodlands or grassy areas where it receives filtered sunlight through trees. When grown in cultivation, aim to replicate this environment by providing bright, indirect sunlight for most of the day. Avoid direct harsh sunlight, especially during peak hours, as this can scorch its delicate leaves and flowers. During dormancy, the plant can tolerate reduced light conditions. Ensuring the right balance of light will promote healthy growth and vibrant blooms."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning Caladenia lyallii is generally minimal. After flowering, it’s beneficial to remove any spent flowers or leaves to tidy up the plant and improve its appearance. This helps redirect the plant’s energy towards developing healthy tubers for the next growth cycle. If leaves appear damaged or diseased, remove them promptly to prevent any potential spread of disease. Avoid cutting into the green, active parts of the plant, as it might hinder its overall health and vigor. Pruning should be done with clean, sharp tools to avoid causing harm to the plant."}],"care_level":"Medium","common_name":"Mountain Caps Orchid","description":"Caladenia alpina, commonly known as mountain or alpine caladenia, is a plant in the orchid family Orchidaceae and is native to subalpine areas of south-eastern Australia and to New Zealand. It has a single fleshy leaf and a thin wiry flowering spike bearing two white flowers with red bars on the labellum. In New Zealand this orchid is sometimes known as Caladenia lyallii.","family":null,"flower_color":"White","flowering_season":false,"fruit_color":null,"growth_rate":"Low","harvest_season":null,"leaf_color":["Green"],"maintenance":"Moderate","origin":["Australia"],"other_name":["Mountain Caps Orchid"],"pest_susceptibility":["Fungal leaf spot"],"propagation":["Seed Propagation"],"pruning_month":["August"],"scientific_name":["Caladenia lyallii"],"soil":["Well-drained"],"watering_period":"Morning"}}
