{"type":"json_schema","json_schema":{"id":15616,"attracts":["Bees","Butterflies"],"care_guides_details":[{"type":"watering","description":"Lespedeza hirta, commonly known as bush clover, thrives in dry to medium moisture soils. It is adapted to withstand drought conditions and prefers infrequent but deep watering to stimulate deep root growth. During its first growing season, ensure consistent moisture until the roots are established. Once established, it requires minimal watering, only during extended periods of dry weather. Over-watering should be avoided, as it can lead to root rot and other moisture-related issues. In well-drained soil, the plant will manage periods of dry conditions effectively, making it a relatively low-maintenance plant in terms of water needs."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"This plant flourishes in full sun, requiring at least six to eight hours of direct sunlight daily for optimal growth. Placing Lespedeza hirta in a position where it receives abundant sunlight encourages vigorous blooming and a robust plant structure. While it can tolerate some light shade, full sunlight ensures the best flowering results and overall plant health. In excessively shaded areas, the plant may become leggy and produce fewer blooms. Ensuring adequate sunlight also helps in reducing the risk of mold and fungal diseases by promoting good air circulation and faster drying of foliage."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning Lespedeza hirta should be done in late winter or early spring before new growth begins. Cut back the stems close to the ground to promote a compact and healthy appearance. This perennial can become leggy if not pruned regularly, reducing its visual appeal and bushiness. By pruning, you encourage vigorous growth and flowering in the new season. Throughout the growing season, remove any dead or damaged stems to maintain the plant's health and aesthetics. Regular pruning also helps control the spread and maintains the plant's size within desired limits."}],"care_level":"Medium","common_name":"hairy lespedeza","description":"Lespedeza hirta, the hairy lespedeza or hairy bush clover, is a perennial forb native to Ontario and the eastern United States that grows at most three feet high. It has inconspicuous small white blooms in the summer and prefers average to dry soil. It is noteworthy for the number of Lepidoptera species it supports. It is a larval host to the bella moth, black-spotted prominent moth, cloudless sulpher, confused cloudy-wing, eastern tailed blue, gray hairstreak, southern","family":null,"flower_color":"Purple","flowering_season":false,"fruit_color":null,"growth_rate":"Moderate","harvest_season":null,"leaf_color":["Green"],"maintenance":"Low","origin":["North America"],"other_name":["hairy lespedeza"],"pest_susceptibility":["Leaf spots"],"propagation":["Seed Propagation"],"pruning_month":["November"],"scientific_name":["Lespedeza hirta"],"soil":["Well-drained","Sandy","Loamy"],"watering_period":"Morning"}}

{"type":"json_schema","json_schema":{"id":15019,"attracts":["Bees","Butterflies"],"care_guides_details":[{"type":"watering","description":"Solidago rugosa, commonly known as Rough Goldenrod, prefers moist to well-drained soil conditions. It is relatively drought-tolerant once established, but regular watering is necessary, especially during dry periods in its growing season. Ensure the soil does not completely dry out for extended periods, particularly in hot weather. When planting in a garden, it's beneficial to mulch around the base to retain soil moisture. Maintain a consistent watering schedule but avoid overwatering, which can lead to root rot. Aim to keep the soil consistently damp but not waterlogged for optimal growth and bloom production."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Solidago rugosa thrives best in full sun, requiring at least 6 to 8 hours of direct sunlight each day. While it can tolerate partial shade, abundant sunlight is crucial for maximum flowering and healthy growth. In areas with intense heat, it may benefit from some afternoon shade to prevent scorching. If planting in a garden with less sunlight, be prepared for reduced flowering and possibly a less vigorous plant. When considering a planting location, ensure that it gets ample sunlight throughout the day for optimal blooming and plant vitality."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning Solidago rugosa helps maintain its shape and encourage bushier growth. It is best to prune after the flowering season, typically in late fall or early spring. Start by removing dead or damaged stems and cutting back the spent flower spikes to the base of the plant to prevent self-seeding. To control its height and encourage a denser form, you can cut back about one-third of the plant's height before the growing season begins. Regular pruning also helps to minimize its spread if grown in a garden, as it can become quite invasive under ideal conditions."}],"care_level":"Easy","common_name":"common wrinkle-leaved goldenrod","description":"Solidago rugosa, commonly called the wrinkleleaf goldenrod or rough-stemmed goldenrod, is a species of flowering plant in the sunflower family (Asteraceae). {"type":"json_schema","json_schema":{"id":14421,"attracts":["Birds"],"care_guides_details":[{"type":"watering","description":"Ilex vomitoria, commonly known as yaupon holly, is quite drought-tolerant once established but prefers consistently moist soil conditions. Water the plant regularly during its first year to help it establish a deep root system. Ensure the soil is well-draining to prevent waterlogged conditions, which can cause root rot. In subsequent growing seasons, water mature plants only during prolonged dry spells, letting the top inch of soil dry out between waterings. Mulching around the base can help retain soil moisture and protect roots during dry periods."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Ilex vomitoria thrives in a variety of light conditions, from full sun to partial shade. For optimal growth and berry production, plant it in an area that gets at least 4-6 hours of direct sunlight per day. In hotter climates, providing some afternoon shade can protect the leaves from scorch. The plant can tolerate full shade, but this may impact its growth rate and berry production. Positioning in dappled sunlight or morning sun with afternoon shade is ideal in zones with intense summer sun."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning Ilex vomitoria helps maintain its shape and encourages healthy growth. It's best to prune in late winter or early spring before new growth appears. Remove any dead, diseased, or crossing branches to improve air circulation within the plant. You can also trim back overgrown branches to maintain desired size and shape. Light pruning throughout the growing season is possible to maintain neatness but avoid severe pruning during this period to prevent stress. Always use clean, sharp pruning tools to make clean cuts."}],"care_level":"Easy","common_name":"Yaupon Holly","description":"Ilex vomitoria, commonly known as yaupon /jɒpɒn/ or yaupon holly, is a species of holly that is native to southeastern North America. The word yaupon was derived from its Catawban name, yopún, which is a diminutive form of the word yop, meaning \"tree\". Another common name, cassina, was borrowed from the Timucua language (despite this, it usually refers to Ilex cassine).","family":null,"flower_color":null,"flowering_season":false,"fruit_color":"[\"Red\"]","growth_rate":"Moderate","harvest_season":"Autumn","leaf_color":["Green"],"maintenance":"Low","origin":["Southeastern United States"],"other_name":["Yaupon Holly"],"pest_susceptibility":[],"propagation":["Seed Propagation","Cutting"],"pruning_month":["February"],"scientific_name":["Ilex vomitoria"],"soil":["Well-drained","Acidic"],"watering_period":"Morning"}}

{"type":"json_schema","json_schema":{"id":14721,"attracts":["Bees","Butterflies","Birds"],"care_guides_details":[{"type":"watering","description":"Helianthus mollis, commonly known as ashy sunflower, thrives in regular moisture but is also quite drought-tolerant once established. Water this plant thoroughly during its growing season, allowing the top inch of soil to dry out between waterings to prevent root rot. Ensure it receives at least one inch of water per week, either from rainfall or supplemental watering, especially during prolonged dry spells. Be cautious not to overwater in areas with high humidity, as this can lead to fungal issues. Mulching can help conserve soil moisture and keep the root system cool."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Helianthus mollis requires full sun to thrive, needing at least six hours of direct sunlight each day. Ideally, it should be planted in a location with unobstructed sunlight for the best growth and flowering. While it can tolerate partial shade, this may reduce its overall blooming potential and make the plant less robust. In areas with extremely hot climates, providing some afternoon shade can minimize heat stress and leaf scorching. Ensure the plant is in a well-ventilated, open space to reduce humidity around it and prevent fungal disease development."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning Helianthus mollis should be done in early spring or late fall to remove dead stems and promote healthy new growth. During the growing season, cutting back about one-third of the plant in late spring can encourage a bushier shape and more blooms. Deadheading throughout the blooming period can prolong flowering by preventing the plant from going to seed. If desired, you can prune spent flowers to tidy up the plant's appearance, but be sure to leave some if you want the seeds for wildlife or propagation."}],"care_level":"Easy","common_name":"ashy sunflower","description":"Helianthus mollis is a species of sunflower known by the common names ashy sunflower. It is widespread across much of the United States and Canada, primarily the Great Lakes region from Ontario south to Texas and Alabama. Additional populations are found in the states of the Atlantic Coast from Maine to Georgia, but these appear to be introduced.","family":null,"flower_color":"Yellow","flowering_season":false,"fruit_color":"[\"Brown\"]","growth_rate":"Moderate","harvest_season":null,"leaf_color":["Green"],"maintenance":"Low","origin":["North America"],"other_name":["ashy sunflower"],"pest_susceptibility":[],"propagation":["Seed Propagation","Division"],"pruning_month":["September"],"scientific_name":["Helianthus mollis"],"soil":["Well-drained","Loamy","Sandy"],"watering_period":"Morning"}}

{"type":"json_schema","json_schema":{"id":15020,"attracts":["Bees","Butterflies"],"care_guides_details":[{"type":"watering","description":"Dactylorhiza viridis, commonly known as the frog orchid, prefers evenly moist conditions, especially during its growing season in the spring and early summer. Be cautious with watering, as these orchids do not tolerate waterlogged soil. Allow the top inch of soil to dry out between waterings, but ensure that the plant does not dry out completely. During its dormant period in the late summer and fall, reduce watering significantly. In natural settings, it typically thrives in environments with moderate moisture, so replicating these conditions will help the plant flourish."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Dactylorhiza viridis prefers partial shade to dappled sunlight conditions, mimicking the light environments of their natural woodland and meadow habitats. Direct sunlight, especially during the hottest parts of the day, should be avoided as it can lead to leaf burn or stress. Morning sun or filtered light through tree canopies can work well. Providing the orchid with adequate yet not excessive light is crucial for healthy growth and flowering. If growing indoors, placing the plant near an east-facing window can provide the needed light without overexposing it."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning Dactylorhiza viridis generally involves removing dead or yellowing foliage to allow the plant to focus its energy on healthy growth. This should be done by carefully cutting off the dead leaves at the base, making sure not to damage the surrounding healthy parts. After the flowering period, it's also recommended to remove any spent flower stalks to prevent energy wastage in seed production unless propagation through seeds is desired. Ensure tools used are sterilized to prevent disease and pest transmission, maintaining the plant’s health."}],"care_level":"Medium","common_name":"Frog Orchid","description":"Coeloglossum is a genus of orchids. It has long been considered to have only one species, Coeloglossum viride, the frog orchid. Some recent classifications regard Coeloglossum as part of the larger genus, Dactylorhiza, so that C. viride becomes Dactylorhiza viridis. Other sources continue to keep Coeloglossum viride separate.","family":null,"flower_color":"Green","flowering_season":false,"fruit_color":null,"growth_rate":"Low","harvest_season":null,"leaf_color":["Green"],"maintenance":"Moderate","origin":["Europe","Asia","North America"],"other_name":["Frog Orchid"],"pest_susceptibility":[],"propagation":["Seed Propagation"],"pruning_month":["March"],"scientific_name":["Dactylorhiza viridis"],"soil":["Well-drained","Loamy","Acidic"],"watering_period":"Morning"}}

Although it is adaptable, insufficient sunlight can lead to leggy growth and reduced flowering. If grown indoors, supplement with a grow light during darker months to provide adequate light exposure for optimal development and flowering."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning Eryngium carlinae involves removing dead or damaged leaves and stems to encourage healthy growth and improve its appearance. This is best done in early spring before new growth begins. Use clean, sharp scissors or secateurs to cut back to the base of the plant or to a healthy lateral bud. Removing spent flowers can help to extend the blooming period by triggering new blooms. Be sure to wear gloves and long sleeves during pruning as the plant can be spiny and may cause mild skin irritation. {"type":"json_schema","json_schema":{"id":15317,"attracts":["Bees","Butterflies"],"care_guides_details":[{"type":"watering","description":"Solidago odora, commonly known as sweet goldenrod, prefers moderate watering. It's fairly drought-tolerant once established, so allow the soil to dry out slightly between waterings. In its natural habitat, the plant can survive on rainfall alone, but during prolonged dry spells or in very hot weather, occasional deep watering can help the plant thrive. Be careful not to overwater, as this can lead to root rot and other moisture-related problems. Always ensure the container or ground has proper drainage to prevent standing water."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Solidago odora prefers full sun to partial shade for optimal growth. Ideally, it should receive at least 6 to 8 hours of sunlight a day to produce the best display of blooms. While it can tolerate light shade, the flowering may be reduced and the plant can become leggy. In very hot climates, a little afternoon shade can protect the plant from intense heat. Ensure that, if planted in a shaded area, it still gets enough light for photosynthesis, or growth may be stunted."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning Solidago odora is mainly done to maintain shape and promote bushiness. Cut back up to half of the plant in late spring or early summer to encourage denser growth and more blooms. Light pruning can be done throughout the year to remove unwanted or crossing branches."}],"care_level":"Easy","common_name":"sea grape","description":"Coccoloba uvifera is a species of flowering plant in the buckwheat family, Polygonaceae, that is native to coastal beaches throughout tropical America and the Caribbean, including southern Florida, the Bahamas, the Greater and Lesser Antilles, and Bermuda. Planting in an area where it receives morning sun is beneficial, as it helps to dry off the morning dew and reduces the risk of fungal diseases. Ensure a location that prioritizes good sunlight exposure."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Prune Rosa virginiana in early spring before new growth begins. Start by removing any dead, damaged, or crossing branches to maintain good air circulation and healthy growth. Next, cut back about one-third of the previous year’s growth to encourage bushier growth and more blooms. Make cuts at a 45-degree angle about a quarter-inch above outward-facing buds to foster proper growth direction. Throughout the growing season, remove spent flowers and any suckers. Regular pruning promotes robust health, enhances flowering, and controls the size of the shrub."}],"care_level":"Medium","common_name":"Virginian Rose","description":"Rosa virginiana, commonly known as the Virginia rose, common wild rose or prairie rose, is a woody perennial in the rose family native to eastern North America, where it is the most common wild rose. The leaves are pinnate, usually with between 7 and 9 glossy leaflets. {"type":"json_schema","json_schema":{"id":15021,"attracts":["Bees","Butterflies"],"care_guides_details":[{"type":"watering","description":"Eustoma grandiflorum, commonly known as lisianthus, requires moderate watering. It's important to keep the soil consistently moist but not waterlogged. During the growing season, water the plant when the top inch of soil feels dry to the touch. Avoid letting the plant sit in water, as this can lead to root rot. During the winter months, reduce watering frequency to allow the plant to rest, while still ensuring the soil does not completely dry out. It's beneficial to use room temperature water to avoid stressing the plant."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Eustoma grandiflorum thrives in bright, indirect sunlight. Although it can tolerate some direct sun, too much intense midday sun can lead to leaf scorch. The ideal spot would be a location that receives morning sun and afternoon shade, such as an east or west-facing window if grown indoors. Outdoors, choose a space that provides some shelter from the harshest rays. Ensuring the plant receives adequate light is crucial for its flowering and overall health, so monitor its position and adjust if leaves show signs of exposure stress."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning Eustoma grandiflorum involves removing spent blooms and deadheading to encourage prolonged flowering and maintain a tidy appearance. Cut back the flower stems to the base once the bloom has faded. This not only stimulates further flowering but also helps to redirect the plant's energy into producing new growth. Additionally, trim away any yellowing or dead leaves to keep the plant healthy. Regular pruning during the growing season will enhance the plant’s appearance and overall vigor."}],"care_level":"Medium","common_name":"Texas Bluebell","description":"Eustoma exaltatum ssp. russellianum, is a species of flowering plant in the Gentian family. Its previous binomial name was Eustoma grandiflorum. Common names include Texas bluebells, Texas bluebell, bluebell, showy prairie gentian, prairie gentian The Bolero Deep Blue, and Lisianthus.","family":null,"flower_color":"Purple","flowering_season":false,"fruit_color":null,"growth_rate":"Moderate","harvest_season":null,"leaf_color":["Green"],"maintenance":"Moderate","origin":["Southern United States","Mexico","Caribbean"],"other_name":["Texas Bluebell"],"pest_susceptibility":["Aphids","Leaf miners","Fungal infections"],"propagation":["Seed Propagation"],"pruning_month":["August"],"scientific_name":["Eustoma grandiflorum"],"soil":["Well-drained","Loamy"],"watering_period":"Morning"}}

{"type":"json_schema","json_schema":{"id":14820,"attracts":["Butterflies","Hummingbirds"],"care_guides_details":[{"type":"watering","description":"Ruellia simplex, commonly known as Mexican petunia, prefers consistently moist soil, but it is relatively drought-tolerant once established. To keep the plant healthy and vibrant, water it regularly, especially during dry spells. Watering deeply once or twice a week should suffice, ensuring that the soil doesn’t dry out completely. Avoid over-watering as this can lead to root rot. In containers, water until it drains through the bottom, but do not let the plant sit in water. Adjust the frequency of watering based on the climate and season, reducing it during the plant's dormant winter period."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Ruellia simplex thrives in full sunlight, needing at least six to eight hours of direct sunlight each day for optimal blooming. It can tolerate partial shade but may become leggy and produce fewer flowers in such conditions. The plant is quite adaptable and can handle the hot afternoon sun, making it suitable for sunny garden spots or as a highlight in borders. Ensure the plant receives adequate sunlight to maintain its vibrant blooms and prevent it from becoming too sparse or lanky. If grown indoors or in a pot, place it near a bright window facing south or west."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning Ruellia simplex is essential for maintaining its shape and encouraging bushier growth. Trim back the stems in late winter or early spring before the new growth begins. You can cut the stems back by about a third to promote branching. Throughout the growing season, remove spent flowers and any dead or damaged stems to encourage continuous blooming and prevent disease. If the plant becomes leggy or overgrown, light pruning during active growth can help maintain its form. Regular pruning will also help control its spread, as this plant can be invasive in some regions."}],"care_level":"Easy","common_name":"Mexican ruellia","description":"Ruellia simplex (Britton's wild petunia, Mexican petunia, Mexican bluebell) is a species of flowering plant in the acanthus family, Acanthaceae. It is a native of Mexico, the Caribbean, and South America. It has become a widespread invasive plant in Florida, where it was likely introduced as an ornamental before 1933.","family":null,"flower_color":"Purple","flowering_season":false,"fruit_color":null,"growth_rate":"High","harvest_season":null,"leaf_color":["Green"],"maintenance":"Low","origin":["Mexico","Caribbean","Central America"],"other_name":["Mexican ruellia"],"pest_susceptibility":[],"propagation":["Cutting","Seed Propagation"],"pruning_month":["April"],"scientific_name":["Ruellia simplex"],"soil":["Well-drained","Loamy"],"watering_period":"Morning"}}

It is recommended to water this plant sparingly, allowing the soil to dry out between waterings. Overwatering can lead to root rot, as the roots prefer not to sit in waterlogged soil. During dry spells or extremely hot weather, it may need more frequent watering to keep it healthy, particularly if it shows signs of wilting. Observing the top inch of soil is a good way to determine when it needs water."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Aureolaria pectinata prefers full sun to partial shade. For optimal growth and blooming, it should receive at least 4 to 6 hours of direct sunlight each day. If plantings are in regions with particularly intense sun, a spot with some afternoon shade can prevent the leaves from scorching. While it can grow in partial shade, too much shade might limit flowering and lead to leggy growth. Ensuring enough sunlight can help this plant maintain its vibrant blooming and overall health, matching its natural preference for mostly sunny habitats in the wild. "},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning of Aureolaria pectinata should be minimal, as it naturally maintains a fairly neat growth habit. It is mostly done to remove any dead or diseased stems that may appear, which helps in preventing the spread of any potential disease and encourages healthy growth. If the plant becomes leggy or misshapen, light trimming can be done to maintain its form, typically after flowering. Avoid heavy pruning since it can stress the plant. Additionally, deadheading or removing old blooms can promote the growth of new flowers and extend the blooming period."}],"care_level":"Medium","common_name":"fernleaf yellow false foxglove","description":"Aureolaria pectinata, commonly called combleaf yellow false foxglove, is a species of plant in the broomrape family that is native to the southeastern United States.","family":null,"flower_color":"Yellow","flowering_season":false,"fruit_color":"[\"Brown\"]","growth_rate":"Moderate","harvest_season":null,"leaf_color":["Green"],"maintenance":"Low","origin":["United States"],"other_name":["fernleaf yellow false foxglove"],"pest_susceptibility":[],"propagation":["Seed Propagation"],"pruning_month":["November"],"scientific_name":["Aureolaria pectinata"],"soil":["Well-drained","Dry"],"watering_period":"Morning"}}

{"type":"json_schema","json_schema":{"id":14522,"attracts":[],"care_guides_details":[{"type":"watering","description":"Tradescantia occidentalis, commonly known as Prairie Spiderwort, thrives with regular watering during its active growing season, which is spring through summer. It prefers evenly moist but not waterlogged soil, so it's vital to allow the topsoil to dry out slightly between waterings. Overwatering can lead to root rot or fungal diseases. As the plant is somewhat drought-tolerant, it can handle occasional dry periods once established. In winter, reduce watering significantly as growth slows down, allowing the soil to dry completely before re-watering."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Tradescantia occidentalis does best in full sun to partial shade. It ideally requires at least 4-6 hours of direct sunlight daily to promote healthy growth and vibrant blooms. While it can tolerate a variety of lighting conditions, too much shade can lead to spindly growth and less flowering. In hotter climates, some afternoon shade can prevent foliage scorch and keep the plant looking its best. If grown indoors, place it near a bright window where it can receive ample indirect sunlight, avoiding direct exposure to intense midday sun."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning Tradescantia occidentalis helps maintain its shape and encourages bushier growth. It's best to prune in early spring before new growth begins. Remove any dead or damaged leaves and stems throughout the growing season to keep the plant healthy. Pinching back the tips of the stems encourages denser foliage, contributing to a fuller appearance. After the flowering period, cutting back the stems is recommended to tidy up the plant and induce a second bloom cycle. Always use clean, sharp pruning tools to prevent the spread of diseases."}],"care_level":"Easy","common_name":"Western Spiderwort","description":"Tradescantia occidentalis, the prairie spiderwort or western spiderwort, is a plant in the dayflower family, Commelinaceae. It is common and widespread across the western Great Plains of the United States, as well as in Arizona, New Mexico, southern Utah, and Sonora, but is listed as a threatened species in Canada.","family":null,"flower_color":"Purple","flowering_season":false,"fruit_color":null,"growth_rate":"Moderate","harvest_season":null,"leaf_color":["Green"],"maintenance":"Low","origin":["North America"],"other_name":["Western Spiderwort"],"pest_susceptibility":[],"propagation":["Cutting","Seed Propagation"],"pruning_month":["March"],"scientific_name":["Tradescantia occidentalis"],"soil":["Well-drained","Sandy"],"watering_period":"Morning"}}

{"type":"json_schema","json_schema":{"id":16005,"attracts":[],"care_guides_details":[{"type":"watering","description":"Ageratina riparia prefer consistently moist, well-draining soil and should be watered regularly to maintain slight dampness. The top inch of soil should be allowed to dry out between waterings, especially in cooler months when the plant’s growth slows down. During hotter periods, increase the frequency of watering to cope with the plant’s higher moisture demands. Always ensure the plant has adequate drainage, whether grown in pots or directly in the ground, to prevent standing water around the roots."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Ageratina riparia thrives in full sun to partial shade. It's best to provide it with at least 4-6 hours of sunlight each day for optimal growth and flowering. In hotter climates, it can benefit from some afternoon shade to prevent leaf burn. Conversely, in cooler regions, full sun can help encourage more vigorous and healthy growth. If grown indoors or in a shadier location, ensure it's exposed to enough light to prevent leggy growth and to stimulate blooming. Adjust lighting conditions based on the plant’s response, adapting to seasonal changes as necessary."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning Ageratina riparia involves regularly trimming back any dead or damaged stems to maintain the plant's health and encourage new growth. Using rainwater or distilled water is ideal as the plant is sensitive to chemicals in tap water. It is essential to ensure proper drainage to prevent root rot, especially when grown in pots. Direct sunlight, especially during the midday and afternoon, can damage the fronds, leading to browning and scorching. If planted outdoors, choose a location with filtered light or provide artificial shading if necessary. When grown indoors, place the plant near north or east-facing windows where it can receive indirect light. Ensuring the right balance of light will support healthy growth and maintain the plant's verdant foliage."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning Dicksonia antarctica should be minimal and focused on removing dead or damaged fronds to maintain its appearance and health. Carefully trim off any brown or withered fronds at the base using clean and sharp scissors or pruning shears. This can be done at any time of the year as needed. Avoid excessive pruning, as the old fronds provide natural insulation for the trunk in colder weather. Regularly checking and cleaning the plant will help promote healthy new growth and maintain its lush appearance."}],"care_level":"Medium","common_name":"man fern","description":"Dicksonia antarctica (soft tree fern, man fern) is a species of evergreen tree fern native to eastern Australia, ranging from south-east Queensland, coastal New South Wales and Victoria to Tasmania.","family":null,"flower_color":null,"flowering_season":false,"fruit_color":null,"growth_rate":"Moderate","harvest_season":null,"leaf_color":["Green"],"maintenance":"Moderate","origin":["Australia","Tasmania"],"other_name":["man fern"],"pest_susceptibility":[],"propagation":["Spores"],"pruning_month":["March"],"scientific_name":["Dicksonia antarctica"],"soil":["Well-drained","Humus-rich"],"watering_period":"Morning"}}

{"type":"json_schema","json_schema":{"id":15805,"attracts":[],"care_guides_details":[{"type":"watering","description":"Flavoparmelia baltimorensis (rock greenshield lichen) does not require traditional watering as it is not a vascular plant like most garden plants. Instead, it derives moisture from rain, humidity, and the surrounding air. Thus, naturally occurring precipitation typically provides adequate moisture. In dry climates or during extended periods without rain, occasional misting can help maintain optimal moisture levels. However, avoid over-misting, as lichens are sensitive to excess moisture and prolonged dampness, which can lead to deterioration. Consider environmental conditions and be mindful of the natural habitat to mimic moisture needs."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Flavoparmelia baltimorensis thrives in environments where it can receive indirect sunlight. It can typically be found growing on rocks in partly shaded areas. While it does need some sunlight, ensure that it is not exposed to intense, direct sunlight for prolonged periods as this can cause desiccation and damage. Instead, aim for a balance where it can receive dappled light or filtered sunlight, similar to the conditions found in its natural habitat. Maintaining a balance between light and shade will help support its photosynthetic needs without causing stress from overexposure."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning is not typically required for Flavoparmelia baltimorensis, as lichens grow slowly and do not have stems or leaves that require regular trimming. Instead, if necessary, gently remove any debris or dead sections that might accumulate on the lichen’s surface, taking care not to damage the healthy parts. Minimal intervention is best, given the symbiotic relationship between fungi and algae or cyanobacteria in lichens. Focus on maintaining a clean growing environment to support healthy lichen growth rather than frequent pruning, which is not part of their care routine."}],"care_level":"Medium","common_name":"rock greenshield lichen","description":"Flavoparmelia baltimorensis or Rock greenshield lichen (from Lichens of North America) is a medium to large foliose lichen with a yellow green upper surface when dry; lobes rounded without pseudocyphellae; the upper surface with globose, pustule-like growths resembling isidia. Lower surface is black with a narrow brown zone at the margins.","family":null,"flower_color":null,"flowering_season":false,"fruit_color":null,"growth_rate":"Low","harvest_season":null,"leaf_color":["Green-Gray"],"maintenance":"Low","origin":["North America"],"other_name":["rock greenshield lichen"],"pest_susceptibility":[],"propagation":["Fragmentation"],"pruning_month":["March"],"scientific_name":["Flavoparmelia baltimorensis"],"soil":["Well-drained","Gravely","Acidic"],"watering_period":"Morning"}}

Ensure the planting location grants ample sunlight to support the tree's development and longevity."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning for the Juglans major is best done in late winter or early spring before new growth begins. This will help prevent fungal infections and promote healthy growth. Avoid heavy pruning as it may stress the tree; instead, make small and strategic cuts to shape the tree and remove any competing leaders to encourage a strong central trunk. Regular pruning helps develop a sturdy, aesthetically pleasing form."}],"care_level":"Medium","common_name":"Arizona black walnut","description":"Juglans major (literally, the larger walnut), also known as Arizona walnut, is a walnut tree which grows to 50 ft tall (15 m) with a DBH of up to 0.61 metres (2 ft) at elevations of 300–2,130 m (1,000–7,000 ft) in Texas, Oklahoma, New Mexico, Arizona, and Utah. {"type":"json_schema","json_schema":{"id":14513,"attracts":[],"care_guides_details":[{"type":"watering","description":"Gymnosporangium juniperi-virginianae, commonly known as cedar-apple rust, is a type of fungus, and not a plant that requires watering. However, it's part of a life cycle involving both juniper and apple or crabapple trees. To manage this fungus, ensure trees are well-watered to keep them healthy in general. Junipers should be watered at the base to prevent fungal growth. Avoid overhead watering, as moisture on leaves can encourage fungal development. Proper watering aids in maintaining the overall health of the host plants, making them less susceptible to infection."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Gymnosporangium juniperi-virginianae is a fungus affecting junipers and apples, so the light requirement pertains to these plants. Both juniper and apple trees generally thrive in full sun, which also aids in controlling fungal infections. Sunlight can help reduce moisture levels and thus the proliferation of the fungus. Ensuring that these plants receive adequate sunlight (at least 6-8 hours a day) can promote health and vigor, making them more resistant to infections like cedar-apple rust. {"type":"json_schema","json_schema":{"id":14613,"attracts":["Bees"],"care_guides_details":[{"type":"watering","description":"Narcissus papyraceus, commonly known as paperwhite narcissus, requires careful watering to prevent bulb rot. During the growing season, water them thoroughly but allow the soil to dry slightly between waterings. Typically, this means watering once or twice a week. Ensure that your container or garden bed has good drainage, as paperwhites do not tolerate soggy soil. Once the flowering period ends, gradually reduce watering until foliage dies back, at which point you should stop watering altogether as the bulbs enter dormancy."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Narcissus papyraceus thrives in full sunlight, which supports robust growth and flowering. Ideally, provide them with at least six hours of direct sunlight each day. In regions with hot climates, some afternoon shade might be beneficial to prevent excessive heat stress. If growing indoors, place them near a south-facing window to maximize light exposure. However, indirect sunlight can also work, though it might prolong the growth period and lead to taller, more leggy plants. Ensure that lighting conditions encourage steady, healthy growth."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning is not typically required for Narcissus papyraceus, but removing spent blooms can improve appearance and direct the plant's energy back into the bulb for next season's growth. After flowering, allow the foliage to remain until it yellows and dies back naturally, as this process is crucial for photosynthesis and replenishing the bulb's nutrients. Avoid cutting back green leaves prematurely. Clean up any dead or yellowed foliage to maintain a tidy appearance and prevent disease."}],"care_level":"Easy","common_name":"Paperwhite","description":"Narcissus papyraceus (from papyrus and aceus; meaning paper-like), one of a few species known as paperwhite, is a perennial bulbous plant native to the Mediterranean region, from Greece to Portugal plus Morocco and Algeria. The species is considered naturalized in the Azores, Corsica, Texas, California and Louisiana. The white flowers are borne in bunches and are strongly fragrant. It is frequently grown as a house plant, often forced to flower at Christmas.","family":null,"flower_color":"White","flowering_season":false,"fruit_color":"[\"Green\"]","growth_rate":"Moderate","harvest_season":"Winter","leaf_color":["Green"],"maintenance":"Low","origin":["Mediterranean"],"other_name":["Paperwhite"],"pest_susceptibility":[],"propagation":["Bulbs","Division","Seed Propagation"],"pruning_month":["March"],"scientific_name":["Narcissus papyraceus"],"soil":["Well-drained","Loamy"],"watering_period":"Morning"}}

Prune during the growing season by cutting back any dead or damaged stems. You can also trim the plant to control its size and shape. Use sharp, sterilized pruning shears to make clean cuts just above a leaf node. Regular pruning can prevent the plant from becoming leggy and helps promote dense, bushy growth. {"type":"json_schema","json_schema":{"id":14812,"attracts":["Pollinators"],"care_guides_details":[{"type":"watering","description":"Hibiscus syriacus, also known as Rose of Sharon, requires consistent watering, especially during dry periods. Ensure the soil remains moist but not waterlogged. During the growing season (spring to early autumn), water deeply once a week if there's no rain. In especially hot or dry climates, increased frequency may be necessary. Allow the top couple of inches of soil to dry out between waterings to prevent root rot. Mulching can help retain soil moisture and reduce the need for frequent watering. Reduce watering during the fall and winter months when the plant is dormant."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Hibiscus syriacus thrives in full sun, requiring at least 6 to 8 hours of direct sunlight daily for optimal flowering. It tolerates a range of light conditions, but insufficient sunlight may result in fewer blooms and weaker growth. In regions with exceptionally high temperatures, some afternoon shade can prevent leaf scorch. When planting, select a location that allows for adequate sunlight exposure throughout the day. If grown indoors, place near a south or west-facing window, ensuring it receives abundant bright light."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning Hibiscus syriacus is best done in late winter or early spring before new growth begins. Start by removing any dead or damaged wood. To control the shape and size of the plant, you can cut back the branches to a healthy node or bud. Thinning the plant by removing some of the older, woodier stems can improve air circulation and encourage new growth. Avoid pruning more than one-third of the plant at a time to prevent stress. Regular pruning helps maintain a tidy appearance and promotes prolific blooming."}],"care_level":"Medium","common_name":"common hibiscus","description":"Hibiscus syriacus is a species of flowering plant in the family Malvaceae, native to India and much of Asia. It was given the epithet syriacus because it had been collected from gardens in Syria. {"type":"json_schema","json_schema":{"id":15806,"attracts":[],"care_guides_details":[{"type":"watering","description":"Drosera whittakeri, a type of sundew, prefers consistently moist conditions, mimicking its natural boggy habitat. It is important to use distilled or rainwater for watering, as this species is sensitive to the minerals in tap water. The soil should never dry out completely, so maintain a consistently damp environment by watering from the bottom, allowing the plant to absorb water through a tray beneath. Ensure the tray has water at all times for optimal hydration, especially in warmer months. Reducing watering slightly during dormancy in winter is recommended, but never let the soil dry out completely."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Drosera whittakeri thrives in bright, indirect sunlight, which is necessary for its health and robust growth. A windowsill with filtered light or a location where it can receive dappled sunlight for at least 4-6 hours a day is ideal. Direct sunlight can scorch the leaves, while too little light can hinder its growth and reduce its ability to produce dew, critical for its insect-catching capabilities. During the growing season, maintaining consistent light conditions will help ensure healthy development. If natural light is insufficient, consider supplementing with fluorescent grow lights."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning for Drosera whittakeri is minimal but beneficial for maintaining the plant’s health and appearance. Remove dead leaves and spent flower stalks to prevent mold and disease. This can be done by gently snipping them off at the base with sterilized scissors, taking care not to damage surrounding healthy leaves. Pruning helps to direct the plant’s energy into new growth and flower production. Performing maintenance pruning at the end of the growing season, before the winter dormancy period, can also help prepare the plant for a restful and healthy transition into dormancy."}],"care_level":"High","common_name":"Whittaker's sundew","description":"Drosera whittakeri (scented sundew, Whittaker's sundew) is a sundew that is native to South Australia.","family":null,"flower_color":"White","flowering_season":false,"fruit_color":null,"growth_rate":"Low","harvest_season":null,"leaf_color":["Green"],"maintenance":"High","origin":["Australia"],"other_name":["Whittaker's sundew"],"pest_susceptibility":[],"propagation":["Seed Propagation","Tissue Culture"],"pruning_month":["December"],"scientific_name":["Drosera whittakeri"],"soil":["Well-drained","Acidic"],"watering_period":"Morning"}}

Avoid pruning in late fall to prevent exposing the plant to potential winter damage."}],"care_level":"Medium","common_name":"ebony sedge","description":"Carex eburnea (ivory sedge or bristleleaf sedge) is a small and slender sedge native to North America.","family":null,"flower_color":null,"flowering_season":false,"fruit_color":null,"growth_rate":"Low","harvest_season":null,"leaf_color":["Green"],"maintenance":"Low","origin":["North America"],"other_name":["ebony sedge"],"pest_susceptibility":["Fungal leaf spot"],"propagation":["Division","Seed Propagation"],"pruning_month":["March"],"scientific_name":["Carex eburnea"],"soil":["Well-drained","Loamy","Clay","Sandy"],"watering_period":"Morning"}}

{"type":"json_schema","json_schema":{"id":15012,"attracts":["Butterflies"],"care_guides_details":[{"type":"watering","description":"Gomphrena globosa, commonly known as Globe Amaranth, is fairly drought-tolerant once established. It prefers moderate watering and should be watered thoroughly but allowed to dry out between waterings. Overwatering can lead to root rot since it does not like to sit in waterlogged soil. During the hot growing season, water the plant more frequently, ensuring the topsoil is dry before each session. In containers, be mindful of drainage to prevent excess water buildup. Reducing the frequency in cooler months is advised, as water needs diminish."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Globe Amaranth thrives best in full sunlight, requiring at least 6 to 8 hours of direct sunlight daily. This plant is well-suited for bright, warm locations and performs superbly when sited in a sunny spot in the garden or on the patio. While it can tolerate partial shade, especially in hotter climates, reduced sunlight may result in fewer blooms. The plant's vibrant flower colors are enhanced by ample sunlight exposure. Ensure it receives enough light, particularly during its peak growing season, for optimal flowering and growth."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning Gomphrena globosa helps promote bushier growth and encourages more blooms. Regularly deadheading the spent flowers is beneficial and keeps the plant looking tidy. To do this, simply snip the spent blooms just above the nearest set of leaves. The plant responds well to cutting back, so feel free to trim any leggy or overgrown stems. It's ideal to perform a more extensive pruning in early spring, which helps to rejuvenate the plant after winter dormancy. Always ensure your pruning tools are clean to prevent the spread of diseases."}],"care_level":"Easy","common_name":"Globe amaranth","description":"Gomphrena globosa, commonly known as globe amaranth, makhmali and bachelor button , is an annual plant that grows up to 24 inches in height. {"type":"json_schema","json_schema":{"id":15210,"attracts":[],"care_guides_details":[{"type":"watering","description":"Ipomoea imperati, commonly known as the beach morning glory, prefers well-drained soil and tends to be drought-tolerant once established. Water the plant moderately, allowing the soil to dry out slightly between waterings. Overwatering should be avoided as it can lead to root rot. During the growing season, it may require more frequent watering, especially in hotter, drier climates. However, reduce watering in the winter months when the plant's growth slows down. As this plant can tolerate salt spray and coastal conditions, it is well suited for sandy and gritty soil textures."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Ipomoea imperati thrives in full sunlight, requiring at least six to eight hours of direct sun each day to flourish and bloom profusely. Although it can tolerate some partial shade, optimal flowering and growth are achieved with maximum sun exposure. This plant is well-suited to coastal areas due to its tolerance for high salinity and intense sun. If grown indoors or in less sunny regions, ensure it receives as much light as possible by placing it near a south-facing window or using artificial grow lights to supplement natural sunlight, if necessary."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning Ipomoea imperati is mainly necessary to control its spread and maintain a neat appearance, as it can become invasive in some areas. Prune back any overly long or unruly stems to encourage a bushier growth and prevent the plant from overpowering surrounding areas. This is best done in the early spring or late winter, before the start of the growing season. Regularly removing spent flowers and dead or damaged foliage can also promote healthier growth. Pruning helps in maintaining the desired shape and encourages vigorous flowering throughout the blooming season."}],"care_level":"Medium","common_name":"beach morning-glory","description":"Ipomoea imperati, the beach morning-glory (a name it shares with Ipomoea pes-caprae), is a species of flowering plant in the family Convolvulaceae. It has been found on the sandy shores of every continent except Antarctica.","family":null,"flower_color":"White","flowering_season":false,"fruit_color":null,"growth_rate":"Moderate","harvest_season":null,"leaf_color":["Green"],"maintenance":"Moderate","origin":["Southeastern United States","Mexico","Central America","Caribbean"],"other_name":["beach morning-glory"],"pest_susceptibility":[],"propagation":["Seed Propagation","Cutting"],"pruning_month":["February"],"scientific_name":["Ipomoea imperati"],"soil":["Well-drained","Sandy"],"watering_period":"Morning"}}

To ensure optimal health, water the moss regularly, maintaining a damp, but not waterlogged environment. During dry periods or when kept indoors, misting the moss with water can help maintain appropriate moisture levels. Avoid using hard water, which can leave mineral deposits; purified or rainwater is preferable. Monitor the substrate it is growing on and ensure that it's draining well to prevent water accumulation, which can damage the moss's delicate structure. Keep in mind that overwatering, especially in stagnant conditions, may promote mold growth."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"American tree moss thrives in low to moderate light conditions. It naturally grows in shaded environments under tree canopies, so it doesn't require direct sunlight. In fact, direct sun can be detrimental, leading to drying and potential scorching. For indoor cultivation, place it in indirect light, such as near a north or east-facing window. If you're growing it outdoors, ensure it's in a shaded area, protected from intense midday sun. With the right level of ambient light, the moss will maintain its vibrant green color and overall vitality without suffering from stress or dehydration."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning Climacium americanum typically involves removing dead or damaged sections to encourage healthy growth. This can help maintain its lush, green appearance and prevent potential spread of decay or disease. Use clean, sharp scissors to snip off any brown or dry patches. It’s not a plant that requires extensive pruning due to its slow growth, so occasional maintenance is usually sufficient. Be gentle, as the moss is quite delicate. Regular, light pruning will help promote a fresh and full appearance, particularly if it's used in decorative purposes or terrariums."}],"care_level":"Medium","common_name":"American Tree Moss","description":null,"family":null,"flower_color":null,"flowering_season":false,"fruit_color":null,"growth_rate":"Low","harvest_season":null,"leaf_color":["Green"],"maintenance":"Moderate","origin":["North America"],"other_name":["American Tree Moss"],"pest_susceptibility":[],"propagation":["Division","Spore Propagation"],"pruning_month":["April"],"scientific_name":["Climacium americanum"],"soil":["Acidic","Moist","Well-drained"],"watering_period":"Morning"}}

Water young trees regularly during their first few years, especially during dry periods, to help establish a strong root system. Mature trees typically do not require regular watering, but during prolonged droughts, supplemental watering can help maintain tree health. Always allow the soil to dry out between waterings to prevent root rot and ensure proper drainage to avoid water retention."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Pinus strobiformis thrives in full sunlight, requiring at least six hours of direct sunlight each day. Remove any dead, diseased, or damaged branches whenever noticed. This species benefits from occasional thinning to improve air circulation and reduce pest issues. In very hot climates, some afternoon shade can be beneficial to prevent leaf scorch, especially in the peak of summer."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning Senna pallida is crucial to maintaining its shape and encouraging bushier growth. Prune the plant in late winter or early spring before new growth appears. Focus on removing dead, damaged, or leggy stems to improve air circulation and promote a more compact form. You can also trim back excessively long stems to encourage branching. Regular pruning not only keeps the plant healthy but also supports a more vibrant display of flowers during the blooming season. This plant is quite drought-tolerant once established and prefers slightly dry conditions rather than being overwatered. It is best to allow the soil to dry out partially between waterings to prevent root rot. During the hot summer months, watering once a week should be sufficient, while during cooler seasons, it may need less frequent watering. In regions with intense heat, some afternoon shade might be beneficial to prevent scorching."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning Glandularia bipinnatifida is essential to maintain its health and encourage prolific blooming. Trim back the plant after the main flowering period to encourage a bushier growth and potential re-blooming. Deadheading the spent flowers regularly will prevent seed formation and encourage new blooms. In early spring, you can cut the plant back by about half to rejuvenate its growth. Be sure to use clean and sharp pruning shears to avoid damaging the plant. Regular pruning also helps in controlling its spreading habit."}],"care_level":"Easy","common_name":"Dakota mock vervain","description":"Glandularia bipinnatifida, commonly called Dakota mock vervain, is a species of flowering plant in the verbena family (Verbenaceae).","family":null,"flower_color":"Pink","flowering_season":false,"fruit_color":"[\"Blue\"]","growth_rate":"Moderate","harvest_season":null,"leaf_color":["Green"],"maintenance":"Low","origin":["United States","Mexico"],"other_name":["Dakota mock vervain"],"pest_susceptibility":["Aphids","Spider mites"],"propagation":["Seed Propagation","Cutting"],"pruning_month":["August"],"scientific_name":["Glandularia bipinnatifida"],"soil":["Well-drained","Sandy","Gravelly"],"watering_period":"Morning"}}

It is relatively drought-tolerant once established but thrives best when the soil is kept consistently moist, especially during the growing season. It's important to let the top couple of inches of soil dry out between waterings to prevent root rot. Overwatering can lead to poor plant health, so ensure the plant is in well-draining soil to avoid waterlogging. In periods of high heat or if the plant is in a container, you may need to water more frequently than usual to maintain optimal moisture levels."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Eupatorium capillifolium thrives best in full sun to partial shade conditions. When placed in full sun, it enjoys 6 to 8 hours of direct sunlight per day, which promotes robust growth and helps it develop its distinctive foliage. However, it can also tolerate some partial shade, especially in hotter climates, where some afternoon shade can prevent scorching. If grown in too much shade, the plant may become leggy and produce fewer flowers. Therefore, providing a balanced light environment based on your geographical location is optimal for this plant."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning is not strictly necessary for Eupatorium capillifolium, but it can help maintain a more manageable size and encourage bushier growth. The best time to prune is in late winter or early spring before new growth starts. You can cut back the old stems to about 6 inches above the ground. Removing any dead or damaged branches and spent flowers can tidy up the plant and promote healthier growth. Regular trimming can also prevent the plant from self-seeding excessively, which helps control its spread in the garden."}],"care_level":"Easy","common_name":"dogfennel","description":"Eupatorium capillifolium (dogfennel) is a North American perennial herbaceous plant in the family sunflower family, native to the eastern and south-central United States. It is generally between 50 cm and 2 meters tall with several stems that fork from a substantial base. The stems and base are covered in leaves so dissected that they resemble branching green threads coming out of the stem in fractal patterns. This also helps redirect the plant's energy towards producing fresh growth and blooms. Use sharp, sterilized pruning shears to make clean cuts and prevent infections. Additionally, removing any overcrowded stems can help in improving air circulation around the plant."}],"care_level":"Medium","common_name":"queen of the night","description":"Epiphyllum oxypetalum (Dutchman's pipe cactus or queen of the night) is a species of cactus and one of the most cultivated species in the genus. Though it is sometimes referred to as a nightblooming cereus, it is not closely related to any of the species in the tribe Cereeae, such as Selenicereus, that are more commonly known as nightblooming cereus. Instead, it thrives in humid environments that mimic its natural habitat. Ensuring a consistently moist environment, as found in a damp forest floor mixed with decaying organic matter, is crucial. It does not need direct watering but appreciates high humidity levels or environments where moisture retention is naturally high. Avoid dry conditions, as these can hinder its growth considerably."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Mycena leaiana is found commonly in shaded forest environments, particularly thriving in low-light conditions. Direct sunlight is not preferred for its growth, as they are naturally adapted to the dappled sunlight filtering through tree canopies. Ideally, they should be kept in dimly lit areas or alongside other foliage that provides some shade. Maintaining an environment that mimics a forest floor, with indirect light and high humidity, is essential for its proper development."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Unlike typical plants, Mycena leaiana does not require pruning. As a fungus, it grows and decomposes naturally without intervention. If grown for study or observation, simply allow it to follow its natural lifecycle. Remove any decomposing or overly mature fruit bodies to avoid unwanted spores spreading if kept in a controlled environment. However, in a natural setting, leave it untouched to sustain its ecological role in decomposition and nutrient cycling."}],"care_level":"Medium","common_name":"orange mycena","description":"Mycena leaiana, commonly known as the orange mycena or Lea's mycena, is a species of saprobic fungi in the genus Mycena, family Mycenaceae. Characterized by their bright orange caps and stalks and reddish-orange gill edges, they usually grow in dense clusters on deciduous logs. The pigment responsible for the orange color in this species has antibiotic properties. A variety of the species, Mycena leaiana var. australis, can be found in Australia and New Zealand.","family":null,"flower_color":"Orange","flowering_season":false,"fruit_color":null,"growth_rate":"Moderate","harvest_season":null,"leaf_color":["Green"],"maintenance":"Moderate","origin":["North America"],"other_name":["orange mycena"],"pest_susceptibility":[],"propagation":["Spore Propagation"],"pruning_month":["September"],"scientific_name":["Mycena leaiana"],"soil":["Well-drained","Loamy","Moist"],"watering_period":"Morning"}}

For cultivation, it requires a damp environment, simulating its natural habitat. If grown indoors or in a controlled environment, maintaining consistent moisture without waterlogging is crucial, as excess water may promote unwanted mold or bacteria. Mist the substrate to maintain humidity, ensuring it never dries out completely, but avoid soaking to discourage rot."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Hypholoma lateritium, or brick cap, is a mushroom species and does not rely on sunlight for growth as plants do. Instead, it thrives in shady, forest-like environments with indirect sunlight or artificial lighting if grown indoors. Direct sunlight can dry out its growing substrate and hinder its development. Providing subdued lighting similar to its natural habitat helps support its growth cycle and enhances its color and form. Ensure the growing environment mimics its natural conditions for optimal development."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Being a fungus, Hypholoma lateritium does not require pruning in the traditional sense used for plants. However, for maintaining cleanliness and health during cultivation, it is important to remove any decayed or unhealthy fruiting bodies (mushrooms) promptly. This process helps prevent the spread of disease and encourages better growth conditions for healthy specimens. Always use clean tools or hands when handling mushrooms to minimize risk of contamination."}],"care_level":"Medium","common_name":"Brick Cap","description":"Hypholoma lateritium, sometimes called brick cap, is rarer and less well-known than its relatives, the inedible, and poisonous sulfur tuft (Hypholoma fasciculare) and the edible Hypholoma capnoides. {"type":"json_schema","json_schema":{"id":14914,"attracts":["Birds","Butterflies"],"care_guides_details":[{"type":"watering","description":"Borrichia frutescens, commonly known as sea ox-eye daisy, thrives in well-drained soils and is drought-tolerant once established. It requires moderate watering, ensuring the soil remains slightly moist but not waterlogged. During its initial growth period, regular watering helps establish the root system. Once established, it typically requires watering only during extended dry spells. Be cautious to prevent overwatering, as stagnant water can lead to root rot. During rainy seasons or if planted in areas of high rainfall, watering can be significantly reduced or ceased altogether. Adjust frequency based on climate and environmental conditions."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Borrichia frutescens thrives in full sun conditions, requiring at least 6-8 hours of direct sunlight each day to ensure optimal growth and flowering. It is well-suited for coastal areas and tolerates high salt levels, making it an excellent choice for seaside gardens. While it can grow in partial shade, reduced sunlight may lead to less robust flowering and a more leggy plant. For best results, place it in a location where it receives consistent, direct sunlight throughout the day. In hotter climates, slight afternoon shade can help prevent leaf scorch from intense sunlight."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning Borrichia frutescens is generally minimal but beneficial for maintaining its shape and promoting bushier growth. It can be pruned lightly in early spring before the new growth emerges, removing any dead or damaged stems. Occasional trimming of leggy growth can help keep the plant compact and tidy. Deadheading spent flowers encourages more blooms and prevents the plant from diverting energy into seed production. Regularly inspect for diseased or pest-infested areas and remove these sections promptly. Using clean, sharp pruning shears will ensure clean cuts and reduce the risk of disease spread."}],"care_level":"Easy","common_name":"sea ox-eye","description":"Borrichia frutescens is a North American species of flowering plants in the aster family known by the common names sea oxeye, sea oxeye daisy, bushy seaside tansy, and sea-marigold. In Veracruz it is called verdolaga de mar. It is native to the United States and Mexico, where it occurs along the Atlantic and Gulf Coasts. Its distribution extends from Maryland south to Florida and west to Texas in the US, and along the Mexican Gulf Coast...","family":null,"flower_color":"Yellow","flowering_season":false,"fruit_color":"[\"Brown\"]","growth_rate":"Moderate","harvest_season":null,"leaf_color":["Green"],"maintenance":"Low","origin":["United States"],"other_name":["sea ox-eye"],"pest_susceptibility":[],"propagation":["Seed Propagation","Cutting"],"pruning_month":["April"],"scientific_name":["Borrichia frutescens"],"soil":["Well-drained","Sandy","Loamy"],"watering_period":"Morning"}}

{"type":"json_schema","json_schema":{"id":15511,"attracts":["Birds"],"care_guides_details":[{"type":"watering","description":"Strelitzia nicolai, commonly known as the white bird of paradise, requires regular watering to thrive. It's important to maintain evenly moist soil, but be careful not to overwater as this can lead to root rot. Water the plant thoroughly, allowing the top inch of soil to dry out between waterings. During winter months, when the plant's growth slows, reduce the frequency of watering. Always ensure adequate drainage to prevent water from accumulating at the roots, and adjust watering schedules based on the plant's environment and size of the container."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Strelitzia nicolai prefers bright, indirect sunlight for optimal growth but can tolerate some direct sunlight. Ideally, it should be placed near a window with filtered light to protect its leaves from scorching, especially in hot climates. If grown indoors, a location that receives abundant natural light throughout the day is best. While mature plants can adapt to partial shade, insufficient light may result in slower growth and duller foliage. If growing indoors, supplementing with grow lights can help maintain its vibrancy in less well-lit spaces."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning Strelitzia nicolai is essential for maintaining its shape and promoting healthy growth. Regularly remove dead or damaged leaves by cutting them at the base using sharp, sterile pruning shears. To encourage new growth and enhance the plant’s overall appearance, you can also trim spent flower stems. Pruning should generally be done in the spring or early summer when the plant is actively growing. Avoid excessive pruning as this can stress the plant; focus instead on removing specific undesired parts to keep the plant healthy and attractive."}],"care_level":"Medium","common_name":"giant bird-of-paradise flower","description":"Strelitzia nicolai, commonly known as the giant white bird of paradise or wild banana, is a species of banana-like plants with erect woody stems reaching a height of 6 m (20 ft) and the clumps formed can spread as far as 3.5 m (11 ft).","family":null,"flower_color":"White","flowering_season":false,"fruit_color":null,"growth_rate":"Moderate","harvest_season":null,"leaf_color":["Green"],"maintenance":"Moderate","origin":["South Africa"],"other_name":["giant bird-of-paradise flower"],"pest_susceptibility":["Spider mites","Mealybugs"],"propagation":["Seed Propagation","Division"],"pruning_month":["April"],"scientific_name":["Strelitzia nicolai"],"soil":["Well-drained","Loamy"],"watering_period":"Morning"}}

{"type":"json_schema","json_schema":{"id":15709,"attracts":["Birds","Bees"],"care_guides_details":[{"type":"watering","description":"Prunus padus, commonly known as the bird cherry, prefers consistent moisture but does not like to be waterlogged. It is important to water the plant regularly, especially during its growing season in spring and summer. Ensure the soil is well-draining to prevent standing water, which can lead to root rot. During dry spells, increase the watering frequency to maintain soil moisture. However, it is essential to allow the top layer of soil to dry out between watering to prevent excess moisture and fungal diseases. In winter, reduce watering to only when the soil is dry to the touch."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Prunus padus thrives in full sun to partial shade. For optimal growth and flowering, it is best to plant it where it can receive at least 4 to 6 hours of direct sunlight daily. In areas with very hot summers, some relief from afternoon sun can prevent leaf scorch. In partial shade conditions, the plant may have fewer flowers but can still grow healthily. Adequate sunlight exposure also ensures better disease resistance and promotes a strong, healthy structure, allowing the plant to reach its full ornamental potential."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning Prunus padus should typically be done in late winter or early spring before the new growth starts. This timing helps remove dead, diseased, or crossing branches and encourages a strong structure for robust blooms in the following spring. It's advised to prune lightly to maintain the natural shape, focusing on removing any suckers and thinner, weaker growth to prevent the plant from becoming too dense. Avoid heavy pruning as it may reduce flowering. Clean and disinfect your pruning tools before and after use to prevent the spread of diseases."}],"care_level":"Medium","common_name":"bird cherry","description":"Prunus padus, known as bird cherry, hackberry, hagberry, or Mayday tree, is a flowering plant in the rose family Rosaceae. It is a species of cherry, a deciduous small tree or large shrub up to 16 m tall. It is the type species of the subgenus Padus, which have flowers in racemes. It is native to northern Europe and northern Asia.","family":null,"flower_color":"White","flowering_season":false,"fruit_color":"[\"Black\"]","growth_rate":"Moderate","harvest_season":"Autumn","leaf_color":["Green"],"maintenance":"Moderate","origin":["Europe","Asia"],"other_name":["bird cherry"],"pest_susceptibility":["Aphids","Cherry slug","Powdery mildew"],"propagation":["Seed Propagation","Cutting"],"pruning_month":["March"],"scientific_name":["Prunus padus"],"soil":["Well-drained","Loamy","Sandy"],"watering_period":"Morning"}}

When watering, use rainwater or distilled water if possible to avoid mineral build-up, and ensure that the plant is in a well-draining medium to prevent root rot. If growing indoors, fluorescent lighting can help supplement natural light, especially during shorter winter days. Ensure that the plant has some access to natural daylight, but avoid placing it in harsh, direct sunlight to keep it healthy."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning Rhizomnium glabrescens involves removing any dead or discoloured leaves to maintain the overall health and appearance of the plant. This process helps to encourage new growth and maintain a desirable, compact form. Avoid excessive pruning, as this can stress the plant, hindering its natural growth pattern. Moderate clipping is sufficient to keep the plant healthy and tidy."}],"care_level":"Medium","common_name":"rhizomnium moss","description":"Rhizomnium glabrescens, also called fan moss or large leafy moss, is a species of moss in the genus Rhizomnium.","family":null,"flower_color":null,"flowering_season":false,"fruit_color":null,"growth_rate":"Moderate","harvest_season":null,"leaf_color":["Green"],"maintenance":"Low","origin":["North America"],"other_name":["rhizomnium moss"],"pest_susceptibility":[],"propagation":["Spores","Division"],"pruning_month":["March"],"scientific_name":["Rhizomnium glabrescens"],"soil":["Well-drained","Moist"],"watering_period":"Morning"}}

During its growing season, regular watering helps in achieving optimal growth, but be cautious of overwatering as soggy soil can damage the roots. For optimal growth and flowering, it is advisable to plant it in a location where it receives at least 6-8 hours of direct sunlight per day. If it's grown indoors or in shady areas, ensure it gets some direct sunlight each day to prevent weak, leggy growth. Ideally, choose a spot with bright, consistent sunlight access to foster healthy development and maximize resilience."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning Pongamia pinnata is essential for maintaining its shape and encouraging vigorous growth. Prune to maintain a desired shape or size, cutting above a bud or branch collar to promote branching. Avoid excessive pruning as it can stress the tree. Always use clean, sharp tools to prevent damage and disease spread."}],"care_level":"Medium","common_name":"Indian beech tree","description":"Pongamia pinnata (L.) Removing older mushrooms can help reduce the chance of mold or bacteria that might affect younger growth."}],"care_level":"Medium","common_name":"Dryad's Saddle","description":"Polyporus squamosus aka Cerioporus squamosus (yet to be confirmed new taxonomy) is a basidiomycete bracket fungus, with common names including dryad's saddle and pheasant's back mushroom. During the winter, reduce the frequency of watering, making sure the top inch or so of soil has dried out before watering again. Avoid letting the fern sit in water as this could lead to root rot. Utilizing room-temperature, rainwater or filtered water is best, as they are free from hard minerals."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Asplenium scolopendrium thrives in low to medium indirect light conditions, ideally in a shaded or dappled shade location, making it an excellent choice for indoors or shaded outdoor spots. It's important to ensure that the plant receives consistent light conditions, avoiding sudden shifts to bright or dark environments, to maintain healthy foliage. If the plant receives too little light, its growth may slow, and its vibrant green color can fade."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning of Asplenium scolopendrium should mainly focus on removing dead or damaged fronds to maintain its lush appearance and encourage healthy growth. Use clean, sharp scissors or pruning shears to snip off any unwanted foliage at the base of the frond. It's best to carry out pruning tasks during the plant's dormant season or after the new growth phase in spring. Avoid excessive pruning as the fern's natural structure does not require shaping, and over-pruning can stress the plant. Additionally, regularly removing dead fronds can help prevent disease and pest issues."}],"care_level":"Medium","common_name":"Hart's-tongue fern","description":"Asplenium scolopendrium, known as hart's-tongue or hart's-tongue fern (syn. During its growing season in spring and early summer, it benefits from occasional watering, especially if natural rainfall is scarce. However, avoid overwatering as it prefers drier conditions typical of its native habitats. Adjust the frequency based on local climate and rainfall, ensuring that water does not pool around the roots."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Oxytropis lambertii prefers full sun exposure to thrive. It is best to plant it in a location where it receives at least 6-8 hours of direct sunlight each day. This plant is adapted to the naturally sunny habitats of grasslands and open fields, and sufficient sunlight is essential for its growth and flowering. In areas with intense afternoon sun, some partial shade during the hottest part of the day might be beneficial, but generally, more sun will ensure a healthier plant with more vibrant blooms. Avoid planting in shaded areas to prevent leggy growth and poor flowering."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning for Oxytropis lambertii is minimal. It generally does not require frequent pruning, but you can trim off dead or damaged stems to maintain plant health and appearance. It's advisable to prune stems back in early spring before new growth appears to encourage a more robust structure. Avoid heavy pruning as this can stress the plant. If the plant becomes too bushy or starts to spread beyond its desired bounds, selectively removing some stems can help maintain its shape, but do so sparingly to ensure continued flowering and health."}],"care_level":"Medium","common_name":"Lambert's Locoweed","description":"Oxytropis lambertii is a species of flowering plant in the legume family known by several common names, including purple locoweed, woolly locoweed, and Lambert crazyweed.","family":null,"flower_color":"Pink","flowering_season":false,"fruit_color":null,"growth_rate":"Low","harvest_season":null,"leaf_color":["Green"],"maintenance":"Low","origin":["North America"],"other_name":["Lambert's Locoweed"],"pest_susceptibility":["Stem borer insects","Root rot"],"propagation":["Seed Propagation"],"pruning_month":["March"],"scientific_name":["Oxytropis lambertii"],"soil":["Rocky","Gravelly","Well-drained"],"watering_period":"Morning"}}

It's very important to have a pot with drainage holes to prevent water from accumulating at the bottom. During summer, you may need to water more frequently, while in winter, watering can be reduced as the plant's growth slows down."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Phymatosorus grossus thrives best in moderate to bright indirect light but can tolerate low light conditions. Direct sunlight should be avoided as it can scorch the fronds. If placed in a bright room, ensure the plant is shielded from direct sun rays either by curtains or by placing it a few feet away from windows. A location that receives dappled sunlight or is near a north or east-facing window would be ideal. Adjust light exposure depending on any observable changes in the color of the fronds, indicating if it's getting too much or too little light."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning Phymatosorus grossus is relatively straightforward and mainly involves removing yellowed, damaged, or dead fronds to maintain the plant's appearance and health. This can be done any time throughout the year. Use clean, sharp scissors or pruning shears to cut the frond at its base. Regularly check for and remove any debris or dead plant material from around the fern to prevent fungal infections or pests from taking hold. Minimal pruning is needed beyond routine cleaning."}],"care_level":"Medium","common_name":"maile-scented fern","description":null,"family":null,"flower_color":null,"flowering_season":false,"fruit_color":null,"growth_rate":"Moderate","harvest_season":null,"leaf_color":["Green"],"maintenance":"Moderate","origin":["South East Asia","Australia","Africa"],"other_name":["maile-scented fern"],"pest_susceptibility":["Scale insects","Nematodes"],"propagation":["Rhizome division","Spores"],"pruning_month":["March"],"scientific_name":["Phymatosorus grossus"],"soil":["Well-drained","Loamy"],"watering_period":"Morning"}}
