{"type":"json_schema","json_schema":{"id":14319,"attracts":["Bees","Butterflies"],"care_guides_details":[{"type":"watering","description":"Ageratina altissima, commonly known as white snakeroot, requires moderate watering. It's important to keep the soil consistently moist but not waterlogged. During periods of dry weather, water the plant deeply once a week to ensure the soil stays damp but avoid overwatering which can lead to root rot. Allow the top inch of soil to dry out between watering sessions to prevent excessive moisture accumulation, especially in humid climates. Ensure proper drainage in the pot or garden bed to maintain healthy growth."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Ageratina altissima thrives in partial to full shade conditions. It is well-suited for planting under trees or in areas where it receives dappled sunlight throughout the day. While the plant can tolerate some direct sunlight, especially in cooler climates, excessive exposure in full sun can lead to heat stress and scorched leaves. Therefore, aim to provide it with a balance of morning sun and afternoon shade or consistent dappled shade for optimal growth and flowering."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning Ageratina altissima should be done in late winter or early spring before the new growth begins. This involves cutting back the dead and diseased stems to encourage healthier growth. During the growing season, remove any spent flowers to prevent unwanted self-seeding and encourage the plant to produce more blooms. Regular pruning helps to maintain its shape and can prevent the plant from becoming too bushy or overcrowded, ensuring adequate air circulation around the foliage."}],"care_level":"Easy","common_name":"white snakeroot","description":"Ageratina altissima, also known as white snakeroot, richweed, white sanicle, or tall boneset, is a poisonous perennial herb in the family Asteraceae, native to eastern and central North America. An older binomial name for this species is Eupatorium rugosum, but the genus Eupatorium has undergone taxonomic revision by botanists, and a number of the species that were once included in it have been moved to other genera.","family":null,"flower_color":"White","flowering_season":false,"fruit_color":null,"growth_rate":"Moderate","harvest_season":null,"leaf_color":["Green"],"maintenance":"Low","origin":["North America"],"other_name":["white snakeroot"],"pest_susceptibility":["Fungal leaf spot"],"propagation":["Seed Propagation"],"pruning_month":["March"],"scientific_name":["Ageratina altissima"],"soil":["Well-drained","Loamy"],"watering_period":"Morning"}}

{"type":"json_schema","json_schema":{"id":15809,"attracts":["Bees","Butterflies"],"care_guides_details":[{"type":"watering","description":"Euphorbia albomarginata, commonly known as rattlesnake spurge, prefers dry conditions and should be watered sparingly. In general, it is best to allow the soil to dry out completely between waterings. Overwatering can lead to root rot, which is a common problem in succulents like this one. During the growing season (spring and summer), water the plant thoroughly, but infrequently, allowing excess water to drain away. Reduce watering significantly in fall and winter when the plant is not actively growing. Always check the soil moisture level before watering to ensure it truly needs it."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Euphorbia albomarginata thrives in full sun to partial shade. It prefers a location where it can receive at least 6 hours of sunlight per day, which ensures vigorous growth and vibrant foliage. In very hot climates, some afternoon shade can help prevent leaf scorch. If grown indoors, place the plant near a south or west-facing window where it can receive bright, indirect sunlight. If natural light is insufficient, consider supplementing with artificial grow lights to provide the necessary light intensity for healthy growth."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning Euphorbia albomarginata is generally not necessary for plant health, but light pruning can help maintain its shape and promote bushier growth. If you wish to prune, it's best done during the growing season. Start by removing any dead or damaged stems to improve air circulation. Be sure to wear gloves, as the plant's sap can cause skin irritation. Trim back any overly long stems to encourage a denser growth habit. Always use sterilized, sharp pruning tools to make clean cuts and prevent the spread of pathogens."}],"care_level":"Easy","common_name":"Whitemargin Sandmat","description":"Euphorbia albomarginata (formerly Chamaesyce albomarginata), whitemargin sandmat or rattlesnake weed, is a small low-growing annual, in the spurge family (Euphorbia, Euphorbiaceae) native to desert, chaparral, and grassland habitats of southwestern North America, from southern and central California to Northern Mexico and Louisiana.","family":null,"flower_color":"White","flowering_season":false,"fruit_color":null,"growth_rate":"Moderate","harvest_season":null,"leaf_color":["Green and white"],"maintenance":"Low","origin":["North America"],"other_name":["Whitemargin Sandmat"],"pest_susceptibility":[],"propagation":["Seed Propagation","Cutting"],"pruning_month":["April"],"scientific_name":["Euphorbia albomarginata"],"soil":["Well-drained","Sandy","Loamy"],"watering_period":"Morning"}}

Deadhead the flowers as they wilt to encourage more blooms and prevent self-seeding if desired. In late fall or early spring, cut back any dead or old growth to near the base to make way for new shoots. This cleanup helps maintain a tidy appearance and promotes healthy growth. Since goldenrod spreads, you may also want to manage its growth by dividing the plant every few years."}],"care_level":"Easy","common_name":"early goldenrod","description":"Solidago juncea, the early goldenrod, plume golden-rod, or yellow top, is North American species of herbaceous perennial plants of the sunflower family native to eastern and central Canada and the eastern and central United States. Regular inspection of the plant will guide appropriate pruning interventions."}],"care_level":"Medium","common_name":"marsh elder","description":"Iva frutescens is a species of flowering plant in the aster family known by the common names Jesuit's bark, bigleaf marsh-elder, and high-tide bush. Mulching can also help retain moisture and minimize the need for frequent watering."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Salix caroliniana prefers full sun to partial shade conditions, which is vital for optimal growth and health. In sunny locations, ensure it has access to adequate water, as sunlight can increase the rate of evaporation and potentially dry out the soil. If planting in a partially shaded area, make sure it still receives ample morning or afternoon sun to thrive."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning Salix caroliniana can help maintain its shape and encourage healthier growth. Prune this willow tree in late winter or early spring before new growth begins. Remove any dead, diseased, or broken branches to improve air circulation and overall plant health. It's also beneficial to thin out dense areas to allow sunlight to reach the inner branches. Be sure not to cut too far into the main trunk and maintain its natural shape by following the tree's growth pattern as much as possible. For younger trees, regular pruning can help establish a strong structural framework."}],"care_level":"Medium","common_name":"Carolina willow","description":"Salix caroliniana, commonly known as the coastal plain willow, is a shrub or small tree native to the southeastern United States, Mexico and parts of Central America and the Caribbean. It prefers the soil to dry out completely between waterings, especially during its growing season. Watering once every two weeks should suffice during warmer months. In the winter, when the plant is dormant, reduce watering frequency further to once a month or on an as-needed basis. Direct sunlight, particularly during the intense afternoon hours, may scorch the leaves, so it's essential to provide some protection, like a sheer curtain. During winter months, when daylight is limited, consider supplementing with grow lights to support its photosynthesis process."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning Senecio ampullaceus is typically done to maintain shape and remove any dead or damaged parts. If the plant has become leggy or overgrown, you can trim the tips of the stems to encourage more compact growth. Always use clean, sharp pruning shears to make clean cuts and minimize stress on the plant. Regular pruning will not only shape the plant but also help in redirecting energy to healthier growth."}],"care_level":"Medium","common_name":"Texas ragwort","description":"Senecio ampullaceus also known as Texas ragwort, Texas squaw-weed, Texas groundsel, and Texas butterweed is a species of Senecio in the family Asteraceae and gets its Latin name ampullaceus from its flask shaped flower-head and is a recommended native for landscape use in Texas where it came from.","family":null,"flower_color":"Yellow","flowering_season":false,"fruit_color":null,"growth_rate":"Moderate","harvest_season":null,"leaf_color":["Green"],"maintenance":"Moderate","origin":["North America"],"other_name":["Texas ragwort"],"pest_susceptibility":["Fungal leaf spot"],"propagation":["Seed Propagation"],"pruning_month":["July"],"scientific_name":["Senecio ampullaceus"],"soil":["Well-drained","Loamy","Sandy"],"watering_period":"Morning"}}

{"type":"json_schema","json_schema":{"id":15413,"attracts":["Butterflies"],"care_guides_details":[{"type":"watering","description":"Hypericum punctatum generally prefers consistently moist but well-drained soil. Water the plant deeply when the top inch of soil feels dry to the touch. During hot, dry periods, you may need to increase the frequency of watering to ensure the soil remains adequately moist. However, be cautious not to overwater, as standing water can lead to root rot. During the winter months or in dormancy, reduce the watering frequency, allowing the top 2-3 inches of soil to dry out between waterings."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Hypericum punctatum thrives best in full sun to partial shade. Aim to provide at least 6 hours of direct sunlight per day, as this will encourage the best flowering and growth. In areas with intense afternoon sun, some light afternoon shade can protect the plant from excessive heat and potential leaf scorch. While it can tolerate some shade, too much shade may result in reduced flowering and a leggier, less compact growth habit. Ensure the plant receives adequate light to flourish and produce vibrant blooms."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning Hypericum punctatum can help maintain its shape and promote healthy growth. Prune in early spring before new growth starts or in late fall after flowering has finished. Trim back spent flowers and remove any dead, damaged, or diseased branches to encourage bushier growth. Light pruning can also be done throughout the growing season to maintain shape and remove any unwanted growth. Avoid cutting back to the base during the growing season, as this can stress the plant and reduce flowering potential."}],"care_level":"Medium","common_name":"spotted St. John's wort","description":"Hypericum punctatum, the spotted St. John's wort, is a perennial herb native to North America. The yellow-flowered herb occurs throughout eastern North America into southern Canada. The process of microsporogenesis carried out by this plant is prone to errors in chromosomal segregation. It has a diploid number of 14 or 16. Insects are attracted to the plant's pollen and the hypericin in the plant's leaves is toxic to mammals.","family":null,"flower_color":"Yellow","flowering_season":false,"fruit_color":"[\"Red\"]","growth_rate":"Moderate","harvest_season":null,"leaf_color":["Green"],"maintenance":"Moderate","origin":["North America"],"other_name":["spotted St. John's wort"],"pest_susceptibility":[],"propagation":["Seed Propagation","Cutting"],"pruning_month":["August"],"scientific_name":["Hypericum punctatum"],"soil":["Well-drained","Loamy","Sandy"],"watering_period":"Morning"}}

{"type":"json_schema","json_schema":{"id":15513,"attracts":[],"care_guides_details":[{"type":"watering","description":"Ipomoea lacunosa, commonly known as white morning glory, prefers a moderate watering schedule. It's important to ensure that the soil is kept consistently moist but never waterlogged. Allow the top inch of soil to dry out between waterings to prevent root rot. During the growing season, which is typically spring and summer, the plant will require more frequent watering as opposed to fall and winter when its growth slows down. In extremely hot and dry conditions, you may need to water it more frequently to keep it from drying out completely."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Ipomoea lacunosa thrives in full sun to partial shade conditions. For optimal blooming and growth, ensure it receives at least 6 to 8 hours of direct sunlight daily. While it can tolerate some shade, too little sunlight may result in fewer blooms and slower growth. If growing indoors or in a shaded garden area, position the plant where it can get periodic sunshine or consider supplementing with artificial grow lights to mimic its preferred light conditions. Ensuring ample sunlight helps promote vibrant blooms and robust foliage."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning Ipomoea lacunosa should primarily focus on removing dead or damaged leaves and any stems that appear weak or invasive. This can be done in early spring before new growth begins. Pruning helps prevent the plant from becoming overly leggy and helps maintain a tidy appearance. If the plant becomes too large or invasive, trimming it back can encourage more controlled growth. Regularly inspecting and pruning can also prevent the plant from choking neighboring plants, especially if grown in a garden setting."}],"care_level":"Medium","common_name":"White Morning-glory","description":"Ipomoea lacunosa, the whitestar, white morning-glory or pitted morningglory, is a species that belongs to the Ipomoea genus. In this genus most members are commonly referred to as \"morning glories\". The name for the genus, Ipomoea, has root in the Greek words ips and homoios, which translates to worm-like. This is a reference to the plant's vine-like growth. Lacunosa comes from a Latin word meaning air spaces, correlating with the veination of the leaves. Ipomoea lacunosa...","family":null,"flower_color":"White","flowering_season":false,"fruit_color":null,"growth_rate":"Moderate","harvest_season":null,"leaf_color":["Green"],"maintenance":"Moderate","origin":["United States"],"other_name":["White Morning-glory"],"pest_susceptibility":[],"propagation":["Seed Propagation"],"pruning_month":["November"],"scientific_name":["Ipomoea lacunosa"],"soil":["Well-drained"],"watering_period":"Morning"}}

{"type":"json_schema","json_schema":{"id":15711,"attracts":[],"care_guides_details":[{"type":"watering","description":"Persicaria longiseta, also known as Oriental Lady's Thumb, prefers consistently moist soil conditions, reflecting its natural habitat in wetlands and moist areas. However, it is adaptable to varying moisture levels and can tolerate occasional dry spells once established. During the growing season, it is beneficial to water the plant regularly to maintain soil moisture, especially if planted in a dryer environment. Avoid waterlogging, as excessive water can lead to root rot. Adjust watering frequency based on weather conditions and soil drainage properties, reducing in winter when the plant’s growth slows."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Persicaria longiseta thrives in full sun to partial shade environments. For optimal growth, position the plant where it can receive at least 4 to 6 hours of direct sunlight per day. While it can tolerate partial shade, especially in hotter climates, more sunlight typically results in healthier foliage and more vibrant growth. In shaded environments, assess if the plant shows signs of poor vigor or extended growth, which can occur due to insufficient light. Adjust the planting location or surrounding vegetation if necessary to ensure it receives adequate light conditions for robust growth."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning Persicaria longiseta is typically straightforward and beneficial for controlling its spread, as it can become invasive. Regularly cutting back the plant promotes fresh growth and prevents it from overtaking garden space. The best time to prune is in late winter or early spring before new growth begins. Remove any dead, damaged, or overwintered stems by cutting them close to the ground. During the growing season, trim back any overly vigorous stems to maintain the desired shape and prevent seed spread. Disposing of seeds and trimmings is crucial to prevent unwanted propagation."}],"care_level":"Easy","common_name":"low smartweed","description":"Persicaria longiseta is a species of flowering plant in the knotweed family known by the common names Oriental lady's thumb, bristly lady's thumb, Asiatic smartweed, long-bristled smartweed, Asiatic waterpepper, bristled knotweed, bunchy knotweed, and tufted knotweed. It is native to Asia (China, India, Russia, Japan, Malaysia, etc.), and it is present in North America and Europe as an introduced species and often a weed.","family":null,"flower_color":"Pink","flowering_season":false,"fruit_color":"[\"Brown\"]","growth_rate":"Moderate","harvest_season":null,"leaf_color":["Green"],"maintenance":"Low","origin":["East Asia"],"other_name":["low smartweed"],"pest_susceptibility":[],"propagation":["Seed Propagation"],"pruning_month":["March"],"scientific_name":["Persicaria longiseta"],"soil":["Well-drained"],"watering_period":"Morning"}}

It requires at least 6 hours of direct sunlight daily to ensure healthy growth. Placing the plant in a location that receives ample sunlight throughout the day is ideal. If grown indoors, a south-facing window where it can soak in maximum sunlight is perfect. However, during extremely hot weather conditions, some afternoon shade can protect it from scorching. Without adequate light, the plant may become leggy and more prone to diseases."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning of Euphorbia fendleri should be done to maintain its shape and remove any dead or damaged stems. Prune in early spring before new growth begins. Use clean, sharp scissors or pruning shears to avoid damaging the plant. Wear gloves when pruning, as the plant's sap can be irritating to the skin. Additionally, cleaning out old debris around the plant will improve air circulation and reduce the risk of fungal diseases. Pruning can also encourage more robust growth and flowering during the blooming season."}],"care_level":"Medium","common_name":"Fendler's Sandmat","description":"Euphorbia fendleri is a species of euphorb known by the common name Fendler's sandmat. It is native to much of the southwestern and central United States and northern Mexico, where it grows in scrub and woodland habitat in desert and plateau regions. This is a mat- or clump-forming reddish-green plant with a crooked, creeping, hairless stem. The leaves are rounded, oval, or spade-shaped, smooth along the edges and generally coming to a point, and not much...","family":null,"flower_color":"Green","flowering_season":false,"fruit_color":null,"growth_rate":"Moderate","harvest_season":null,"leaf_color":["Green"],"maintenance":"Low","origin":["Southwestern United States","Mexico"],"other_name":["Fendler's Sandmat"],"pest_susceptibility":["Spider mites"],"propagation":["Seed Propagation","Cutting"],"pruning_month":["May"],"scientific_name":["Euphorbia fendleri"],"soil":["Well-drained","Loamy"],"watering_period":"Morning"}}

{"type":"json_schema","json_schema":{"id":14219,"attracts":[],"care_guides_details":[{"type":"watering","description":"Porodaedalea pini, commonly known as the red ring rot fungus, typically does not require traditional ‘watering’ as it is a wood-decaying fungus. It thrives on moisture naturally present in its woody hosts, primarily vital within coniferous tree environments. This fungus benefits from environments with consistent natural humidity, but artificial watering is not applicable for outdoor or native funguses like this, which primarily invade trees directly."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"As Porodaedalea pini is a fungal pathogen, it doesn’t rely on sunlight in the way that plants do. Instead, it inhabits the shaded and protected areas beneath tree bark where direct sunlight is limited. While sunlight can influence the moisture levels and overall health of the tree hosts (indirectly affecting the fungus), the fungus itself doesn’t require sunlight to grow, as it derives nutrients from the decaying wood of its host trees. Therefore, sunlight management isn't directly applicable to this fungus."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning doesn’t apply to Porodaedalea pini since it’s not a plant but a fungus causing decay in trees like pines and firs. To manage its impact, foresters may remove infected tree parts or entire trees to prevent spread. Observing and removing visually infected areas can limit further mycelial advancement. For landscape management, it’s important to enhance the health of surrounding trees, reducing stress factors that could exacerbate fungal invasions, rather than direct pruning."}],"care_level":"Medium","common_name":"Pine Bracket","description":null,"family":null,"flower_color":null,"flowering_season":false,"fruit_color":null,"growth_rate":"Low","harvest_season":null,"leaf_color":null,"maintenance":"Low","origin":["North America","Europe","Asia"],"other_name":["Pine Bracket"],"pest_susceptibility":["Heart rot"],"propagation":[],"pruning_month":["March"],"scientific_name":["Porodaedalea pini"],"soil":["Well-drained","Acidic"],"watering_period":"Morning"}}

{"type":"json_schema","json_schema":{"id":14618,"attracts":[],"care_guides_details":[{"type":"watering","description":"Parmotrema perlatum, commonly known as a type of lichen, generally requires a very minimal watering approach. Typically, lichens are adapted to absorb moisture from the air, so they do not need direct watering. In a cultivated or monitored environment, maintaining a level of ambient humidity is beneficial. Over-watering can be detrimental. To support its natural moisture absorption, mimicking natural humid conditions without direct watering ensures vitality. If necessary, light misting, rather than direct watering, can offer adequate moisture as it replicates natural fog or dew conditions."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Parmotrema perlatum requires indirect sunlight. Lichens generally thrive under filtered sunlight found in their natural forested or rocky habitats. They can tolerate shaded conditions but tend to grow more abundantly in areas with occasional mild sunlight. Direct sunlight may lead to desiccation or damage as lichens absorb ambient moisture and sunlight. When cultivating or observing in an environment, placing them where they can receive diffused light will help mimic their natural exposure, promoting optimal health and growth."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning is not typically required for Parmotrema perlatum as it is a lichen and does not grow in the same manner as vascular plants with stems and leaves. Instead, lichens expand gradually over surfaces like bark or stones. If cultivation is required for scientific or aesthetic reasons, gentle removal can be done to manage overgrowth or transfer. However, handling should be minimal to avoid damage, as lichens are sensitive to touch and can easily become detached from their substrate, impacting their growth and functionality."}],"care_level":"Medium","common_name":"Black Stone Flower","description":"Parmotrema perlatum, commonly known as black stone flower or kalpasi, is a species of lichen used as spice in India. The species occurs throughout the temperate Northern and Southern Hemispheres. Typically used in meat dishes like nahari (Paaya), Bombay biryani, Goat meat stews, it is also used in vegetarian dishes. It is one of the ingredients in East Indian Bottle Masala, used for cooking Meats, fish and vegetables.","family":null,"flower_color":null,"flowering_season":false,"fruit_color":null,"growth_rate":"Moderate","harvest_season":null,"leaf_color":null,"maintenance":"Moderate","origin":["Asia","Europe"],"other_name":["Black Stone Flower"],"pest_susceptibility":["Fungal leaf spot"],"propagation":["Cutting"],"pruning_month":["August"],"scientific_name":["Parmotrema perlatum"],"soil":["Well-drained"],"watering_period":"Morning"}}

{"type":"json_schema","json_schema":{"id":14916,"attracts":["Butterflies","Bees"],"care_guides_details":[{"type":"watering","description":"Canna flaccida, commonly known as the golden canna, thrives in moist to wet environments such as marshes, lakeshores, and ponds. When grown in gardens, it requires consistent watering to replicate these natural conditions, particularly during dry spells. Ensure that the soil remains damp but not waterlogged. Overwatering can lead to root rot, so adequate drainage is essential. In outdoor settings, this plant can withstand occasional flooding, but if planted in containers, a regular watering schedule should be maintained to prevent the soil from drying out completely."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Canna flaccida prefers full sunlight for optimal growth and flowering. It should receive at least six hours of direct sunlight each day to thrive and produce vibrant blooms. While it can tolerate partial shade, prolonged periods of low light can result in fewer flowers and slower growth. If grown indoors or in containers, placing it in a south-facing window or a similarly bright spot will help it flourish. In climates with intense summer heat, providing some afternoon shade can prevent leaf scorch and help the plant maintain its vibrant appearance."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning Canna flaccida is essential for maintaining its health and appearance. Deadhead the spent blooms regularly to encourage continuous flowering. At the end of the growing season, prune back the foliage to the ground. This prevents any diseased or dead parts from overwintering pests or infections. Additionally, cutting back the stems after flowering promotes fresh growth in the following season. Always use clean, sharp tools to prevent disease spread. If the plant becomes unruly or too large, you can divide the rhizomes to control its growth and propagate new plants."}],"care_level":"Easy","common_name":"Golden Canna","description":"Canna flaccida is a species of the Canna genus, a member of the family Cannaceae. The species is indigenous to the wetlands of the south-central and south-eastern United States from Texas to South Carolina. It is also reportedly naturalized in India, the Philippines, Mexico, Panama, Cuba, the Dominican Republic, Peru and southern Brazil.","family":null,"flower_color":"Yellow","flowering_season":false,"fruit_color":null,"growth_rate":"Moderate","harvest_season":null,"leaf_color":["Green"],"maintenance":"Moderate","origin":["Southeastern United States"],"other_name":["Golden Canna"],"pest_susceptibility":[],"propagation":["Division","Seed Propagation"],"pruning_month":["September"],"scientific_name":["Canna flaccida"],"soil":["Moist","Well-drained","Wet"],"watering_period":"Morning"}}

{"type":"json_schema","json_schema":{"id":15614,"attracts":["Bees","Butterflies"],"care_guides_details":[{"type":"watering","description":"Lupinus nootkatensis, or Nootka lupine, prefers moderately moist soil but can tolerate drought once established. Water young plants regularly to help establish a deep root system. As they mature, water them less frequently, allowing the soil to dry out slightly between watering sessions. Overwatering can lead to root rot, so it’s important to ensure good drainage. During periods of excessive heat or drought, you may need to increase watering frequency, but be cautious not to let the soil remain soggy. Aim to water in the morning to reduce evaporation and prevent fungal diseases."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Nootka lupine thrives best in full sun conditions, which helps it grow robustly and flower abundantly. Aim to provide at least six hours of direct sunlight per day. While it can tolerate partial shade, too much shade may result in fewer blooms and weaker growth. If you live in a region with intense sun, it's beneficial to monitor your plant for signs of sunburn, such as browning edges on leaves, and consider providing light afternoon shade if needed. Ensuring the plant has adequate sunlight will promote healthy, vibrant blooms and overall vigor."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning Lupinus nootkatensis isn't typically needed for the health of the plant, but it helps maintain its shape and encourages new growth. Deadhead spent flowers regularly to promote re-blooming and to prevent the plant from self-seeding excessively. In late winter or early spring, cut back any dead or damaged stems to clean up the plant and encourage vigorous new growth in the upcoming growing season. When pruning, clean your tools to prevent the spread of diseases, and be mindful not to cut into the basal growth, which can harm the plant's ability to generate new shoots."}],"care_level":"Medium","common_name":"Nootka Lupine","description":"Lupinus nootkatensis, the Nootka lupine, is a perennial plant of the genus Lupinus in the legume family, Fabaceae. It is native to North-America. The Nootka lupine grows to 60 cm tall. During its active growing period in spring and summer, water thoroughly whenever the top inch of soil feels dry to the touch. In the cooler months, reduce watering to allow the soil to dry out slightly between sessions, as excessive moisture during this period can lead to root rot. Always ensure good drainage to prevent standing water around the roots, and consider using a well-draining potting mix if planting in containers."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Melanthera nivea prefers full sun to thrive, requiring at least six hours of direct sunlight each day. This helps encourage deep root growth, which is crucial for the tree's stability and health. During particularly hot or dry spells, increase the frequency of watering. Avoid waterlogging, as overly wet soil can lead to root rot and other fungal issues."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Betula pubescens thrives best in full sun to partial shade conditions. It ideally requires at least 4 to 6 hours of direct sunlight per day to promote healthy growth and encourage the development of its distinctive white bark. Although it can tolerate some shade, too little sunlight may hinder its growth and reduce vigor. When planting, select a location with adequate sun exposure, preferably where it will receive morning sunlight and some afternoon shade to protect it from the harshest sun rays. This balance ensures optimal growth and resilience of the tree."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning of Betula pubescens should be carried out during late fall or early spring when the tree is dormant. Remove any dead, diseased, or crossing branches to maintain the health and shape of the tree. It's also beneficial to thin out crowded areas to allow better air circulation and sunlight penetration. Avoid heavy pruning as it can stress the birch tree. Instead, aim for light maintenance pruning annually. Make cuts just outside the branch collar to ensure proper healing. Regularly inspect the tree for any signs of disease or damage that require attention."}],"care_level":"Easy","common_name":"Downy Birch","description":"Betula pubescens (syn. Betula alba), commonly known as downy birch and also as moor birch, white birch, European white birch or hairy birch, is a species of deciduous tree, native and abundant throughout northern Europe and northern Asia, growing farther north than any other broadleaf tree. {"type":"json_schema","json_schema":{"id":15215,"attracts":["Bees"],"care_guides_details":[{"type":"watering","description":"Rubus pedatus, commonly known as the five-leaved bramble, prefers consistently moist soil conditions. Be sure to water it regularly to keep the soil damp, especially during dry spells. However, it is crucial not to overwater or allow the plant roots to sit in water, which can lead to root rot. Ensure the plant is in well-draining soil, and adjust watering frequency during periods of rainfall to prevent waterlogging. Mulching can help retain soil moisture and maintain even humidity around the roots."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Rubus pedatus thrives in habitats with partial to full shade, making it an excellent choice for areas that receive dappled sunlight or are underneath trees. While it can tolerate some direct sunlight, too much exposure, especially during peak summer, may stress the plant and hinder its growth. In its natural environment, it often grows in shaded forest areas, so replicating these conditions by providing protection from intense afternoon sun will ensure optimal growth and health of the plant."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning Rubus pedatus should be done annually to promote healthy growth. Late winter or early spring, before new growth starts, is the ideal time for pruning. Remove any dead, damaged, or crossing stems to encourage good air circulation and light penetration. Trim the stems back to healthy buds to maintain the desired shape and size. Regular pruning not only keeps the plant tidy but also helps in promoting new growth and potentially more abundant flowering and fruiting."}],"care_level":"Medium","common_name":"Five-leaf Dwarf Bramble","description":"Rubus pedatus is an Asian and North American species of raspberry known under the common names Five-leaved bramble, Strawberryleaf Raspberry and Creeping Raspberry.","family":null,"flower_color":"White","flowering_season":false,"fruit_color":"[\"Red\"]","growth_rate":"Moderate","harvest_season":"Summer","leaf_color":["Green"],"maintenance":"Moderate","origin":["North America"],"other_name":["Five-leaf Dwarf Bramble"],"pest_susceptibility":["Fungal leaf spot","Aphids"],"propagation":["Seed Propagation","Cutting"],"pruning_month":["June"],"scientific_name":["Rubus pedatus"],"soil":["Well-drained","Loamy"],"watering_period":"Morning"}}

{"type":"json_schema","json_schema":{"id":14101,"attracts":["Bees"],"care_guides_details":[{"type":"watering","description":"Trifolium alpinum, or Alpine clover, prefers well-drained soils and doesn't require frequent watering. It's adapted to alpine environments, which means it's accustomed to harsh conditions and occasional droughts. During the active growing season, water the plant moderately, ensuring the soil does not become waterlogged. In contrast, reduce watering significantly during the dormant winter months. Always allow the top inch of soil to dry out before watering again. Overwatering is a common mistake, so it's important to monitor soil moisture closely."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Trifolium alpinum thrives in full sun to partial shade, replicating its native alpine habitat. Ideally, it should receive at least 6 hours of direct sunlight per day for optimal growth. If planted in hotter climates or lower altitudes, providing afternoon shade can protect it from scorching. In cooler, alpine-like environments, the plant can withstand more direct sunlight. A balance of light and shade will ensure the healthiest growth and most vibrant flowering, making it crucial to evaluate the specific conditions of your garden before planting."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning Trifolium alpinum is not typically a demanding task. Due to its compact form, pruning can be kept minimal and is often performed to remove any dead or diseased foliage, which helps maintain plant health and aesthetic appeal. If the plant becomes unruly or leggy, you can trim it back slightly to encourage more bushy growth. The best time to do any necessary pruning is in early spring before new growth begins. Ensure that your pruning tools are clean to prevent the spread of disease."}],"care_level":"Easy","common_name":"Alpine Clover","description":"Trifolium alpinum is a species of flowering plant in the legume family known by the common name alpine clover. It is native to the Alps.","family":null,"flower_color":"Pink","flowering_season":false,"fruit_color":"[\"Brown\"]","growth_rate":"Moderate","harvest_season":null,"leaf_color":["Green"],"maintenance":"Low","origin":["Europe"],"other_name":["Alpine Clover"],"pest_susceptibility":[],"propagation":["Seed Propagation"],"pruning_month":["September"],"scientific_name":["Trifolium alpinum"],"soil":["Well-drained","Loamy"],"watering_period":"Morning"}}

{"type":"json_schema","json_schema":{"id":15115,"attracts":["Bees","Butterflies"],"care_guides_details":[{"type":"watering","description":"Knautia arvensis prefers moderate watering and appreciates well-drained soil conditions. During the growing season, water the plant regularly to keep the soil slightly moist but not soggy. Ensure that the top inch of the soil is dry before the next watering to prevent overwatering, which can lead to root rot. In drought conditions, increase watering to maintain plant health, but in cooler months, water sparingly, allowing the plant's natural dormancy cycle to occur. Mulching can help retain soil moisture and maintain a stable root environment, particularly in warmer climates."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Knautia arvensis thrives best in full sun to partial shade. Full sun exposure for at least six hours daily encourages optimal blooming and maintains the plant's structural integrity. However, it can tolerate partial shade, where it will still perform well, though flowering may be reduced. In very hot climates, providing some afternoon shade can prevent foliage scorch and prolong the bloom period. Ensure the plant is placed in an open area that allows adequate air circulation to minimize potential disease issues associated with damp, shaded conditions."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning Knautia arvensis involves deadheading spent flowers to encourage continuous blooming throughout the season. This can also help maintain a tidy appearance and prevent self-seeding, which can lead to invasive growth. In late winter or early spring, before new growth begins, cut back any dead or damaged stems to the ground to promote healthy new growth. Regular pruning helps manage the plant's height and spread, keeping its contribution to garden aesthetics under control. It is generally a low-maintenance plant, requiring minimal pruning once established."}],"care_level":"Medium","common_name":"Field Scabious","description":"Knautia arvensis, commonly known as field scabious, is a species in the genus Knautia.","family":null,"flower_color":"Purple","flowering_season":false,"fruit_color":null,"growth_rate":"Moderate","harvest_season":null,"leaf_color":["Green"],"maintenance":"Low","origin":["Europe","Asia"],"other_name":["Field Scabious"],"pest_susceptibility":["Aphids","Powdery Mildew"],"propagation":["Seed Propagation","Cutting"],"pruning_month":["November"],"scientific_name":["Knautia arvensis"],"soil":["Well-drained","Loamy"],"watering_period":"Morning"}}

{"type":"json_schema","json_schema":{"id":15811,"attracts":[],"care_guides_details":[{"type":"watering","description":"Euphorbia micromera, a drought-tolerant succulent, requires minimal watering. It’s important to let the soil dry out completely between waterings to prevent root rot. Typically, you should water it sparingly, about once every two to three weeks during its growing season in spring and summer. In the fall and winter, reduce watering even further to once a month or less, as the plant enters dormancy. Ensure excess water can drain away to keep the roots from sitting in moisture. Overwatering is one of the most common issues, so err on the side of under-watering."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Euphorbia micromera thrives in bright, indirect sunlight. It can also tolerate some direct sun, especially morning sunlight, which is gentle. Ideally, position the plant where it can receive about six hours of light per day. It's adaptable to a range of lighting conditions but avoid prolonged exposure to harsh, midday sun, as this can cause scorching. Indoors, placing it near a south or east-facing window is optimal. If the plant's growth seems sluggish or if it's losing its vibrant coloration, it may not be receiving enough light, and relocation to a brighter spot might be necessary."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning Euphorbia micromera is generally minimal but can be done to maintain its shape and remove any dead or diseased parts. Late winter or early spring is the best time to prune before the new growth starts. Use clean, sharp tools to make clean cuts. Be cautious of the milky sap that the plant secretes, as it can be irritating to the skin and toxic. It's best to wear gloves and protective eyewear while handling. Prune selectively to maintain the aesthetic shape or to remove any overcrowded stems, allowing the plant to remain healthy and vigorous."}],"care_level":"Easy","common_name":"Sonoran Sandmat","description":"Euphorbia micromera is a species of euphorb known by the common name Sonoran sandmat. It is native to the southwestern United States from California to Texas, and northern Mexico, where it grows in sandy soils in desert and other dry habitat. It is an annual herb forming a small mat of slender stems. The hairy to hairless leaves are oblong in shape and just a few millimeters long. The tiny inflorescence is a cyathium less than...","family":null,"flower_color":null,"flowering_season":false,"fruit_color":null,"growth_rate":"Moderate","harvest_season":null,"leaf_color":["Green"],"maintenance":"Low","origin":["Western United States"],"other_name":["Sonoran Sandmat"],"pest_susceptibility":[],"propagation":["Seed Propagation"],"pruning_month":["March"],"scientific_name":["Euphorbia micromera"],"soil":["Well-drained","Sandy"],"watering_period":"Morning"}}

{"type":"json_schema","json_schema":{"id":14619,"attracts":["Bees"],"care_guides_details":[{"type":"watering","description":"Jubaea chilensis, commonly known as the Chilean Wine Palm, prefers moderately dry conditions and should not be overwatered. It is crucial to allow the soil to dry out between waterings, as the plant is susceptible to root rot in excessively wet soil. During its growing season, water the palm deeply approximately every two weeks, but reduce the frequency in the winter months when its water needs are lower. If the plant is grown in a container, ensure there is adequate drainage and adjust watering based on the pot's moisture retention."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"The Chilean Wine Palm thrives in full sun conditions, which is essential for its growth and development. It requires at least 6 to 8 hours of direct sunlight each day. While it can tolerate some light shade, insufficient sunlight may lead to slower growth and suboptimal health. In particularly hot climates, some afternoon shade can be beneficial to prevent leaf scorch, but generally, the more light it receives, the better. Ensure the planting location provides uninterrupted sun exposure for the best results."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning for Jubaea chilensis is primarily done to remove dead or damaged fronds to maintain its neat appearance and health. It is best to prune in the late spring after new growth has emerged but be cautious not to remove too many fronds as this can stress the plant. Use clean, sharp tools to trim the fronds back to the trunk, taking care not to damage the trunk itself. Regular inspection for any signs of disease or pests can help prevent issues and ensure the palm remains vigorous."}],"care_level":"Medium","common_name":"Chilean wine palm","description":"Jubaea is a genus of palms with one species, Jubaea chilensis or Jubaea spectabilis, commonly known as the \"Chilean wine palm\" or \"Chile cocopalm\". It is native to southwestern South America and is endemic to a small area of central Chile between 32°S and 35°S in southern Coquimbo, Valparaíso, Santiago, O'Higgins, and northern Maule regions.","family":null,"flower_color":"Yellow","flowering_season":false,"fruit_color":"[\"Brown\"]","growth_rate":"Low","harvest_season":"Summer","leaf_color":["Green"],"maintenance":"Moderate","origin":["Chile"],"other_name":["Chilean wine palm"],"pest_susceptibility":[],"propagation":["Seed Propagation"],"pruning_month":["June"],"scientific_name":["Jubaea chilensis"],"soil":["Well-drained","Loamy"],"watering_period":"Morning"}}

In regions with extremely hot summers, providing some afternoon shade can protect the plant from excessive heat stress. If grown indoors, place it near a south or west-facing window where it can receive plenty of natural light, or consider supplementing with artificial lights if necessary."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning Pseudognaphalium obtusifolium is generally not required for its health but can be done to maintain its shape and appearance. {"type":"json_schema","json_schema":{"id":14519,"attracts":["Birds","Butterflies"],"care_guides_details":[{"type":"watering","description":"Arundinaria gigantea, also known as giant cane, prefers consistently moist soil, especially during its active growing season in spring and summer. It can tolerate some drought, but for optimal growth, it should not be left to dry out completely for extended periods. Water the plant deeply to encourage the deep root system it naturally develops. In areas with hot climates or less frequent rainfall, more regular watering will be necessary to maintain the requisite moisture levels in the soil, particularly for young plants or those in containers."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Arundinaria gigantea thrives in full sun to partial shade. It performs best in a location where it can receive at least 4-6 hours of sunlight each day. In hotter climates, providing some afternoon shade can prevent the leaves from scorching. While it can tolerate some shade, dense shade may hinder its growth and reduce vigor. When planting under large trees or in shaded areas, ensure that the plant still receives adequate light for optimal health and does not compete excessively for nutrients."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning Arundinaria gigantea is essential to manage its size and prevent it from becoming invasive. In late winter or early spring, before the new growth begins, remove any dead, damaged, or weak stems with clean, sharp shears. This will stimulate healthy new growth. If the plant is placed indoors, rotating it regularly ensures even exposure to sunlight, promoting uniform growth, and preventing any leaves from becoming overly shaded."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning Croton argyranthemus is necessary to maintain its shape and promote healthy leaf growth. Prune in late winter or early spring before the new growth begins. Use sharp, clean shears to remove any dead or damaged leaves and branches. You can also pinch back the tips of the plant to encourage bushier growth. Pruning helps improve air circulation within the plant, reducing the risk of pests and diseases. Always wear gloves when pruning, as the plant's sap can be irritating to the skin. {"type":"json_schema","json_schema":{"id":15414,"attracts":["Butterflies","Bees"],"care_guides_details":[{"type":"watering","description":"Eutrochium fistulosum, commonly known as hollow Joe-Pye weed, prefers consistently moist soil and can tolerate wet conditions. It's important to water it regularly, especially during dry spells, to ensure the soil remains damp. However, avoid waterlogging, which can lead to root rot. Mulching around the base can help retain soil moisture. During its growing season, check the soil moisture frequently and water if the top inch feels dry. In areas with sufficient rainfall, additional watering might not be necessary once the plant is established, except in prolonged dry periods."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Eutrochium fistulosum thrives in full sun to partial shade conditions. Ideally, it should receive at least 4 to 6 hours of direct sunlight daily to support robust flowering and healthy growth. In regions with extremely hot climates, providing afternoon shade can prevent stress from intense sunlight. While this plant can tolerate some shade, too much shade can reduce its flowering potential and result in a leggier growth habit. Choosing a planting location with ample morning sunlight and some afternoon shade will often yield the best results for this species."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning Eutrochium fistulosum typically involves cutting back the stems to maintain shape and encourage bushier growth. In early spring, remove any dead or damaged stems to make way for new growth. You can trim back the plant by about one-third in late spring if you want to control its height, as it can grow quite tall. After flowering, deadhead spent blooms to extend the flowering period and prevent unwanted self-seeding. Once established, the blue spruce is relatively drought-tolerant but will benefit from occasional deep watering during dry spells. Overwatering should be avoided as it can lead to root rot. Ideal watering practices involve checking the top few inches of soil for moisture and providing water before it dries out completely, ensuring that the entire root zone is thoroughly soaked."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Picea pungens thrives best in full sunlight, requiring at least six hours of direct sunlight each day. Ensuring optimal sunlight will support strong, healthy growth and enhance the tree's resistance to pests and diseases."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning for Picea pungens is best done in late winter or early spring before new growth begins. The main goal is to maintain the natural shape and remove any dead, diseased, or damaged branches. Avoid heavy pruning as these trees do not respond well to cutting back into old wood. Light trimming can help maintain the shape and size of the tree, but do not remove more than a third of the foliage in one go. Prune away any branches that cross each other or grow towards the center to improve air circulation."}],"care_level":"Medium","common_name":"blue spruce","description":"The blue spruce, green spruce, white spruce, Colorado spruce, or Colorado blue spruce, with the scientific name Picea pungens, is a species of spruce tree. If planted in a shaded area, consider increasing the light exposure by trimming overhanging branches or relocating the plant. Proper sunlight ensures robust growth and optimal fruiting. It benefits from light pruning in early spring to remove any dead or damaged stems from winter’s effect. This encourages new growth and maintains overall plant health. As the plant grows, regular removal of yellowing or diseased leaves will help prevent the spread of disease. Additionally, pinching back the tips of the stems can promote a bushier growth habit and can enhance fruit production by encouraging more flowering branches. Be sure to use clean and sharp pruning tools to avoid damaging the plant."}],"care_level":"Medium","common_name":"Virginia groundcherry","description":"Physalis virginiana, the Virginia groundcherry, is a rhizomatous perennial with a deeply buried stem base. To determine when to water, check the top couple of inches of soil; if it feels dry, it’s time to water."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Vitis riparia thrives best in full sunlight, requiring at least 6 to 8 hours of direct sun each day. While it can tolerate partial shade, especially where intense sunlight might scorch young leaves, fruiting will likely be less abundant than in full sun conditions."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning Vitis riparia is crucial for health and productivity. It should be done during the dormant season, usually in late winter. Remove any dead, damaged, or crossing branches to encourage an open structure. Focus on reducing overcrowding to allow sunlight and air to penetrate. Cut back one-year-old canes, as they bear fruit, to a few buds per cane. This process encourages new growth and fruiting in the coming season. Keep enough mature wood to sustain the plant's structure while promoting vigorous new growth for optimum fruit production."}],"care_level":"Medium","common_name":"riverbank grape","description":"Vitis riparia Michx, with common names riverbank grape or frost grape, is a native American climbing or trailing vine, widely distributed across central and eastern Canada and the central and northeastern parts of the United States, from Quebec to Texas, and eastern Montana to Nova Scotia. There are reports of isolated populations in the northwestern USA, but these are probably naturalized. It is long-lived and capable of reaching into the upper canopy of the tallest trees....","family":null,"flower_color":"Green","flowering_season":false,"fruit_color":"[\"Purple\"]","growth_rate":"High","harvest_season":"Autumn","leaf_color":["Green"],"maintenance":"Moderate","origin":["North America"],"other_name":["riverbank grape"],"pest_susceptibility":["Downy Mildew","Powdery Mildew","Grape Leafhopper","Grape Phylloxera"],"propagation":["Cutting","Seed Propagation"],"pruning_month":["March"],"scientific_name":["Vitis riparia"],"soil":["Well-drained","Loamy"],"watering_period":"Morning"}}

{"type":"json_schema","json_schema":{"id":15812,"attracts":["Bees","Butterflies"],"care_guides_details":[{"type":"watering","description":"Lappula occidentalis, commonly known as flatspine stickseed, is a drought-tolerant plant that thrives in dry conditions. It does not require frequent watering and can actually suffer from overwatering. To care for this plant, water it sparingly, allowing the soil to completely dry out between waterings. During extended dry periods or in unusually hot climates, you may provide additional water, but typically this plant will survive well on rainfall and occasional supplemental watering. Ensure that water drains well to prevent root rot, as the plant's native habitat is in well-drained, sandy, or rocky soils."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Lappula occidentalis requires full sun to thrive, meaning it needs about six to eight hours of direct sunlight per day. This sun exposure ensures vigorous growth and supports its flowering. If planted in a partially shaded area, the plant may become leggy and produce fewer flowers. It's well-suited to open, bright areas, such as fields or meadows, where it can benefit from full exposure to sunlight. While it can tolerate some light shade, optimal growth and flowering will occur in a location where it receives ample sunlight throughout the day."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning Lappula occidentalis is generally not necessary as it is a low-maintenance plant. However, you may want to remove dead or damaged stems to maintain an orderly look and promote healthier growth. Pruning can be done at any time during the growing season as needed. Be cautious while handling the plant, as its small barbed seeds can stick to clothing and skin. If the plant has become too bushy or is self-seeding excessively, you can trim back some of the stems or remove seed heads to control its spread and keep the plant looking tidy."}],"care_level":"Medium","common_name":"Flatspine Stickseed","description":null,"family":null,"flower_color":"Blue","flowering_season":false,"fruit_color":"[\"Brown\"]","growth_rate":"Moderate","harvest_season":null,"leaf_color":["Green"],"maintenance":"Low","origin":["North America"],"other_name":["Flatspine Stickseed"],"pest_susceptibility":["Fungal leaf spot"],"propagation":["Seed Propagation"],"pruning_month":["August"],"scientific_name":["Lappula occidentalis"],"soil":["Well-drained","Loamy"],"watering_period":"Morning"}}

{"type":"json_schema","json_schema":{"id":15713,"attracts":["Bees"],"care_guides_details":[{"type":"watering","description":"Caladenia lyallii, or Lyall's Spider Orchid, requires careful watering practices. Mimicking its natural environment, it's best to water sparingly and allow the substrate to dry out slightly between waterings to prevent root rot. During the growing season, typically in spring and early summer, increase watering frequency slightly to support its active growth. However, during its dormancy period, usually in late summer to winter, reduce watering significantly or stop altogether to prevent excessive moisture. Always ensure the plant is in well-draining soil to avoid waterlogging."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Caladenia lyallii thrives in conditions that provide dappled sunlight. In its natural habitat, it often grows in open woodlands or grassy areas where it receives filtered sunlight through trees. When grown in cultivation, aim to replicate this environment by providing bright, indirect sunlight for most of the day. Avoid direct harsh sunlight, especially during peak hours, as this can scorch its delicate leaves and flowers. During dormancy, the plant can tolerate reduced light conditions. Ensuring the right balance of light will promote healthy growth and vibrant blooms."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning Caladenia lyallii is generally minimal. After flowering, it’s beneficial to remove any spent flowers or leaves to tidy up the plant and improve its appearance. This helps redirect the plant’s energy towards developing healthy tubers for the next growth cycle. If leaves appear damaged or diseased, remove them promptly to prevent any potential spread of disease. Avoid cutting into the green, active parts of the plant, as it might hinder its overall health and vigor. Pruning should be done with clean, sharp tools to avoid causing harm to the plant."}],"care_level":"Medium","common_name":"Mountain Caps Orchid","description":"Caladenia alpina, commonly known as mountain or alpine caladenia, is a plant in the orchid family Orchidaceae and is native to subalpine areas of south-eastern Australia and to New Zealand. It has a single fleshy leaf and a thin wiry flowering spike bearing two white flowers with red bars on the labellum. In New Zealand this orchid is sometimes known as Caladenia lyallii.","family":null,"flower_color":"White","flowering_season":false,"fruit_color":null,"growth_rate":"Low","harvest_season":null,"leaf_color":["Green"],"maintenance":"Moderate","origin":["Australia"],"other_name":["Mountain Caps Orchid"],"pest_susceptibility":["Fungal leaf spot"],"propagation":["Seed Propagation"],"pruning_month":["August"],"scientific_name":["Caladenia lyallii"],"soil":["Well-drained"],"watering_period":"Morning"}}

Excess moisture should be avoided to prevent rot; a fine misting can help maintain optimal humidity. If you are cultivating or observing these in a controlled environment, use a spray bottle to lightly mist the area once or twice a week, depending on ambient humidity and temperature."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Gyroporus castaneus, like most fungi, prefers indirect sunlight or shaded conditions. Direct exposure to sunlight can dry out the substrate and inhibit growth. When cultivating or observing in nature, choose locations that mimic its natural habitat—underneath deciduous trees or areas with dappled light. Ensure the environment is consistently cool and moist, which is ideal for fungal growth. If indoors, use artificial lighting that simulates the low light levels found under forest canopies and avoids direct exposure to bright lights."},{"type":"pruning","description":"As Gyroporus castaneus is a mushroom, traditional pruning does not apply. However, if cultivating, ensure to remove any decomposing or damaged parts promptly to prevent contamination or spread of decay. In natural settings, it's best to observe rather than interfere. Handling should be minimal and done with clean tools to avoid introducing pathogens."}],"care_level":"Medium","common_name":"Chestnut Bolete","description":"Gyroporus castaneus, or commonly the chestnut bolete, is a small, white-pored relation of the Boletus mushrooms. {"type":"json_schema","json_schema":{"id":15117,"attracts":[],"care_guides_details":[{"type":"watering","description":"Phormium cookianum, also known as mountain flax, prefers well-draining soil and should be watered moderately. While it is somewhat drought tolerant, it thrives with regular watering during the growing season. Water deeply once a week, allowing the soil to dry slightly between watering sessions to prevent waterlogging, which can lead to root rot. Reduce watering in the winter months when the plant's growth slows. Always ensure adequate drainage to maintain healthy roots, as consistently soggy soil can harm the plant."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Phormium cookianum thrives in full sun to partial shade conditions. It benefits from at least 6 hours of sunlight daily for vibrant foliage color and robust growth, although it can tolerate some shade in warmer climates. When planted in too much shade, the leaves may become soft and may not display their vibrant colors optimally. In particularly hot regions, providing some afternoon shade can help prevent leaf scorch. It's a versatile plant that adapts well to a variety of light conditions, but maximizing sunlight exposure is ideal for its health and appearance."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning Phormium cookianum involves removing old and damaged leaves to promote new growth. In the early spring, cut back any dead or diseased foliage at the base with clean shears to tidy the plant and encourage its natural shape. Avoid cutting healthy leaves unless they are severely damaged or affecting the plant’s overall aesthetic. Regularly tidying up the plant by removing spent flower stalks and old leaves helps to keep it looking its best and prevents any unnecessary stress on the plant."}],"care_level":"Medium","common_name":"Mountain flax","description":"Phormium colensoi (syn. Phormium cookianum; mountain flax, lesser New Zealand flax, or wharariki in Māori) is a perennial plant that is native to New Zealand. It is less common than the other Phormium species, P. tenax. The greenish, yellow or orange flowers are followed by twisted seed pods.","family":null,"flower_color":"Yellow","flowering_season":false,"fruit_color":null,"growth_rate":"Moderate","harvest_season":null,"leaf_color":["Green"],"maintenance":"Low","origin":["New Zealand"],"other_name":["Mountain flax"],"pest_susceptibility":[],"propagation":["Seed Propagation","Division"],"pruning_month":["March"],"scientific_name":["Phormium cookianum"],"soil":["Well-drained","Loamy"],"watering_period":"Morning"}}

{"type":"json_schema","json_schema":{"id":15616,"attracts":["Bees","Butterflies"],"care_guides_details":[{"type":"watering","description":"Lespedeza hirta, commonly known as bush clover, thrives in dry to medium moisture soils. It is adapted to withstand drought conditions and prefers infrequent but deep watering to stimulate deep root growth. During its first growing season, ensure consistent moisture until the roots are established. Once established, it requires minimal watering, only during extended periods of dry weather. Over-watering should be avoided, as it can lead to root rot and other moisture-related issues. In well-drained soil, the plant will manage periods of dry conditions effectively, making it a relatively low-maintenance plant in terms of water needs."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"This plant flourishes in full sun, requiring at least six to eight hours of direct sunlight daily for optimal growth. Placing Lespedeza hirta in a position where it receives abundant sunlight encourages vigorous blooming and a robust plant structure. While it can tolerate some light shade, full sunlight ensures the best flowering results and overall plant health. In excessively shaded areas, the plant may become leggy and produce fewer blooms. Ensuring adequate sunlight also helps in reducing the risk of mold and fungal diseases by promoting good air circulation and faster drying of foliage."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning Lespedeza hirta should be done in late winter or early spring before new growth begins. Cut back the stems close to the ground to promote a compact and healthy appearance. This perennial can become leggy if not pruned regularly, reducing its visual appeal and bushiness. By pruning, you encourage vigorous growth and flowering in the new season. Throughout the growing season, remove any dead or damaged stems to maintain the plant's health and aesthetics. Regular pruning also helps control the spread and maintains the plant's size within desired limits."}],"care_level":"Medium","common_name":"hairy lespedeza","description":"Lespedeza hirta, the hairy lespedeza or hairy bush clover, is a perennial forb native to Ontario and the eastern United States that grows at most three feet high. It has inconspicuous small white blooms in the summer and prefers average to dry soil. It is noteworthy for the number of Lepidoptera species it supports. It is a larval host to the bella moth, black-spotted prominent moth, cloudless sulpher, confused cloudy-wing, eastern tailed blue, gray hairstreak, southern","family":null,"flower_color":"Purple","flowering_season":false,"fruit_color":null,"growth_rate":"Moderate","harvest_season":null,"leaf_color":["Green"],"maintenance":"Low","origin":["North America"],"other_name":["hairy lespedeza"],"pest_susceptibility":["Leaf spots"],"propagation":["Seed Propagation"],"pruning_month":["November"],"scientific_name":["Lespedeza hirta"],"soil":["Well-drained","Sandy","Loamy"],"watering_period":"Morning"}}

{"type":"json_schema","json_schema":{"id":15019,"attracts":["Bees","Butterflies"],"care_guides_details":[{"type":"watering","description":"Solidago rugosa, commonly known as Rough Goldenrod, prefers moist to well-drained soil conditions. It is relatively drought-tolerant once established, but regular watering is necessary, especially during dry periods in its growing season. Ensure the soil does not completely dry out for extended periods, particularly in hot weather. When planting in a garden, it's beneficial to mulch around the base to retain soil moisture. Maintain a consistent watering schedule but avoid overwatering, which can lead to root rot. Aim to keep the soil consistently damp but not waterlogged for optimal growth and bloom production."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Solidago rugosa thrives best in full sun, requiring at least 6 to 8 hours of direct sunlight each day. While it can tolerate partial shade, abundant sunlight is crucial for maximum flowering and healthy growth. In areas with intense heat, it may benefit from some afternoon shade to prevent scorching. If planting in a garden with less sunlight, be prepared for reduced flowering and possibly a less vigorous plant. When considering a planting location, ensure that it gets ample sunlight throughout the day for optimal blooming and plant vitality."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning Solidago rugosa helps maintain its shape and encourage bushier growth. It is best to prune after the flowering season, typically in late fall or early spring. Start by removing dead or damaged stems and cutting back the spent flower spikes to the base of the plant to prevent self-seeding. To control its height and encourage a denser form, you can cut back about one-third of the plant's height before the growing season begins. Regular pruning also helps to minimize its spread if grown in a garden, as it can become quite invasive under ideal conditions."}],"care_level":"Easy","common_name":"common wrinkle-leaved goldenrod","description":"Solidago rugosa, commonly called the wrinkleleaf goldenrod or rough-stemmed goldenrod, is a species of flowering plant in the sunflower family (Asteraceae). It is usually found in wet to mesic habitats.","family":null,"flower_color":"Yellow","flowering_season":false,"fruit_color":null,"growth_rate":"Moderate","harvest_season":null,"leaf_color":["Green"],"maintenance":"Low","origin":["North America"],"other_name":["common wrinkle-leaved goldenrod"],"pest_susceptibility":[],"propagation":["Seed Propagation","Cutting"],"pruning_month":["March"],"scientific_name":["Solidago rugosa"],"soil":["Well-drained","Loamy","Sandy"],"watering_period":"Morning"}}

This encourages the plant to produce new shoots and retains its bushy appearance. You can also prune to shape the plant or control its size, removing any leggy growth. Regular pruning helps maintain the plant's vigor and can also be used to propagate more plants through cuttings."}],"care_level":"Medium","common_name":"Root Beer Plant","description":"Piper auritum (Hoja santa) is an aromatic herb with a heart-shaped, velvety leaf which grows in tropic Mesoamerica. {"type":"json_schema","json_schema":{"id":15813,"attracts":[],"care_guides_details":[{"type":"watering","description":"Sclerocactus parviflorus is a drought-tolerant cactus. It requires infrequent watering, typically once every 14-21 days during the growing season (spring and summer). Ensure the soil is completely dry between waterings to prevent root rot. During winter, reduce watering significantly, offering just enough moisture to prevent shriveling, approximately once a month. Be cautious of overwatering, as this species is sensitive to excess moisture. Use a well-draining cactus mix to further reduce water retention and promote healthy roots."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"This cactus thrives in full sun conditions, needing at least 6 to 8 hours of direct sunlight daily. It is well adapted to high-light environments typical of its natural habitat in arid regions. Providing ample sunlight ensures healthy growth and promotes flower production. If grown indoors, place the Sclerocactus parviflorus in the sunniest window, preferably a south-facing one. Be cautious of sunburn if transitioning the plant from indoors to outdoors; gradual acclimatization is advised. Insufficient light may lead to etiolation, affecting the plant's compact form."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning for Sclerocactus parviflorus generally involves minimal maintenance. It doesn’t require regular pruning, but you can remove any dead or damaged segments using sterile tools to prevent disease spread. Deadheading spent flowers may not be necessary, as this cactus naturally drops them. Be careful while handling the plant to avoid damage to its spines and to protect your hands. Pruning is best done in the dormant season to limit stress on the plant. Regular inspections can help identify any issues early, ensuring the plant remains healthy."}],"care_level":"High","common_name":"Smallflower Fishhook Cactus","description":null,"family":null,"flower_color":"Pink","flowering_season":false,"fruit_color":"[\"Brown\"]","growth_rate":"Low","harvest_season":null,"leaf_color":null,"maintenance":"Low","origin":["United States"],"other_name":["Smallflower Fishhook Cactus"],"pest_susceptibility":[],"propagation":["Seed Propagation"],"pruning_month":["April"],"scientific_name":["Sclerocactus parviflorus"],"soil":["Well-drained","Gravelly","Rocky"],"watering_period":"Morning"}}

Regular watering is essential, especially during its active growth periods. It's crucial to allow the top inch of soil to dry out between waterings to prevent root rot, particularly if the plant is potted. During the winter months, reduce watering frequency as the plant's growth slows down. Always check the soil moisture before watering by inserting your finger about an inch deep into the soil. If it feels dry, it's time to water."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Polygala rugelii thrives in bright, indirect light but can also tolerate partial shade. For optimal growth, place the plant in a location that receives morning sun and afternoon shade if you are growing it outdoors. If grown indoors, a spot near an east or west-facing window is ideal. Avoid exposing it to harsh, direct sunlight for long periods, as this can scorch the leaves. If you notice the plant becoming leggy, it may not be getting enough light and should be moved to a brighter location."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning Polygala rugelii is important to maintain its shape and encourage bushier growth. It's best to prune in early spring before the growing season begins. Use sharp, sterilized scissors or pruning shears to remove any dead, damaged, or diseased branches. Trim back leggy stems to promote fuller growth, and remove crossing branches to allow better air circulation. It's also beneficial to deadhead spent flowers during the blooming season to encourage more blooms and prevent the plant from focusing energy on seed production."}],"care_level":"Medium","common_name":"Yellow milkwort","description":"Polygala rugelii is a species of flowering plant in the milkwort family (Polygalaceae). {"type":"json_schema","json_schema":{"id":14721,"attracts":["Bees","Butterflies","Birds"],"care_guides_details":[{"type":"watering","description":"Helianthus mollis, commonly known as ashy sunflower, thrives in regular moisture but is also quite drought-tolerant once established. Water this plant thoroughly during its growing season, allowing the top inch of soil to dry out between waterings to prevent root rot. Ensure it receives at least one inch of water per week, either from rainfall or supplemental watering, especially during prolonged dry spells. Be cautious not to overwater in areas with high humidity, as this can lead to fungal issues. Mulching can help conserve soil moisture and keep the root system cool."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Helianthus mollis requires full sun to thrive, needing at least six hours of direct sunlight each day. Ideally, it should be planted in a location with unobstructed sunlight for the best growth and flowering. While it can tolerate partial shade, this may reduce its overall blooming potential and make the plant less robust. In areas with extremely hot climates, providing some afternoon shade can minimize heat stress and leaf scorching. Ensure the plant is in a well-ventilated, open space to reduce humidity around it and prevent fungal disease development."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning Helianthus mollis should be done in early spring or late fall to remove dead stems and promote healthy new growth. During the growing season, cutting back about one-third of the plant in late spring can encourage a bushier shape and more blooms. Deadheading throughout the blooming period can prolong flowering by preventing the plant from going to seed. If desired, you can prune spent flowers to tidy up the plant's appearance, but be sure to leave some if you want the seeds for wildlife or propagation."}],"care_level":"Easy","common_name":"ashy sunflower","description":"Helianthus mollis is a species of sunflower known by the common names ashy sunflower. It is widespread across much of the United States and Canada, primarily the Great Lakes region from Ontario south to Texas and Alabama. Additional populations are found in the states of the Atlantic Coast from Maine to Georgia, but these appear to be introduced.","family":null,"flower_color":"Yellow","flowering_season":false,"fruit_color":"[\"Brown\"]","growth_rate":"Moderate","harvest_season":null,"leaf_color":["Green"],"maintenance":"Low","origin":["North America"],"other_name":["ashy sunflower"],"pest_susceptibility":[],"propagation":["Seed Propagation","Division"],"pruning_month":["September"],"scientific_name":["Helianthus mollis"],"soil":["Well-drained","Loamy","Sandy"],"watering_period":"Morning"}}

{"type":"json_schema","json_schema":{"id":15415,"attracts":["Bees","Butterflies"],"care_guides_details":[{"type":"watering","description":"Tetraneuris scaposa, commonly known as Four-nerve daisy, prefers well-drained soil and is drought-tolerant, meaning it requires minimal watering once established. Overwatering can cause root rot, so it is important to let the soil dry out thoroughly between waterings. During periods of extreme drought or in particularly dry climates, occasional deep watering can help maintain its health, but generally, weekly watering or less is sufficient in regular conditions. Ensure that water does not pool around the plant as it thrives in dry, well-aerated soil conditions."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Tetraneuris scaposa thrives in full sun, requiring at least 6 to 8 hours of direct sunlight each day. It is well-suited for sunny spots in the garden where it can bask in the light it needs to produce a robust display of flowers. Although it can tolerate partial shade, too much shade may lead to fewer blossoms and leggy growth. Ideal locations include rock gardens, xeriscapes, or border fronts. Ensure it receives adequate sunlight by avoiding planting in areas overshadowed by taller plants or structures, which could inhibit its growth and flowering potential."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning Tetraneuris scaposa is relatively straightforward, as this plant generally maintains a tidy appearance. Deadhead spent flowers to encourage more blooms and maintain a neat appearance throughout the growing season. After the flowering period, trim back any dead or damaged stems to tidy up the plant and promote better air circulation. Prune in early spring or late fall, depending on the climate, to remove any old and woody growth, thus encouraging fresh, vibrant growth for the next bloom cycle. Minimal pruning needs make it a low-maintenance plant."}],"care_level":"Easy","common_name":"Stemmy Four-nerved Daisy","description":"Tetraneuris scaposa (common names stemmy four-nerve daisy and stemmy hymenoxys) is a North American species of plants in the sunflower family. {"type":"json_schema","json_schema":{"id":15118,"attracts":["Bees","Butterflies"],"care_guides_details":[{"type":"watering","description":"Cirsium nuttallii, commonly known as Nuttall's Thistle, prefers well-drained soils and can tolerate dry conditions once established. Water this plant moderately, ensuring the soil is allowed to dry out between watering sessions. Over-watering can lead to root rot, so it's crucial to avoid soggy soil. During the growing season, a weekly watering may be sufficient, depending on the climate and soil conditions. In hotter climates, it may require more frequent watering. Be mindful of local rainfall when adjusting your watering schedule."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Cirsium nuttallii thrives best in full sun, which means it requires a minimum of six to eight hours of direct sunlight daily. While it can tolerate some partial shade, especially in hotter climates, full sun exposure is ideal for optimal blooming and growth. In regions with intense heat, some afternoon shade can prevent leaf scorch, but too much shade can inhibit flowering. Ensure it is planted in a location that receives ample sunlight to ensure robust plant health and a prolific display of blooms."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning of Cirsium nuttallii is generally minimal. Deadheading the spent flowers can promote further blooming and prevent unwanted self-seeding, as this plant can reseed prolifically under favorable conditions.
