However, it is important to avoid waterlogging as it can lead to root rot. Water the plant deeply once a week if there is no rainfall, ensuring the top inch of soil remains moist but not overly saturated. During the summer, if the plant exhibits signs of wilting or drying, you can increase the frequency slightly, but always allow the soil to dry out a bit between waterings to encourage healthy root development."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Golden Columbine thrives best in partial shade to full sun environments, but in hotter climates, it benefits from some afternoon shade to protect it from intense sun exposure. The ideal situation provides morning sun and afternoon shade, which helps maintain its vibrant blooms and ensures optimal growth. Monitoring the plant for signs of sunburn, such as browning leaf edges, can help in adjusting the sunlight exposure to meet the plant's needs better."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning Aquilegia chrysantha involves deadheading spent flowers to encourage prolonged blooming and prevent self-seeding, which can lead to unwanted spreading in the garden. Trim the flower stalks down to the base once the blooms have faded. In late fall or early spring, cut back the foliage to ground level to eliminate any dead or damaged leaves, which helps prevent disease and tidy the plant's appearance. {"type":"json_schema","json_schema":{"id":15020,"attracts":["Bees","Butterflies"],"care_guides_details":[{"type":"watering","description":"Dactylorhiza viridis, commonly known as the frog orchid, prefers evenly moist conditions, especially during its growing season in the spring and early summer. Be cautious with watering, as these orchids do not tolerate waterlogged soil. Allow the top inch of soil to dry out between waterings, but ensure that the plant does not dry out completely. During its dormant period in the late summer and fall, reduce watering significantly. In natural settings, it typically thrives in environments with moderate moisture, so replicating these conditions will help the plant flourish."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Dactylorhiza viridis prefers partial shade to dappled sunlight conditions, mimicking the light environments of their natural woodland and meadow habitats. Direct sunlight, especially during the hottest parts of the day, should be avoided as it can lead to leaf burn or stress. Morning sun or filtered light through tree canopies can work well. Providing the orchid with adequate yet not excessive light is crucial for healthy growth and flowering. If growing indoors, placing the plant near an east-facing window can provide the needed light without overexposing it."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning Dactylorhiza viridis generally involves removing dead or yellowing foliage to allow the plant to focus its energy on healthy growth. This should be done by carefully cutting off the dead leaves at the base, making sure not to damage the surrounding healthy parts. After the flowering period, it's also recommended to remove any spent flower stalks to prevent energy wastage in seed production unless propagation through seeds is desired. Ensure tools used are sterilized to prevent disease and pest transmission, maintaining the plant’s health."}],"care_level":"Medium","common_name":"Frog Orchid","description":"Coeloglossum is a genus of orchids. It has long been considered to have only one species, Coeloglossum viride, the frog orchid. Some recent classifications regard Coeloglossum as part of the larger genus, Dactylorhiza, so that C. viride becomes Dactylorhiza viridis. Other sources continue to keep Coeloglossum viride separate.","family":null,"flower_color":"Green","flowering_season":false,"fruit_color":null,"growth_rate":"Low","harvest_season":null,"leaf_color":["Green"],"maintenance":"Moderate","origin":["Europe","Asia","North America"],"other_name":["Frog Orchid"],"pest_susceptibility":[],"propagation":["Seed Propagation"],"pruning_month":["March"],"scientific_name":["Dactylorhiza viridis"],"soil":["Well-drained","Loamy","Acidic"],"watering_period":"Morning"}}

It is drought-tolerant and prefers to dry out somewhat between waterings. Water deeply but infrequently, allowing the soil to dry at least halfway down the pot before watering again. Overwatering can lead to root rot, so ensure the plant is not sitting in water. During the dormant winter months, reduce watering even further. Generally, this plant fares better with less water than too much, so err on the side of under-watering rather than over-watering to keep it healthy."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Eryngium carlinae thrives in full sun conditions, needing at least 6 to 8 hours of direct sunlight each day to maintain its health and vibrant blooms. It prefers bright, unobstructed sunlight to mimic its natural environment. Placing it in a south-facing windowsill or outdoors where it can receive abundant sunlight is ideal. Although it is adaptable, insufficient sunlight can lead to leggy growth and reduced flowering. If grown indoors, supplement with a grow light during darker months to provide adequate light exposure for optimal development and flowering."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning Eryngium carlinae involves removing dead or damaged leaves and stems to encourage healthy growth and improve its appearance. This is best done in early spring before new growth begins. Use clean, sharp scissors or secateurs to cut back to the base of the plant or to a healthy lateral bud. Removing spent flowers can help to extend the blooming period by triggering new blooms. Be sure to wear gloves and long sleeves during pruning as the plant can be spiny and may cause mild skin irritation. Avoid cutting too severely, as this might stress the plant."}],"care_level":"Medium","common_name":"Toad's Herb","description":null,"family":null,"flower_color":"Blue","flowering_season":false,"fruit_color":null,"growth_rate":"Moderate","harvest_season":null,"leaf_color":["Green"],"maintenance":"Low","origin":["Mexico"],"other_name":["Toad's Herb"],"pest_susceptibility":[],"propagation":["Seed Propagation"],"pruning_month":["November"],"scientific_name":["Eryngium carlinae"],"soil":["Well-drained","Gravelly"],"watering_period":"Morning"}}

{"type":"json_schema","json_schema":{"id":14422,"attracts":["Birds"],"care_guides_details":[{"type":"watering","description":"Morella cerifera, commonly known as wax myrtle, prefers moderate watering. It is relatively drought-tolerant once established, but it thrives with regular watering to maintain optimal growth, especially during extended dry periods. Water deeply once a week during the growing season to ensure thorough saturation of the root zone. Reduce watering frequency in the fall and winter months when the plant is not actively growing. Always allow the top inch of soil to dry out between waterings to prevent overwatering, which can lead to root rot. Ensure proper drainage to avoid waterlogging the soil."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Morella cerifera thrives in full sun to partial shade. It grows best with at least six hours of direct sunlight per day, which promotes robust growth and enhances its foliage density and fragrance. While it can tolerate partial shade, the plant may become less dense and may not flower as profusely if it does not receive enough sunlight. In very hot climates, some afternoon shade can be beneficial to prevent leaf scorch. Position the plant in a location where it can receive morning sun and, if possible, a bit of afternoon shade, to ensure optimal growth conditions."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning Morella cerifera is best done in late winter or early spring before new growth begins. Regular pruning helps maintain its shape and encourages dense foliage. Remove dead, damaged, or diseased branches to promote healthy growth. Thin out overcrowded branches to improve air circulation, which helps reduce disease risk. For a more formal appearance, shear lightly to maintain desired shape. This plant responds well to rejuvenation pruning, which involves cutting it back significantly to encourage fresh, vigorous growth. Always use clean, sharp tools to make clean cuts and reduce the risk of infection."}],"care_level":"Medium","common_name":"wax myrtle","description":"Myrica cerifera is a small tree or large shrub native to North and Central America and the Caribbean. Its common names include southern wax myrtle, southern bayberry, candleberry, bayberry tree, and tallow shrub. It sees uses both in the garden and for candlemaking, as well as a medicinal plant.","family":null,"flower_color":"Yellow","flowering_season":false,"fruit_color":"[\"Bluish-white\"]","growth_rate":"Moderate","harvest_season":"Autumn","leaf_color":["Green"],"maintenance":"Moderate","origin":["North America"],"other_name":["wax myrtle"],"pest_susceptibility":[],"propagation":["Seed Propagation","Cutting"],"pruning_month":["February"],"scientific_name":["Morella cerifera"],"soil":["Well-drained","Sandy","Loamy","Acidic"],"watering_period":"Morning"}}

It's fairly drought-tolerant once established, so allow the soil to dry out slightly between waterings. In its natural habitat, the plant can survive on rainfall alone, but during prolonged dry spells or in very hot weather, occasional deep watering can help the plant thrive. Be careful not to overwater, as this can lead to root rot and other moisture-related problems. Always ensure the container or ground has proper drainage to prevent standing water."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Solidago odora prefers full sun to partial shade for optimal growth. Ideally, it should receive at least 6 to 8 hours of sunlight a day to produce the best display of blooms. While it can tolerate light shade, the flowering may be reduced and the plant can become leggy. In very hot climates, a little afternoon shade can protect the plant from intense heat. Ensure that, if planted in a shaded area, it still gets enough light for photosynthesis, or growth may be stunted."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning Solidago odora is mainly done to maintain shape and promote bushiness. Cut back up to half of the plant in late spring or early summer to encourage denser growth and more blooms. After flowering, deadhead spent blooms to maintain a tidy appearance and potentially prompt a second bloom cycle. In late fall, after the plant has died back, some gardeners choose to cut back stems to just above the ground to tidy the garden and prepare for spring growth, though this is optional as the plant will die back naturally over winter."}],"care_level":"Easy","common_name":"Sweet Goldenrod","description":"Solidago odora, whose English name is sweet goldenrod, also referred to as anisescented goldenrod or fragrant goldenrod is a North American species of goldenrods within the sunflower family. It flowers from July through October.","family":null,"flower_color":"Yellow","flowering_season":false,"fruit_color":null,"growth_rate":"Moderate","harvest_season":"Summer","leaf_color":["Green"],"maintenance":"Low","origin":["United States"],"other_name":["Sweet Goldenrod"],"pest_susceptibility":[],"propagation":["Seed Propagation","Cutting"],"pruning_month":["February"],"scientific_name":["Solidago odora"],"soil":["Well-drained"],"watering_period":"Morning"}}

{"type":"json_schema","json_schema":{"id":15119,"attracts":["Bees","Butterflies"],"care_guides_details":[{"type":"watering","description":"Rosa virginiana requires moderate watering to thrive. It generally prefers well-drained soil, so it's important not to overwater to prevent root rot. Water the plant deeply once a week, allowing the top inch of soil to dry out between waterings. During hotter summer months, it may require more frequent watering, particularly if there has been minimal rainfall. Always water at the base of the plant to keep the foliage dry, reducing the risk of diseases. Ensure good drainage and avoid waterlogged conditions to maintain the plant’s health."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Rosa virginiana thrives in full sunlight, requiring at least six to eight hours of direct sunlight daily for optimal growth and blooming. While it can tolerate partial shade, insufficient sunlight may result in fewer blooms and leggy growth. Planting in an area where it receives morning sun is beneficial, as it helps to dry off the morning dew and reduces the risk of fungal diseases. In hotter climates, providing some afternoon shade can help prevent leaf scorch and maintain the plant’s overall vigor. Ensure a location that prioritizes good sunlight exposure."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Prune Rosa virginiana in early spring before new growth begins. Start by removing any dead, damaged, or crossing branches to maintain good air circulation and healthy growth. Next, cut back about one-third of the previous year’s growth to encourage bushier growth and more blooms. Make cuts at a 45-degree angle about a quarter-inch above outward-facing buds to foster proper growth direction. Throughout the growing season, remove spent flowers and any suckers. Regular pruning promotes robust health, enhances flowering, and controls the size of the shrub."}],"care_level":"Medium","common_name":"Virginian Rose","description":"Rosa virginiana, commonly known as the Virginia rose, common wild rose or prairie rose, is a woody perennial in the rose family native to eastern North America, where it is the most common wild rose. It is deciduous, forming a suckering shrub up to 2 metres in height, though often less. The stems are covered in numerous hooked prickles. The leaves are pinnate, usually with between 7 and 9 glossy leaflets. The pink flowers are borne...","family":null,"flower_color":"Pink","flowering_season":false,"fruit_color":"[\"Red\"]","growth_rate":"Moderate","harvest_season":"Autumn","leaf_color":["Green"],"maintenance":"Moderate","origin":["North America"],"other_name":["Virginian Rose"],"pest_susceptibility":["Fungal leaf spot","Mildew","Aphids","Rose Sawfly"],"propagation":["Cutting","Seed Propagation"],"pruning_month":["March"],"scientific_name":["Rosa virginiana"],"soil":["Well-drained","Loamy"],"watering_period":"Morning"}}

{"type":"json_schema","json_schema":{"id":14423,"attracts":["Birds"],"care_guides_details":[{"type":"watering","description":"Cocculus carolinus, commonly known as Carolina Snailseed, prefers consistent moisture but can tolerate short periods of drought once established. In general, you should water it regularly to keep the soil relatively moist, particularly during dry spells in the growing season. During the plant's dormant period in winter, reduce watering frequency to prevent overwatering."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Cocculus carolinus thrives in full sun to partial shade. For optimal growth, it should receive at least 4 to 6 hours of direct sunlight per day. In hotter climates, providing some afternoon shade can help prevent the leaves from scorching, while in cooler areas, full sun helps ensure vigorous growth. Planting in a location with morning sun and afternoon shade can provide a balanced environment for this versatile plant."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning of Cocculus carolinus should be done in late winter or early spring before new growth starts. This helps stimulate healthy growth and maintain its shape. Remove any dead, damaged, or diseased branches to encourage better ventilation and sunlight penetration. Regularly check for and remove suckers or new shoots near the base to prevent unwanted spreading."}],"care_level":"Medium","common_name":"Carolina snailseed","description":"Cocculus carolinus, commonly called the Carolina coralbead, or snailseed, is a perennial vine of the moonseed family (Cocculus). {"type":"json_schema","json_schema":{"id":15416,"attracts":["Bees","Butterflies"],"care_guides_details":[{"type":"watering","description":"Mecardonia acuminata prefers consistently moist soil but is not tolerant of standing water. Water the plant regularly to keep the soil evenly moist but allow the top layer to dry out slightly between waterings. The frequency of watering may vary depending on the climate and season, with higher frequency needed in warmer months and less in cooler months. It is crucial to avoid overwatering as this can lead to root rot. Checking soil moisture with your finger can help determine when it's time to water again."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Mecardonia acuminata thrives in full sun to partial shade. For optimal growth and flowering, providing at least 6 hours of direct sunlight per day is ideal. In regions with intensely hot climates, it may benefit from afternoon shade to prevent scorching. If grown indoors or in less sunny areas, supplementing light with grow lights can help. An environment with too little sunlight may result in fewer blooms and a leggier appearance, so ensure it's placed where it can receive adequate light exposure."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning Mecardonia acuminata is generally done to promote bushier growth and to remove any dead or damaged stems. It can be lightly pruned throughout the growing season to maintain a compact shape. To do so, trim back any leggy stems and spent flowers to encourage more blooms and tidy up the plant appearance. In the fall, a more significant pruning can be performed if the plant looks overgrown, but it's often best to leave some growth to protect its roots in colder climates."}],"care_level":"Easy","common_name":"common axil-flower","description":null,"family":null,"flower_color":"Yellow","flowering_season":false,"fruit_color":null,"growth_rate":"Moderate","harvest_season":null,"leaf_color":["Green"],"maintenance":"Low","origin":["South America"],"other_name":["common axil-flower"],"pest_susceptibility":[],"propagation":["Cutting","Seed Propagation"],"pruning_month":["January"],"scientific_name":["Mecardonia acuminata"],"soil":["Well-drained","Loamy"],"watering_period":"Morning"}}

It is a declared noxious weed in Puerto Rico and is naturalised in northern Australia, including Queensland where it is listed as a Class 2 declared pest plant. It grows to 2.5–4 m (8.2–13.1 ft) high. {"type":"json_schema","json_schema":{"id":15517,"attracts":[],"care_guides_details":[{"type":"watering","description":"Podocarpus macrophyllus, also known as the Buddhist Pine, thrives when its soil is kept consistently moist but never waterlogged. Overwatering can lead to root rot, so ensure good drainage and allow the top inch of soil to dry between waterings. In spring and summer, water more frequently, about once a week, to support active growth. During the cooler months, reduce watering to every two weeks or when the soil feels dry to the touch, as the plant's growth slows down. Always use room temperature water to avoid shocking the roots."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Podocarpus macrophyllus prefers bright, indirect sunlight but can tolerate some direct light, especially in the morning or late afternoon. Ideally, it should be placed in a spot where it receives at least 4 to 6 hours of bright light daily. However, in extremely hot regions, providing afternoon shade can prevent leaf burn. If grown indoors, place it near a north or east-facing window. Too little light can result in leggy growth and sparse foliage, so adjusting the plant's position according to light availability is crucial for its health."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning Podocarpus macrophyllus helps maintain its shape and encourages bushier growth. Ideally, prune the plant in late winter or early spring before new growth begins. Use clean, sharp pruning shears to remove dead, damaged, or diseased branches. To promote a compact form, trim back any overly long shoots or branches, cutting just above a leaf node to encourage branching. Light trimming throughout the growing season can also help control the size and shape, but avoid cutting back more than one-third of the plant at any time to prevent stress."}],"care_level":"Medium","common_name":"kusamaki","description":"Podocarpus macrophyllus is a conifer in the genus Podocarpus, family Podocarpaceae. It is the northernmost species of the genus, native to southern Japan and southern and eastern China. Common names in English include yew plum pine, Buddhist pine and fern pine. Kusamaki (クサマキ) and inumaki (犬槇) are Japanese names for this tree. In China, it is known as 羅漢松 or luóhàn sōng, which literally means \"arhat pine\".","family":null,"flower_color":null,"flowering_season":false,"fruit_color":"[\"Purple\"]","growth_rate":"Moderate","harvest_season":null,"leaf_color":["Green"],"maintenance":"Low","origin":["China","Japan"],"other_name":["kusamaki"],"pest_susceptibility":[],"propagation":["Seed Propagation","Cutting"],"pruning_month":["March"],"scientific_name":["Podocarpus macrophyllus"],"soil":["Well-drained","Loamy"],"watering_period":"Morning"}}

Instead, care should be focused on maintaining the appropriate environmental conditions to facilitate its growth. Understanding the natural growth cycle and habitat requirements is key to supporting its healthy development."}],"care_level":"Medium","common_name":"Common Fiber Vase","description":"Thelephora terrestris is a species of fungus in the basidiomycota phylum that is an inedible mushroom. {"type":"json_schema","json_schema":{"id":14820,"attracts":["Butterflies","Hummingbirds"],"care_guides_details":[{"type":"watering","description":"Ruellia simplex, commonly known as Mexican petunia, prefers consistently moist soil, but it is relatively drought-tolerant once established. To keep the plant healthy and vibrant, water it regularly, especially during dry spells. Watering deeply once or twice a week should suffice, ensuring that the soil doesn’t dry out completely. Avoid over-watering as this can lead to root rot. In containers, water until it drains through the bottom, but do not let the plant sit in water. Adjust the frequency of watering based on the climate and season, reducing it during the plant's dormant winter period."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Ruellia simplex thrives in full sunlight, needing at least six to eight hours of direct sunlight each day for optimal blooming. It can tolerate partial shade but may become leggy and produce fewer flowers in such conditions. The plant is quite adaptable and can handle the hot afternoon sun, making it suitable for sunny garden spots or as a highlight in borders. Ensure the plant receives adequate sunlight to maintain its vibrant blooms and prevent it from becoming too sparse or lanky. If grown indoors or in a pot, place it near a bright window facing south or west."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning Ruellia simplex is essential for maintaining its shape and encouraging bushier growth. Trim back the stems in late winter or early spring before the new growth begins. You can cut the stems back by about a third to promote branching. Throughout the growing season, remove spent flowers and any dead or damaged stems to encourage continuous blooming and prevent disease. If the plant becomes leggy or overgrown, light pruning during active growth can help maintain its form. "},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning of Aureolaria pectinata should be minimal, as it naturally maintains a fairly neat growth habit. Deadhead spent flowers regularly to prolong the flowering period and prevent the plant from self-seeding too aggressively. Water the plant regularly to keep the soil evenly damp but not waterlogged. During hot and dry weather, increase watering frequency and consider additional misting to keep the fronds hydrated. Using rainwater or distilled water is ideal as the plant is sensitive to chemicals in tap water. It is essential to ensure proper drainage to prevent root rot, especially when grown in pots. Mulching around the base can help retain moisture and maintain a stable root environment."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Dicksonia antarctica prefers partial to full shade, mimicking the dappled light conditions of its natural habitat beneath the forest canopy. Direct sunlight, especially during the midday and afternoon, can damage the fronds, leading to browning and scorching. If planted outdoors, choose a location with filtered light or provide artificial shading if necessary. When grown indoors, place the plant near north or east-facing windows where it can receive indirect light. Ensuring the right balance of light will support healthy growth and maintain the plant's verdant foliage."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning Dicksonia antarctica should be minimal and focused on removing dead or damaged fronds to maintain its appearance and health. Carefully trim off any brown or withered fronds at the base using clean and sharp scissors or pruning shears. This can be done at any time of the year as needed. Avoid excessive pruning, as the old fronds provide natural insulation for the trunk in colder weather. Regularly checking and cleaning the plant will help promote healthy new growth and maintain its lush appearance."}],"care_level":"Medium","common_name":"man fern","description":"Dicksonia antarctica (soft tree fern, man fern) is a species of evergreen tree fern native to eastern Australia, ranging from south-east Queensland, coastal New South Wales and Victoria to Tasmania.","family":null,"flower_color":null,"flowering_season":false,"fruit_color":null,"growth_rate":"Moderate","harvest_season":null,"leaf_color":["Green"],"maintenance":"Moderate","origin":["Australia","Tasmania"],"other_name":["man fern"],"pest_susceptibility":[],"propagation":["Spores"],"pruning_month":["March"],"scientific_name":["Dicksonia antarctica"],"soil":["Well-drained","Humus-rich"],"watering_period":"Morning"}}
